TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 13 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islander Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as happened with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That, if the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty year leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests.

That, on past evidence, these interests will clearly have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government.

That the Commonwealth Government has the constitutional power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your petitioners' sincere belief it has already failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self-management.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 106 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profitting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst, pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing therefore, your petitioners urge that:
1. All pension and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
3. Reintroduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

4. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 95 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Romanian government is committing genocide against the 3 million strong native born Hungarian population in Romania as defined in Articles II. and III. of the United Nations Convention on the Crime of Genocide which fact is well documented by many internationally accepted study groups, Amnesty International, etc.

That the Article IV. of the Convention states: ''Persons committing genocide or any other acts enumerated in Article III. shall be punished whether they are constitutionally responsible rulers, public officials or private individuals''.

That Article VIII. of the Convention states: ''Any contracting party may call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such actions under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of the act of genocide or any of the other acts enumerated in Article III''.

As Australia is a contracting party to the Convention and the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence has already established precedent by having investigating Human Rights violations in other countries,
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

1. That the Joint Committee for Foreign Affairs and Defence to take up an investigation into the alleged genocide activities of the Romanian government against its Hungarian population in Romania; and

2. That if such investigation should establish that Romania has been engaged in acts of genocide aforesaid, to call upon the competent organs of the United Nations to take such action under the Charter of the United Nations as they consider appropriate for the prevention and suppression of acts of genocide or any acts enumerated in the Convention on Crime of Genocide.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 266 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable President and Senators in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and Second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich. Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a ''poor risk'' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans; it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 Colleges of Advanced Education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students;
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced;
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance;
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MACKLIN

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 825 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criteria for entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graudate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part-time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50% of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22% of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22 per cent of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threaten Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric development in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the national Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Community Youth Support Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(1) That the decision by the Federal Government to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme will dash the only hope that thousands of teenagers have of finding any employment.
(2) That the abandonment of the scheme will remove a valuable link between society and the unemployed.
(3) That there is ample evidence to show that the scheme is working effectively.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, will reject outright any proposal to abolish the Community Youth Support Scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Crimes Act 1914, and for related purposes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence: Australia's defence co-operation with its neighbours in the Asian-Pacific region, with particular reference to the present scope, purpose, effectiveness and flexibility of such co-operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Is it true that, under the present Government, indirect taxes have risen at twice the inflation rate? Has the Government budgeted for a yield this year from excise duty and sales tax of more than $9,000m, or well over twice as much as was raised in 1975-76? Have direct taxes on single income families with two children risen by 81 per cent in real terms over the last six years? If the Minister cannot today confirm these matters as fact, will she do so as soon as possible?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of facts were requested in the question by Senator Button. I will need to have those figures and facts checked, and I will undertake to bring a response from the Treasurer as soon as possible.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. Has the Minister noted an item in the Sydney Morning Herald in which it is alleged that the Senate of the University of Sydney, the University's governing body, has advised the Federal Government that it is unwilling to implement the collection of tuition fees from second and higher degree students? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether the report as alleged is correct? If so, what steps can the Federal Government take to ensure that fees of second and higher degree students are collected once legislation to that effect is implemented?

—I did see an article in a newspaper to the effect that Senator Lajovic has stated, but I am not sure whether it was accurate. Unless I were to see an official report from the Senate of the University of Sydney I could not comment on the article. The Government will proceed with its legislation. Once the legislation has been carried, it is then a matter for its implementation. I do not think we should deal with hypothetical situations. One thing is certain: This is the elected Government. Its Budget is an integral whole. It is necessary for--
—It has a few holes in it now.

—The people who make those kinds of comments must have forgotten the three years of Whitlam Government Budgets that looked like a colander. They must have forgotten the month by month in which promises of the Whitlam Government faded into disarray time after time. They must also have forgotten the statements by their own leaders who have condemned their own actions in that time. This Government has introduced its policies. They are part of the Budget. The Government intends that those policies should be carried out in an orderly fashion. We believe that the community itself will act to carry them out.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Can the Minister inform the Parliament what has been the total cost to date of compensation payments as a result of the Government's decision to boycott the Moscow Olympics and the introduction of certain trade sanctions? Is it a fact that the promotion company Michael Edgley International Pty Ltd received $760,000 and that a further claim is still to be settled? It is also a fact that the Australian Government will be required to make compensation payments well in excess of $15m? Can the Minister also advise the total income lost by Australia as a result of the Government's decision selectively to ban various exports to Russia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A number of compensation claims have been dealt with. The claims, which were assessed by my Department and by the departments of the relevant Ministers, were received up to 12 December 1980. On 26 August, in answer to question No. 2872, I gave the details of the payments made. I understand that since that time there has been an interim claim, and a final claim may or may not be lodged. One other claim has been rejected. But I could not give the precise total at present, although I think I could have that ascertained before the end of Question Time. I think that I could then give Senator Keeffe the total payments that have been made under this compensation arrangement. However, he may be interested in the answer to question No. 2872, in which some detail along the lines that he has requested was provided. The matter of income lost to Australia I would need to have pursued to see whether any figure or information could be readily given to the Senate.

—I ask a supplementary question. I am aware of what is contained in question No. 2872. However, I ask the Minister whether the information that she kindly promised to obtain today can contain the updated figures, not the original figures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — If I am not able to obtain the up-to-date figures today I will certainly see that they are obtained within a very short time.

—Is the Attorney-General aware of complaints in Queensland about delays in the Family Court of Australia with respect to custody and property applications? Is the Minister aware that when delays are protracted and extend for a year or more inflating property values can frustrate or deny the hopes of one partner to buy out the other? What action does the Minister propose to take to overcome this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of complaints that are made quite frequently about delays in the hearing of custody and property disputes in the Family Court. I am not immediately aware of complaints about specific delays in Queensland. I do not know exactly what the delay is in Queensland at present. But there have been delays and there are delays of varying periods in different registries of the Family Court in Australia. There are delays in most courts in Australia. It is always a problem for litigants when these delays occur. Unless we largely increase the number of judges and thereby greatly increase the expenses of running our system of justice in courts generally, it is very difficult for people to have their cases heard immediately.

ANSWER.PARA: In the Family Court area, apart from increasing the number of judges to some extent, we have been relying on increasing the number of counsellors and deputy registrars. In custody cases they attempt-in a large number of cases they are successful-to settle the dispute, whether it be related to access or custody. The deputy registrars conduct conferences to try to resolve property disputes, and in many cases succeed. That has proved to be a successful way of reducing the number of cases coming to court which demand the time of judges and thereby cause delays. There has been quite significant success in this direction. Despite the interjections that Senator Evans has been trying to make and despite all his speech making on the subject last night, there has been in fact quite considerable success in the Melbourne registry. I note that he acknowledges that, and I thank him.

When I became Attorney-General four years ago there were very serious delays in Melbourne, and we set about tackling them. Very considerable reductions in delays have occurred there. I believe, and the Chief Judge of the court believes, that this is the most appropriate way of tackling the problem. I am answering the question generally because as I said earlier I have no specific information about the particular complaint in Queensland that Senator MacGibbon raises at present. I will look into that and provide him with a specific answer shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment aware that it is now some seven weeks since the term of the last National Women's Advisory Council ended and that the composition of the new council has yet to be announced? Can the Minister justify this delay which, I might add, is a repetition of last year's situation and which is apparently inexcusable in the light of the fact that all States have had their nominations in for some time? Further, can the Minister explain why Cabinet keeps postponing what is really a very simple decision, if it is not due to the fact that this Government has given a very low priority to women's issues? Finally, can the Minister say exactly when the announcement of the composition of the National Women's Advisory Council will be made and thus put an end to the concern being felt among many women's groups in the community that this Government really does not care about the status of women in Australia?

—It does not really help the business of government or the business of the community to have the kind of cheap comment that Senator Haines offered at the end of her question. This Government has a continuing and firm commitment to the welfare of women. More than that, from time to time the Senate has had before it a large number of petitions which have drawn attention to the composition of the National Women's Advisory Council and which have asked the Government to take into account certain views. I take it that the honourable senator would want the Government to give the fullest possible consideration to all viewpoints that have been put before it. It is not a question of justifying delay. The question is that the Minister involved considers the appointments to the National Women's Advisory Council to be important appointments. He considers the Council to be important. He considers the job to be one that has to be done with proper consideration. The consideration of the appointments is continuing, and the appointments will be announced at an appropriate time when those considerations are complete.

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate as it seems to overlap other ministries. It has been alleged to me that some large fishing groups in the Northern Territory are able to obtain government subsidised diesel fuel for prawn trawlers at Groote Eylandt for 17c a litre which they ship in bulk down to Karumba and fuel their vessels. I am told that they get their fuel from a mining company at Groote Eylandt. Will the Minister investigate the allegations and let the Senate know the results as soon as possible? The smaller operators who have to pay 29c a litre for their fuel are going crook because they are going broke faster than the bigger operators.

—I am not aware of any such happening. The fishing industry is a primary industry and as such it obtains diesel fuel without the addition of the tax that road operators pay for diesel. I am not aware of the divergence which applies to those in the north and particularly around Groote Eylandt. I will look at the matter and certainly, if anything arises from it, I will inform the honourable senator.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the United Nations Agreement on the Importation of Educational, Scientific and Cultural Materials opened for signature at Lake Success, New York, on 22 November 1950? Has Australia ratified this agreement? Will the Minister list the outstanding United Nations documents awaiting ratification by Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will refer that question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and seek the information that has been requested.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I draw the Minister's attention to an article by Sue Cook in today's Australian wherein it is alleged that Professor Llewellyn-Jones has stated that unnecessary surgery is being performed on Australian women. The article also states that the Australian Medical Association has viewed this matter seriously enough that it announced last week two surgical audits to look into these claims. Is the Minister aware of any evidence to support these assertions? If so, what are the dangers to women undergoing these surgical procedures unnecessarily? What action can his Department take to discourage unnecessary surgery?

—I am not aware of the article which appeared today but I am aware of Professor Derek Llewellyn-Jones's standing as a gynaecologist. I am also aware of his position close to the Doctors Reform Society and I take it that any view he expresses would be a view of the Doctors Reform Society. If there is unnecessary surgery I would find that a matter for grave concern and I would imagine all honourable senators would want to compliment the Australian Medical Association on the stand it has taken in starting the inquiry to investigate the basis of any unnecessary surgery. I remind the Senate that the Australian Medical Association is still the majority association representing doctors in Australia. It is a proper body to undertake such a study and I believe it is a sign of the emerging and continuing role of the AMA in matters of social importance that it should seek to carry out such a study.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. Is the Minister aware of the hardships placed by the current Government on recipients of invalid pension benefits who have the long term hope of rejoining the work force? In the International Year of Disabled Persons, what incentive for disabled Australians to seek work does the Government see in the 50c in the dollar reduction in pension which occurs when the net income of disabled people is as much as $50 a week below the poverty line? Will the Minister comment on why disabled people should accept this disincentive of reduced pensions when the Prime Minister's annual travel budget is itself twice the cost to the Australian community as would be the raising to the poverty line of permissible earnings for people working in sheltered workshops?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The invalid pensioner, in common with a number of other social security beneficiaries, is subject to an income test which is in fact designed to ensure that there is incentive for the invalid pensioner to increase his or her income. That incentive is provided by the fact that there is an income test free area and by the fact that for earnings above that income test free area the reduction in pension is not dollar for dollar but, as the honourable senator indicated in his question, on the basis of 50c in the dollar. That means that the invalid pensioner continues to receive a part pension as his or her earnings increase, and that applies, of course, whether the pensioner is in or outside a sheltered workshop. Of course, for those invalid pensioners who are able to assume employment the question as to their continuing eligibility for the invalid pension does arise; that is, if they are not in a sheltered workshop situation. But of course the invalid pension is predicated on the fact that the person is 85 per cent disabled for work.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter of incentives is a matter which is very much in the forefront of the debate which is proceeding in Australia and which this year is being promoted in the community by the disabled themselves on the merits and the adequacies and inadequacies of the income maintenance system. One of the strong demands which is being made by the disabled is for an easing of the income test either by a lessening of the withdrawal rate or by an extension of the income test free area. With respect to those demands, as recently as last week I had discussions with disabled people who are participants in the national committee of non-government organisations for the year of the disabled and we discussed the matter on the basis that the disabled, through the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled, are promoting discussion. A great number of papers have been put together on the best approaches which might be adopted in the income maintenance field for disabled people.

I have indicated that I do not believe it is appropriate for the Government to pre-empt the conclusion of those discussions, that we should await their conclusion and then give them careful consideration. For example, I have arranged to meet a group of disabled people in Sydney on Friday week on the very subject that the honourable senator has raised. It is very much on the Government's agenda at the moment, but I would not expect decisions to be taken within a matter of weeks. Rather, as I have indicated to those disabled people who have been in touch with me, I would expect to receive the results of the extensive discussions which have been promoted by ACROD and which ACROD is now in the process of refining and finalising.

In fact, people on the invalid pension or people in sheltered workshops do have something of an advantage over other social security beneficiaries. Honourable senators would be aware that these people receive their pensions free of income tax so that in fact the disincentive for them in terms of additional earnings is less than it is for other social security beneficiaries who have to pay tax. The withdrawal rate of 50c in the dollar is not complicated, until they get up to earnings of about $80 a week, by the fact that income tax is also deducted. This is not the occasion on which to make a lengthy speech on that matter. But I acknowledge that the question of disincentive is a serious matter which is being raised in a number of quarters at the moment. I do not believe it is a simple matter. It is not unrelated to the whole shape of the social security system. The issue is raised not merely by those who are invalid but also by supporting parents, by the unemployed and by other people dependent upon the state for support. I can only say that in trying to arrive at sensible conclusions in this matter the Government will be listening to the views of the disabled themselves and will, within the limits of what is available from taxpayers, move to improve the system as much as possible.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, refers to the Government's financial support for tertiary education in Australia. Has the editorial in today's Australian Financial Review been brought to the Minister's attention? The editorial refers to yesterday's protest in terms of spokesmen for universities putting sectional interests above intellectual principle and now descending to a sordid squabble over funds. The editorial states:

QUESTION.PARA: It is now clear that the universities in their approach to the question of public funding have no longer any integrity to defend . . . The maintenance of a school of engineering at the fourth university in the Melbourne-Geelong area, which would involve wasteful duplication of facilities, has nothing to do with any genuine concept of academic freedom.

Is it not true that universities are spending funds extracted by taxes from the people as a whole? Is it not true that the Government's decisions allocating resources do not compromise genuine academic autonomy? Finally, is it not true that the Commonwealth Government truly supports academic freedom in Australia's universities and colleges?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read a number of comments published in the Press alleging that the Government's policies in its Budget are a threat to academic freedom. Quite rightly, the Australian Financial Review rejects that as absolute nonsense. The fact of the matter is that institutions do not have licence or total liberty to do what they want in anything. Educational institutions have been set up over the years for specific purposes. Individual faculties in individual institutions have been decided by State and Federal governments over the years. Academic freedom is breached when a government or anyone else invervenes in the philosophical or methodological teaching of a subject. The freedom is to teach the subject matters, the facts and opinions objectively. There is no attempt whatsoever by this Government to intervene in terms of academic freedom. The decision of whether there ought to be a school of engineering is a very proper decision for a government in terms of its responsibility for taxpayers' money. I repeat: All State governments have done this at regular intervals; it is absolutely normal.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the people of Australia that we have a Tertiary Education Commission, headed by Professor Karmel, one of Australia's leading academics, who himself has a full understanding of academic freedom, and advised by individual councils, including a Universities Council. Indeed, the essential recommendations that at this moment are being carried out by the Government are based upon those emanating from the councils and from the Tertiary Education Commission. There is no likelihood that the Commission or the Universities Council would seek by any action to breach academic freedom. So the answer to that assertion is that it is absolute nonsense. It is true that this Government has the responsibility for the spending on education of massive amounts of taxpayers' money. It has a right and proper responsibility to see that that money is spent properly and well. I must say that I hold in lesser regard than hitherto many people, whose statements I have read in the newspapers, for having attempted to use absolute propaganda for such purposes when they ought to have known better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware of complaints that the maintenance sections of Telecom Australia have not received substantial supplies for some two months? Is he also aware that new services are not available in some States because new phones have to be dismantled for spare parts to maintain existing services? Will the Minister advise the Senate whether this deliberate choking off is a means of establishing that Telecom is inefficient, thus conditioning people for the sale of that authority to private enterprise?

—There is no deliberate choking off of Telecom, its resources, or its facilities. In that regard, the question is inaccurately based. I am not able to advise the honourable senator whether supplies have been interfered with over a period of some two months; nor am I able to tell the honourable senator whether equipment has had to be cannibalised to obtain spare parts. I will refer those matters to the Minister for Communications and seek specific information for the honourable senator.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, relates to the latest meeting of the Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council, which was held in Brisbane on 28 September 1981, and in particular to the failure of the Federal and Queensland governments to reach agreement on the boundary of the second section, the Cairns section, of the proposed park because of the insistence of the Queensland Government that the park boundaries be kept at least three miles off the coast. While I recognise that the Commonwealth has sought to work in conjunction with Queensland to save the Reef, I ask: Does the Minister agree that this policy of co-operative action has not produced proper security for the future of the reef, which is a national and international asset of priceless value? In view of widespread public demands for urgent action, will the Australian Government now exercise its powers under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act to proclaim at least the Cairns section, if not the remainder of the reef areas, as part of the marine park?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that negotiations on these matters are continuing, so the exercise of Commonwealth power at this stage may be premature.
—It may go on forever.

—The honourable senator says that negotiations may go on forever. I am sure that they will not. The Great Barrier Reef Ministerial Council met in Brisbane on 28 September. My colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, is the convenor of the Council and the other members are the Minister for Science and Technology, Mr Thomson, the Queensland Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Ahern, and the Queensland Minister for Tourism, Mr Elliott. The major decisions of the Council were as follows: The Council endorsed the management guidelines in the three-year rolling program prepared for the Capricornia section of the marine park. The Council agreed to recommend that action proceed immediately to enable proclamation of an area which would protect a colony of potato cod, which is a particular attraction to divers because of the unusual size and tameness of these fish. The Council noted the detailed reports of a working group on proposals for the boundaries of the proposed Cairns section and-this is the part Senator Missen is concerned about-the full implication of those boundaries.

ANSWER.PARA: The Council agreed that further discussions between the two governments should proceed at ministerial level as a matter of urgency with a view to bringing the matter before the next meeting of the Council. I said to Senator Missen that there are continuing negotiations and that it might be premature to consider Commonwealth action. I advise him also that Ministers have agreed to meet again in November 1981. On the basis of an imminent meeting, I think it is appropriate to let the Ministers proceed further to try to resolve this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. It follows the question asked by Senator Coleman earlier. Is it a fact that the independent McKinsey report 'Capital and Policy Requirements for the 1980s'-the product of an inquiry into the capital requirements of Telecom Australia which was commissioned in 1979 and which reported to the Minister 15 months ago-recommends that Telecom be permitted to increase its investment modestly because this would be, in the words of the report, 'the most productive and efficient option'? Is it also a fact that the Government, despite this advice, has continually reduced Telecom's capital expenditure with consequent deleterious effects on productivity, service and efficiency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that yesterday in this place Senator Button tabled what was supposedly the McKinsey report. I am advised that the document tabled by Senator Button was not the report in its complete form. I am advised that several pages and exhibits were deleted from the document tabled. In view of the fact that Senator Button has tabled an incomplete document, I understand that there may be some action taken by my colleague in another place. Let me make it quite clear that the processes which were set in trian when the McKinsey report was commissioned were not suppressed; nor were they short-circuited. My colleague spoke at the hearings of an Estimates committee of the other place recently and made it quite clear that the Davidson committee of inquiry, which is being set up, was to receive from the Government the McKinsey report as part of the documents which it was asked to consider. There has been no question of the Government's suppressing this report. If Senator Button had to release it prematurely, I am only sorry that he did not release the complete document with all its attachments. At the Estimates committee hearings the Minister freely discussed the intent and thrust of the Government's attitude and some of the arguments contained in the McKinsey report.

ANSWER.PARA: I must put to rest a small matter which was raised in Senator Button's question. He was inaccurate in the dates which he gave. The McKinsey report was forwarded to Telecom at an appropriate time and was held by Telecom for some months before it was made available to my colleague. If Senator Button is to give dates he might as well be accurate about the number of months the report was in the hands of the Minister. I am only sorry that that is another inaccuracy in the matters raised by Senator Button. I have not yet had the privilege of reading the report and I am unable to fill in the honourable senator as to its contents. I will refer the question to the Minister for Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Is it a fact that the McKinsey report was in the hands of the Minister 15 months ago or, if he wants to do some arithmetic, June 1980? I further ask: Is it the main recommendation of the report that a modest increase in investment in Telecom would be the most 'productive and efficient' way of improving the services of Telecom? Further, has the Government investment in Telecom declined by 16 per cent in the last five years?

—I am sorry that Senator Button will not accept the point I have made-that he is inaccurate in the dates that he has given the Senate. He might well try to be accurate. I am advised that the report was received by Telecom in June 1980 and that it was transmitted to the Minister for Communications by Telecom in November 1980. The short answer to Senator Button is that he is not correct. He is incorrect and what I say is accurate.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the current work to rule campaign implemented around Australia by clerks of the Australian Taxation Office on 2 September. It is claimed that the campaign has resulted in a reduction in the number of taxation returns processed from 78,000 to 30,000 a week. I ask: What rules are normally ignored to allow the timely processing of 78,000 returns a week and, if these rules are normally ignored with departmental sanction, why are they still in existence? Will the Minister undertake a review of the rules to ensure that overregulation does not exist and that only those rules essential to the processing of taxation returns are retained?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will seek from the Treasurer the information that has been requested.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I ask the Minister: In light of the fact that he has announced that proposed changes to the social services legislation affecting the application of the income test and, particularly, those who take what he considers to be undesirable measures to avoid the income test, will now not be introduced until the autumn session of Parliament, what advice can he give pensioners-in fact, what advice can he give senators and members who are consulted by pensioners-about the advertisements by banks, finance companies and insurance companies in this country urging pensioners to put their moneys in special arrangements to avoid the changes proposed by the Minister? In view of the fact that only the Minister seems to know just what will happen in that area, I ask: What nature will these changes take?

—I am not in the business of giving the sort of advice the honourable senator has requested. If that minority of pensioners who have large capital sums to invest wish to invest them in ways which they believe will increase their income, reduce their taxation or increase their welfare benefits, I suggest that they take professional advice on the matter. I stress that I am talking about that minority of pensioners who have large capital sums to invest and who might wish to enter into arrangements which are specifically aimed not at receiving a return on their investment but at receiving a return from the taxpayers of Australia.

—Mr President, I wish to ask the Minister a supplementary question. What is his definition of large capital sums and what is the cut-off point at which he considers the sums become large and below which they are obviously not large?

—I used the expression 'large' because I meet many pensioners and I am aware that pensioners with small amounts of a few thousand dollars often worry very unnecessarily about their future. On the other hand, I get frequent reports of pensioners with tens and hundreds of thousands of dollars being involved with schemes which are not in their best interests and which are aimed at doing no more than increasing pension income, often at the economic detriment of those pensioners. I would have thought that the honourable senator would be quite familiar with the matter and that he would know that the great bulk of Australian pensioners do not have the sums of money we are talking about.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. In view of the high cost to society and the Government of the high incidence of divorce, will the Attorney-General's Department give consideration to the issuing of a Commonwealth publication regarding pre-marriage counselling to be made available through churches and counselling agencies for young couples contemplating marriage?
—Do away with marriage. Let them do what they want to do.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate would be aware-Senator Georges might be interested in this-of the fact that 22 organisations are approved as marriage counselling organisations under the Family Law Act. Counselling is provided through these agencies at about 160 centres throughout Australia. The location of the organisations in the various States is contained in a pamphlet explaining the obligations and consequences of marriage which is issued by marriage celebrants to all couples intending marriage. This information is also included in pamphlets on the counselling and welfare help available provided by the Family Court. Grants of financial assistance in increasing amounts have been made to approved marriage counselling organisations in each year since 1960-61. For the current year an amount of $2.9m is provided in the Budget as grants to these bodies. Also included in that amount is a small sum in relation specifically to inquiries and experiments into the desirability and effectiveness of premarital counselling.

ANSWER.PARA: We know, of course, that a number of churches do this work. There is quite a deal of interest in it but there is also a great deal of scepticism about its effect. At this stage more attempts in that direction would be justified. I think there are two views among the experts in this field as to how far it is likely to be successful as a general provision. It seems to succeed when carried out by some churches and by people who are members of churches who have a real sense of commitment to the exercise, but how far it would be effective if it were in any way imposed is of great doubt.

However, the question that Senator Watson specifically asked is in relation to another pamphlet on the subject. As I said, there is quite a bit of information provided in pamphlet form about the location and activities of the marriage counselling organisations. I will look specifically at his question to see whether anything further can be done to publicise premarital counselling.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. In view of the meeting of the International Bauxite Association in Australia this month will the Minister put down a statement on this country's policy towards the IBA's objective of a uniform price for bauxite? In the statement will the Minister reconcile the policy towards the IBA with the Government's public commitment to the North-South dialogue?
—I will draw the nature of the question to the attention of the Minister in another place and seek his comment upon it.

—I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Education by saying that no doubt the Minister recognises that Australia must continue to upgrade its technological base, particularly in areas such as engineering, electronics and other applied sciences, if we are to employ Australians rather than to have to import qualified people; yet the funding of universities, whether for research, equipment or staff and buildings, has been severely restricted. No doubt the Minister is aware that no matter how the figures are juggled, significantly less money is available to support much-needed courses and research programs. Does the Government recognise that the scientific sections of universities need an immediate increase in cash and that the university staff in those areas need encouragement so that our relatively short term needs in scientific areas will be available from locally produced graduates? Will the Government examine the possibility of directing special funds to the engineering and science sections of universities if savings cannot be made by cutting back in the pseudo-disciplines that can be described only as punk sociology?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past six years the Government has concentrated very heavily on turning a considerable amount of its tertiary funding towards the technical base. The establishment of the Tertiary Education Commission, with the technical and further education element as an equal part alongside universities and colleges, is an indication of the Government's desire that the technical-technological side of education should be upgraded. Very considerable amounts of money have gone into that. My understanding and my recollection is that a study was made of the number of engineering schools in Victoria. The name of the chairman escapes me now, but that report, from memory, made the finding that there were too many schools. I want first to make the comment that there has been a rationalisation.

ANSWER.PARA: I and the Government would accept the need for an adequacy of technical graduates. We have a Tertiary Education Commission and a Universities Council to ascertain what are the needs and to advise the Government in this regard. I am not aware that there is advice as to shortages in this area, but because it is an important question I will address the remainder of it to the Minister for Education to see whether he would like to add anything further to that aspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Has the Minister, in correspondence to members of the Nuclear Veterans Association, quoted with approval a reply from the former Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Honourable A. E. Adermann, to a question placed on notice by Dr Klugman in the other place on 19 February 1980? In his answer the former Minister implied that the first Australian troops in the British Commonwealth Occupation Forces assembled in Japan in February 1946. Can the Minister confirm that on 27 August 1945 HMAS Napier sailed into Tokyo Harbour and four days later, on 31 August 1945, the warships Shropshire, Hobart, Warramunga and Bataan sailed into Tokyo Bay carrying approximately 3,000 Australian service personnel? If the Minister's reply is in the affirmative to the first and second parts of that question, can he explain the discrepancy of six months in those two dates?

—As I lay in my bed in the Concord Repatriation Hospital last Sunday night I was cheered somewhat to hear Senator Macklin speak of me as being a compassionate person in regard to veterans, whether Vietnam or, as in this case, nuclear veterans. My cheer turned to chagrin fairly quickly, having heard his remarks and some of the conclusions he had drawn in relation to the statement he just quoted. I think we have to acknowledge that the main point of the letter of the Honourable Evan Adermann indicated that the arrival of the first troops in the area of Nagasaki, rather than Tokyo, some 400 miles away, was in February 1946. I think Senator Macklin answered his own question by referring to the fact that Australian warships did enter Tokyo Bay very soon after the surrender of Japan at the end of the war and, of course, were nowhere in the vicinity of the atomic blast at Nagasaki. I understand that that consequently explains the difference which Senator Macklin sought to indicate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Social Security, concerns Federal spending in the crucial area of child care and pre-school facilities. Will the Minister confirm that the Government has made major cutbacks in the allocation for pre-school facilities for four-year-olds as well as for other child care programs? Is it not a fact that, as a consequence of such cutbacks, many community organisations will have to shelve or drastically amend their plans? In this regard I refer to a statement by Mr John Chappel of the Uniting Church's McNeil Child Care Centre in Sydney, in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: We were assured that an operating subsidy would be given. We need the subsidy if we are to keep this centre for low income people. We could easily charge $70 a day and make it an elite place for the rich.

Is it not a fact that the Government's decision will make child care facilities increasingly inaccessible to those most in need, force such families to use untrained backyard child minders, and force many women to drop out of the work force? Is it also not a fact that many organisations have made expenditure on the basis of assurances of government funding? Further, and in closing, I refer the Minister to my letter to him on 28 September this year wherein I asked for details of the cutbacks as they affect South Australia. Will the Minister provide the details sought of such cutbacks in order that he and his Government can stand publicly accountable for their actions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first part of the multiple-point question is no, there have not been major cutbacks for the pre-school programs at all. In fact the major responsibility for pre-school programs rests with the States. Although there is a Commonwealth contribution, that contribution has been static for a number of years with a block amount being made available to the State as a contribution to those pre-school services. It has been quite clear for a number of years that this is not seen as an area of Commonwealth responsibility with the Commonwealth being responsible for increases in pre-school educational arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the Child Services Program generally is concerned, there has been no attempt to try to hide the situation. I issued a Press release at the time of the Budget which set out quite clearly the funding for this program. There is an increase in funding this year of approximately $6.1m which, as the statement makes explicit, will permit maintenance of existing funding commitments but which will not provide for new initiatives during the financial year. That has been clearly stated and I thought it was a matter of public knowledge. So I am not quite sure why the honourable senator suggests in his question that there is something which has not been disclosed.

It has been suggested that the Government's approach is to turn child care centres-I think really the question related to child care rather than pre-schools-into elite places for the rich. Quite the contrary is the case. My concern about the long day care arrangements which we subsidise at present is that, even in the face of very substantial Commonwealth subsidies, we find in some areas that the least well off in the community, those whom we would most want to guarantee access to these facilities through Commonwealth financial assistance, do not have access because the cost of the services is in fact in excess of what they can afford. To take one example, I recently opened a centre based day care facility to which the Commonwealth contributed about $300,000 in capital and has committed about $86,000 in recurrent expenditure.There are places for about 30 long day care children and I think 30 part time care children in the centre. I am told by the organisers that the level of fees to be charged puts this centre beyond the means of many people in the area whose children they would wish to attend. A very substantial Commonwealth subsidy is going to benefit a relatively small number of children and is not necessarily getting to the most needy in the community. It is in that context that I am examining the general funding arrangements with respect to that program.

Under my predecessor the Commonwealth made its objectives in this program quite clear. First, it wanted to ensure that facilities were available to those who had a great social need for them. The previous Minister, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, indicated in the material that she put out in her time as Minister-I think this goes back to 1976-that people with social difficulties, including migrants, Aboriginals, single parent families and so on, should get priority in Commonwealth funded centres. There was also an emphasis that the subsidies which were available should also be used to ensure that those who might not otherwise have access for economic reasons should have access. I think it is perfectly reasonable that we should look at this program and make sure that what I would see as highly desirable objectives of the Commonwealth are in fact met when we fund child care arrangements.

I want to make it quite clear that the examination of the program at the moment is being carried out to ensure quite specifically that Commonwealth funding does not go to fund elite places for the rich but rather that members of the Australian community who would not otherwise have access and who need access are able to get it. I would also like to say that I think most Australians would accept that the primary obligation for the care of children rests with parents and that the role of government is to intervene and to assist in those cases where, for a variety of reasons, the parents themselves may not be able to meet their obligations. So I reject the sorts of accusations implicit in the question. The Government has the matter of child care under careful consideration. That is a matter on which I have been keeping the public and, I would have thought, the Parliament well and truly informed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister for National Development and Energy, refers to the Government's funding of water resource projects, a matter of particular concern to South Australia. I ask the Minister whether he has seen a letter from Mr Don Watson of the Australian Sugar Producers Association in today's Australian Financial Review which states:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . In November, 1977, the Government made a promise repeated in successive Budgets: To allocate $200m for water resources over the five years to 1982-83. With just one year to go only $109.4m has actually been allocated.
Mr Watson used this to justify the statement:
In recent years there has been a substantial downgrading of the priorities of water resources management.
Does the Minister agree with either of the correspondent's assertions of reduced spending or downgrading of the priorities of water resource management?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the letter. The Government believes that of all the resources in Australia the most precious and indeed the most limited is water. It therefore believes that the subject should have a very high priority, and it has set out so to do. I think the figures as to how much money has been spent within that program of $200m are correct. It is true also that within that time, but not with the financial commitment up to this year, the Government has undertaken to pay for the cost of the actual construction of the Burdekin Dam. The preliminary work on the Burdekin Dam is being done by the Queensland Government, but I think in last year's dollar terms the cost is in the order of the best part of $90m and is likely to be in the order of $200m. So, the Government has made some very significant forward commitments and has increased the amounts to the Bundaberg water projects.

ANSWER.PARA: We are very busy at this moment trying to get the River Murray Waters Agreement into place. We are undertaking a number of schemes. An overall survey is being undertaken of the water resources of Australia by the Australian Water Resources Council. I am hoping that it can be speeded up. In fact I am working on that. There is also a survey which should come to fruition fairly soon regarding the research capacity in Australia for water and I hope that we may be able to deliberate on it in the months ahead. Frankly, of course, we rely on the co-partnership, and we get it, of the six States and the Territory in the asessment of water. The States in general do a very good job. Only recently we have been working in conjunction with the New South Wales Government in looking at the Clarence River and its prospects for the future. A great deal of preliminary work is being undertaken at the moment. I can only say and stress that I regard water as one of the real delimiting factors to our potential growth in Australia and it is a matter on which we place the highest priority for the future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that once again a great number of people who live in country areas have missed out on viewing a sporting event that is of both national and international importance because those areas are not serviced by the commercial network which won the rights to telecast the event? I am of course referring to the world youth soccer championships broadcast by the 0-10 network to hundreds of millions of viewers around the world.

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister also aware of the relevant British legislation which provides for a sufficiently popular sporting event to be declared a broadcast of national importance, thus preventing commercial television stations from monopolising any particular sporting event such as the Olympic Games or international cricket at the expense of the British Broadcasting Corporation? Since country people are rightfully sick and tired of being ignored and forgotten at these times, I ask the Minister: Will the Federal Government consider introducing such changes to the Australian legislation in order to protect the competitive position of the Australian Broadcasting Commission in relation to sporting events? Finally, I point out to the Minister that a ludicrous situation has been reached with the world youth soccer championships in that people in South America are able to watch the broadcasts live but people in Lithgow, just a short distance from Sydney, are unable to see them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sir Arthur George, the President of the Australian Soccer Federation, has told me over a number of years about his dissatisfaction with the inadequate continuing support for the televising of soccer in Australia. When Channel 0-28 commenced broadcasts and indicated that it would give continuing support to soccer, it was appropriate that the soccer federation should go to this new avenue which would give to soccer the kind of opportunity to have the sport transmitted which it had previously lacked. We have to look at the transmission of the present world youth soccer championships by channel 0-28 in the context of its continuing and quite considerable support for the sport of soccer. Having said that, I take on board the point that Senator Sibraa raises, namely, that the viewing area for Channel 0-28 is in fact quite limited, and I will pass on to the Minister the problem which has been raised by Senator Sibraa in the event that there is something that can be done about it to make events such as the soccer championship available to a wider audience.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today Senator Keeffe raised a question with me with regard to compensation. I have some information relating to his question. My Department advises me that the total cost of compensation payments to date is $6.46m. Payments totalling $764,383 have been made to Michael Edgely International Pty Ltd. I think there was another part of Senator Keeffe's question suggesting that there would be payments or claims totalling something like $15m. I am advised by my Department that although some claims are outstanding, the total cost of compensation payments will not approach $15m. I undertook to have an investigation made of the other matter raised. I have no information on that at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MEAT INDUSTRY: STATEMENTS BY SENATOR PRIMMER

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 Senator Sibraa asked me a question without notice in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the response to Senator Primmer's statement in the Senate in March 1978 about the Australian meat export industry. The Acting Minister for Primary Industry supplied the following additional information during the absence of Mr Nixon overseas. It is really an answer rather than additional information. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: As the honourable Senator's question is among those to be examined by the Royal Commission inquiring into the Australian meat industry, I do not wish to add to the statement made by my predecessor, Mr Sinclair, Hansard, pages 507-508 so as not to prejudice the findings of the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September Senator Mulvihill asked a question without notice concerning the introduction of a surface air lifted-SAL-mail service to Yugoslavia. As Senator Mulvihill was advised on 17 August 1981, the introduction of a SAL service to Yugoslavia is subject to two things: Firstly, suitable conveyance arrangements being made; and, secondly, the concurrence of the Yugoslav postal administration. I am able to advise the honourable senator that Australia Post has satisfactorily concluded negotiations with the Yugoslav national airline JAT for the carriage of SAL mail to Yugoslavia. Of course, that fulfils only the first of the two conditions. However, the concurrence of the Yugoslav postal administration is still awaited at this stage, although the concurrence of that organisation was sought first in June 1981, again in August 1981 and yet again this month, October 1981. Australia Post is unable to proceed with the detailed arrangements which will need to be made before the service can operate until such time as the Yugoslav postal administration agrees to the proposal. When this is received, Australia Post will take all possible steps to introduce a SAL service to Yugoslavia within two weeks.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Proposed Reference to Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I take this opportunity to make a short statement relevant to allegations about conditions in East Timor. The matter concerned the possibility of my Committee investigating and reporting on newspaper allegations of army recruitment jeopardising food supplies, of reported murder and of atrocities in East Timor. Let me say in the first place that my Committee is finalising a draft report of an inquiry into the refugee situation in Australia. In determining our next reference we considered whether or not an attempt should be made to look at the East Timor situation and decided on balance, not to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I would want to express an absolute abhorrence of the alleged areas of criminal and inhuman behaviour, wherever in the world it may occur, a number of matters should be raised. It would seem unwise to begin inquiries forthwith into allegations without seeking their clarification and evaluation through formal channels such as the Australian Embassy in Jakarta, already instructed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). We need to consider seriously anybody's right to interfere in the internal matters of other countries. Uppermost also would be the Committee's very restricted capacity to carry out an in-depth and balanced investigation in this circumstance. Rather, then, than this being an appropriate area for my Committee to investigate, it would seem proper that the allegations be examined through the normal national avenues.

The Australian Government is certainly not unmindful of our social, economic and security involvement with Indonesia; our continuing trade and seabed negotiations. Similarly, we have shown constant concern for those whose security has become the responsibility of the Indonesian Government. The Australian Government continues to monitor the food situation in that land and since 1975 has provided more than $5.5m for humanitarian assistance in both food and cash grants chiefly through the two Red Cross organisations. The efforts of relief agencies and the Indonesian authorities have had considerable success improving the physical and health conditions of the East Timorese. This is the consistent report of visitors and the International Committee of the Red Cross in its periodic reports. There is still concern at the slow progress seen in the family reunion program, but some 347 of the list of 625 East Timorese, somewhat more than half, have so far come to Australia.

So in conclusion I say that the Committee in its program of inquiry concluded the advisability, capacity and practicality of inquiry into allegations relating to East Timorese and believed the matter was more appropriately one for the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-Mr President, I would just like to make it quite clear to you and to the Senate that this statement has come down from the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence without consultation of the Committee as a whole. Indeed, the question of East Timor was brought up by Senator Bolkus and immediately there was fairly strong opposition from the Government members on that Committee. The matter was discussed lightly but it had not been gone into in any depth. It was suggested that it could be seen to be interfering in the internal affairs of another nation since de jure recognition had been given to the brutal annexation of East Timor by Indonesia. However, the precedent was set in this Parliament when we had a look at human rights concerning dissidents in the Soviet Union. I can see no reason why the Committee cannot look at the question of rights of people in East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: So I suggest that if Senator Missen wishes to pursue with his party his point that we have an inquiry into East Timor it certainly would meet with no opposition from this side of the chamber. I am quite sure I am talking for all of my colleagues on this side of the chamber. We would be only too keen to take it up. We will see how this matter develops because the ball is now in the Government's court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I find the statement which the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has brought down to be quite extraordinary in that it has been brought down at a point at which substantial debate cannot take place. I find it extraordinary also that a member of the Committee can indicate that the Chairman of the Committee has brought down such a report without full discussion by the Committee. It seems to me that the Chairman has taken upon himself a position which the Senate as a whole may not agree. I think what emerges from the statement is the need for the Senate to demand that a reference be given to this Committee to investigate the matter because it is of vital concern to both sides of the House and to the country as a whole that we have an investigation of the allegations that have been brought down. We cannot push these allegations to one side with a statement such as the one that has been brought down. Senator Missen endeavoured by way of a question yesterday to elicit some information.
—That was apparently ruled out of order later.

—And it was ruled out of order. It seems to me that the question may have been asked at the wrong time. If it had been asked after Question Time it could have been responded to at that time. But I do not think Senator Missen or anyone else expected the Chairman of the Committee to come down with such a blanket recommendation which seems to be a blanket recommendation on his own behalf and not on behalf of the whole of the Committee. I take it that the members of the Committee on this side of the House will take this up on a subsequent occasion and propose to that Committee a reference to investigate fully the allegations because Timor is very much within our region. The events in Timor are very much our responsibility. Some of the comments which have been made in the Press seem to indicate that Australia was implicated in the Indonesian takeover and that in fact we encouraged it.

SPEECH.PARA: We have reached a stage in the Senate where it is not a matter of party politics or a partisan approach. It is a matter of concern to us all because several governments, several Ministers and several ambassadors were concerned. If the allegations which have now been made in the Press that we were in collusion with the Indonesians to invade East Timor have any basis then the sooner that is out the better. If there are allegations of atrocity in East Timor at this stage we ought to investigate them and not take the word of the various officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs as I think the Chairman of the Committee has taken their assessment because we have found in the past that their assessment has not been correct, that the information and advice that came out of our Embassy in Indonesia was advice that suited the Indonesian authorities to the disadvantage of the people of Timor and, if I might say so, to the disadvantage of the people of Australia. My view of it is that we should not push this matter aside and in fact we should put a reference to the Committee to investigate the allegations fully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-As the person who originally initiated this discussion I feel I must say just a word or two about this. I think there has been some quite unfair criticism of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in connection with this matter. This matter actually arose because of a question I asked yesterday and which I learned from the Hansard was ruled out of order last evening. I learned subsequently, after asking the question, there had been some discussion in the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the subject of East Timor. Certainly, I think it is quite proper for the Chairman to have mentioned as he did in his statement today that there had been such a discussion. I was made aware then of the fact that the Committee was proceeding with another reference on the defence arrangements with our neighbours of which notice has been given today.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is only right that the Chairman should have explained to the Senate that there had been some discussion on this matter and that in fact the Committee has not-at this stage anyway-sought any reference on the matter. I certainly would not be a party to trying to impose on a committee a reference which the committee did not seek and which it did not feel was within its capacity to deal with.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate makes a reference to a committee and you well know that.

—Yes, I know that. I am merely saying that I would not move that. Senator Georges put a particular proposition to me that I should proceed to try to move a reference. I say that I would not do that in respect of this Committee. That does not mean that there should not be investigation into this subject by a committee of this Senate. That is a different matter altogether. This Committee has considered this matter to some extent and has not sought a reference in this respect. I appreciate the statement which the Chairman of the Committee has made. I believe that that should not be a subject of any criticism. If the Committee members want to change that view and do something different then I think that is a matter entirely for them. Also, the Senate may decide here whether it ought to send to some committee of the Senate a reference to look into this matter. That is well within the competence of this Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I am certain that other senators on this side of the chamber and I are very determined that there will be more investigation of this matter. We will not be content to accept even the views of the Australian Ambassador in Indonesia or even necessarily those of the Department of Foreign Affairs or any other department; we will want to be satisfied about the facts of these most serious allegations. Obviously, this matter will be heard of further in this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I feel I must make a statement in order primarily to dissociate myself from some of the sentiments expressed by the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. As Senator McIntosh mentioned earlier, I did raise the question of East Timor in a previous meeting of the Committee. At that stage it was decided by the Committee that we should look at an item with reference to defence and defence co-operation. However, since the raising of Senator Missen's question yesterday I have had the opportunity to express once again my opinion to the Chairman of the Committee.
