SPEECH.PARA: I stated, in contradiction to what had been mentioned in the Senate earlier, that I disagreed with the assessment that the position in East Timor was settled and that Indonesian policies had been of benefit to the people of East Timor. I disagreed with the statement that it was an internal matter of another country and that we had no right to assess either our role in respect of that other country or the rights of persons in that other country. As did Senator McIntosh, I referred to the situation of dissidents in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. I believe that the reference discussed in the last day or so and raised by Senator Missen is one that could quite properly be investigated by a Senate committee. I think the facts and the information raised in recent days and covered in Australian national newspapers probably lend cause to the reason for our investigating this matter. However, I am a little disappointed that Senator Missen was quite prepared yesterday to raise the question but in his contribution today to some extent has run away from it. I will not say any more. I appreciate this opportunity to clarify my position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I believe there has been some misunderstanding in relation to this issue. Yesterday Senator Missen sought to ask a question of Senator Scott, the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Mr President, you had a few words to say about the matter and stated that you would have something to say about it later. At about 9.30 last night I went to see Senator Scott to discuss the matter. Senator Missen was in Senator Scott's office when I went there. The three of us had a round table conference. At that stage it was believed by all of us that you, Mr President, would not be making any statement on the matter last night. It was not long after that when I walked into the chamber--

—My statement depended upon the procedures yesterday within this chamber. In commenting on Senator Missen's question at the time I stated that I would endeavour to give a response at a later hour of that day. I did that when I had the opportunity in between debates last night.

—Mr President, I put it this way: It was our assessment that we believed you would not be making a statement later last evening. With that in mind there did not seem to be a great deal of haste, or not the haste that there ultimately proved to be, in our discussions. As Senator Scott, Senator Bolkus and Senator McIntosh have said, the question of a reference on East Timor was discussed by the Committee. That has been the normal practice of the Senate Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee in the years I have been on it. When searching around for a reference it is normal for a round table discussion to take place and for some consensus to be arrived at as to what finally would be the reference that the Committee would take on. It was done exactly that way this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose the one suggestion that came through fairly loud in those discussions was that the Committee over the last few years has persistently taken on references in relation to foreign affairs and has not had a look at a defence reference, I think, since we did the Army reference in about 1974. It was felt that perhaps at this stage the Committee may well get into the area of defence rather than foreign affairs. Another question that arose was the interference in the affairs of another sovereign state-if Timor is a sovereign part of Indonesia, which I believe it should not be. The other question of course that arises in relation to these matters is the hardy perennial of the Committee's inability to travel. I may not have expressed this view but certainly I feel that if the Committee were to undertake intensive investigation into East Timor our inability to travel as a committee would be an inhibiting factor. Anyhow, the end result was that we went for a defence rather than a foreign affairs reference. I do believe there is ample scope somewhere within this Senate for an inquiry into Timor. I believe this Senate has an obligation to conduct such an inquiry to try to find out the facts, and perhaps more so, to look a little into the future, not forgetting what has happened over the last five or six years in East Timor but with that background trying to work out some way whereby this Parliament or this nation can in some way redress the crimes committed against the Timorese since 7 December 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —Were you not a party to that statement?
—No.
—Well, that is a statement that has come from the Chairman without--
—Order!
—I want to approach the subject from a slightly different angle.
—Senator, are you seeking leave?
—I am sorry, Mr President, I seek leave to make a short statement.
—Is leave granted?

—How long is this debate to go on, Mr President? I can understand some of the members of the Committee explaining what happened but are we getting outside the discussions that led up to the statement and the debate about that? I am very concerned to know just where the Senate is going at present. I have no indication of motions before the Chair. A series of honourable senators are standing up wanting leave to make statements.
—Why not? The Chairman brings down a statement without the consent of the rest of his Committee.
—Order! I call Senator Keeffe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I was quite shocked when I heard Senator Scott read his statement. I was clearly under the impression that it represented a decision of the full committee of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. To my mind, the action of the honourable senator was unethical. Whether it was intentional or unintentional does not really matter, but if it was intentional that compounds the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not happy about the way in which the subject of the reunification of families was glossed over by an apologetic sort of reference to the fact that more than half of the families are now here. We have been negotiating this matter for the last three or four years and I doubt whether half of the families are in fact here. Nothing has been done by the Government to speed up reunification of families. That ought to be done and we ought not to be apologising for it either.

I am reminded of the action of the Premier of Queensland, who at the time of the invasion of East Timor sent a telegram to the President of Indonesia expressing his congratulations. One would think that Senator Scott had had the Premier of Queensland draft his statement before he made it to the Parliament. What has happened is not good enough. I agree with those members of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence who have already spoken. We have reached a stage at which the matter ought to be referred by the Senate to an appropriate standing committee if the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is unable, because of a minor change of direction in its responsibility, in favour of defence rather than foreign affairs, to handle the matter.

I suggest that the Parliament was misled by the Chairman of the Committee when he made his statement and I seriously hope, Mr Deputy President, that you will take up the situation to ensure that such methods of making reports in this chamber are not used again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the indulgence of the Senate, under Standing Order 408, to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the issue of the Adelaide News of Monday 7 September, certain statements were made about my association with the Irish hunger striker in Sydney, Mr Eamonn O'Connor. I do not generally read the Adelaide News and have only just become aware of this matter through a clipping from that newspaper which was sent to me. Hence. I have not been able to raise the subject earlier. The news item, under a Melbourne dateline, states.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate is expected to ask the Federal Government to declare its position on demands by an Irish hunger striker in Sydney, Eamonn O'Connor, when Parliament resumes this week.

Mr O'Connor, 27, has received support from the A.L.P., the Democrats and Tasmanian Independent Senator Harradine in his bid to press the Government to ask the British Government to agree to the demands of the hunger strikers in Belfast.
Queensland Senator George Georges (A.L.P.) said in a telegram to Mr O'Connor he would raise the issue as a matter of urgency and seek a decision by the Senate in his favor.
The Acting Leader of the Democrats, Senator Mason, said his party also would call for urgent discussion of the matter and a decision by the Government in favor of Mr O'Connor.

The statements attributed to me are not only utterly untrue but cannot be linked in any way with any interview I have ever had with any journalist. The facts are that on 3 September I went to the Gaelic Club in Sydney, in which Mr O'Connor was undertaking his hunger strike. I went there at the request of a Catholic bishop, who had asked me to try to persuade Mr O'Connor to give up his strike. I made it plain to the bishop that I in no way supported Mr O'Connor's strike. I also made that plain to the H Block Committee representatives I found at the Gaelic Club. I stated that I was solely interested in Mr O'Connor's ending his trike and on that basis I was admitted to see him.

I held a lengthy discussion with Mr O'Connor in which I stated that I believed his hunger strike would be counter-productive and would provoke a negative reaction from Australians if it continued; that I was concerned that eight other constitutents of mine, including a woman, were said to be prepared to follow his lead, and that he owed it to himself and to those other people not to starve himself to death in such a cause. I added that in my opinion, he could be quite certain that the eventuality of his death would not and could not provoke the action that he had requested from the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser).

I later signed as an individual a petition seeking certain concessions at the Maze Prison, because of my belief-in which I persist-that refusal to make any such concessions was giving the Irish Republican Army a stick with which to beat the British Government. That petition in no way involved the Australian Democrats. I have never called for discussions of the matter within the party, and I wish to place on record my utter abhorrence of the policy of armed terrorism that is adopted by the IRA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave, following the statement of Senator Mason, to make a statement because my name has been brought into the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason raised the matter of Eamonn O'Connor and sought to clear himself regarding a Press statement. In doing so, he quoted a reference in the Press article to a telegram which allegedly I sent to Mr O'Connor. I sent no such telegram. I was very much involved in the concern which surrounded the fast this young man undertook in support of something in which he believed very strongly. I raised the matter in the Senate on a couple of occasions. Subsequently, I visited the Gaelic Club in Sydney on two occasions, on the second of which I convinced O'Connor to end his strike. With me on that occasion was Senator Primmer. Our purpose was, of course, to indicate to the young man that what he was doing in giving up his life was of very little use in the campaign in which he was engaged; that to give up his life would be a loss; and that he ought to apply himself more to continuing the struggle and leading it rather than engaging in an horrific wastage of human life. I do not retreat from that view. I support neither the violence of the Irish Republican Army nor that of those who oppose it. There is violence on both sides. It has to be accepted. As I have said in the Senate previously, it is necessary that the Australian Government accept its responsibility to intervene in some way, even if only by giving economic support to the people of Northern Ireland, in order to remove the causes of the conflict.

SPEECH.PARA: In convincing O'Connor that he should end the strike, I undertook to raise the matter, whenever it was necessary and possible, in the Senate. I also indicated to O'Connor that if he felt it necessary to come to the Parliament I would make available to him the means to speak to as many of my colleagues as possible. I also undertook to see the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to make some arrangements for O'Connor to see the Prime Minister so that he could personally express his concern to him about what was happening in Northern Ireland. Subsequently I did see the Prime Minister on the matter, who indicated that he was pleased that O'Connor had ended his strike and that such an unnecessary sacrifice would not take place. But the Prime Minister put one condition on seeing O'Connor that I thought O'Connor would not accept. It was that he would sign a declaration that, having seen the Prime Minister, he would not again engage in a hunger strike. I have not raised this matter previously because the Prime Minister said that the matter was highly divisive in the Australian community-from the letters I received it proved to be so-and that he was afraid that it might lead to a demonstration which would result in violence within the Australian community, violence which he did not desire should take place. For that reason, I did not raise the matter before the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting took place in Melbourne.

I take the opportunity now to indicate that O'Connor ended his strike because he believed that he would have the ear of parliamentarians to state his case. If he comes to this place I hope that, now the hunger strikes are over, he will not be shunned, pushed to one side and accused-as one honourable senator, without a proper understanding of the problem, has accused these people-of being a murderer and a supporter of violence. That situation of violence exists, but those people who are involved in that exercise of violence are acting for political reasons, as is the case in Cyprus, Israel, at present in the Middle East, and so on. Those people act for political reasons. No matter how misguided they are this misunderstanding must be understood. People such as O'Connor who have shunned violence ought to be given a chance to express their point of view. I cannot quite see why the Australian Democrats should suddenly pull away from what might be a controversial issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not pulled away from it. We have been quite clear throughout.

—The Australian Democrats are determined to pull away from the issue. I thank the Senate for the opportunity of allowing me to make a statement in support of Eamonn O'Connor, the young hunger striker who was prepared to fast to death in support of that which he believed in so strongly.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Grimes proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The involvement of the Australian Government in the arrest in Athens of persons charged with fraud committed in Australia and the misleading information given to the Parliament by the Attorney-General and the former Minister for Administrative Services.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-
That notwithstanding anything contained in sessional orders, Senators Grimes and Durack be permitted to speak for thirty minutes each if required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter which I raise concerns the arrests in Athens of nine people their charging and their gaoling for offences which were allegedly committed in Australia. It concerns the involvement of Australian Government representatives in their cases. It involves the misinformation and, what is more important, the lack of information by two Ministers, namely, the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the former Minister for Administrative Services in another place, Mr John McLeay, when inquiries were made about these cases. I believe the case is important to Australians of Greek origin who, through no choice of their own, have dual nationality. The matter should concern all Australians because any Australian who is involved in what I consider to be an apparent miscarriage of justice should be the concern of us all.

SPEECH.PARA: Two years after the original arrests were made in Sydney, in April 1978 in what has become known as the social security conspiracy case, a Sydney newspaper, the Daily Telegraph, on 27 May 1980, reported that nine persons had been indicted in an Athens court under Greek law on charges of 'fraud against the Australian Government'. This was based on a United Press International report from Athens which said that sources expected the trial to take place before July. Since that time every effort of mine and others in this Parliament to try to find out what was happening, what led to the arrests and where the Australian Government fitted in with these charges has been met with surprise and, at times, expressions of ignorance, casualness and sometimes palpable lies from those who were responsible for answers. The Government has volunteered no information. Every fact that has been dragged out of anyone in this place has come as a result of repeated questions and almost painful extraction.

In the end the Opposition was forced to seek information from Greece. The Opposition had to approach sources in the Greek courts and the Greek judicial system to find out what has happened to people, some of whom are Australian citizens, who have been charged under Greek law on evidence derived from Australian sources for offences which occurred within Australia. When I asked the Attorney-General, Senator Durack, about when he had learnt that these charges had been pressed the answer I received four months later was: 'I don't remember'. He referred me to the newspaper report of 27 May 1980. Following further questions he quoted a cable from the Australian Embassy on 28 May 1980 which confirmed the arrests in Greece, but he did not do this until July 1981. In Parliament on 21 August 1980, when I asked Senator Durack about the Australian Government's involvement, he maintained that it was inappropriate for him to say anything at all until he had talked to the then Minister for Foreign Affairs. However, he did state:
We certainly have not taken any part in initiating it . . .--
That is, the case-

the circumstances which led to their occurring are matters to which . . . I have given consideration. But we have not-in the sense that Senator Grimes intends-initiated them . . . or are taking part in them.

If he did talk to the Minister for Foreign Affairs he did not report back to the Parliament or to the Senate. On 26 August he said that he would follow up the suggestion that the Greek authorities had acted at the request of the Commonwealth Police. But it was not until I raised the matter again on 11 September that he read to me a prepared answer from the Assistant Commissioner, Operations, of the Australian Federal Police. I summarise the answer as follows:

Detective Inspector Thomas went to Greece with a request for legal assistance addressed to the Greek authorities-signed on his first visit by the Deputy Crown Solicitor and on his second by the Attorney General . . . it was for assistance by the Greek Government in making inquiries in respect of the activities or knowledge of the nine arrested persons. The Greek police made inquiries and forwarded the papers to the prosecuting attorney for Greece, who in turn forwarded them to the Australian Ambassador to send on to Australia.

At no time did the Chief Inspector or any other member of the Commonwealth Police ask the Greek authorities to take action against those persons then living in Greece whom it was believed had committed offences in Australia.
The Minister added:

. . . as far as I am aware there was no further conduct by the Australian Federal Police in relation to these proceedings in Greece, to make the representations to the Greek authorities. I am not aware of the operations of the Australian Federal Police. That is not my responsibility. I will pass that question on to the Minister for Administrative Services . . .
He may have passed on the question but we received no answer from the Minister for Administrative Services. A week later, on 18 September, the then Minister, Mr John McLeay, stated:
. . . whatever action was taken in Greece was taken on the initiative of the Greek Government and in no way was it taken on the initiative of the Australian Government.

I now wish to establish my case and suggest that the denials of the Government, which were treated at the time with rational scepticism by me, have ended up being less than plausible and have been treated by the Opposition and the Greek community in this country with some anger. Early in April 1978, at the time of the arrests in Australia, the newspapers reported, as they reported many things as a result of Commonwealth Police briefings, that plans had been made to extradite a further 300 people from Greece. One can remember that there was a suggestion at the time that there would be 1,000 people arrested in Australia. That did not come to pass. In fact, no people were extradited from Greece. Interestingly enough, none of the returning Greek pensioners, some of whom I spoke about last night, who had attended the accused doctors, have been arrested or charged in this country on their return.

Detective Chief Inspector Thomas, who is now a legal practitioner in Sydney, having been invalided out of the Commonwealth Police, assisted by Detective Inspector Wheatley, visited Greece in June-July 1978 and again in January-February 1979. The request for assistance which he bore from the Australian Government asked for the Greek Republic's assistance in the investigation 'of several incriminating actions which have taken place in Australia'. The document I have before me details as fact, not as allegations, that from 1971 six doctors had issued false medical certificates claiming that the persons mentioned in them were sick and unable to work. It specifies the nine people, giving a rundown of their alleged felonies as if they were proven facts, about whom the Commonwealth Police wanted information in Greece. The same nine people were later charged and indicted by the Greek police in April 1980. The request for assistance was, in fact, a request to the Greek Government to charge on behalf of the Australian Government people whom the Australian Government could not extradite.

The second document to which I shall refer is a report of an interview by the Greek Police-the first of the reports from this source which I wish to quote-of Chief Detective Inspector Thomas under oath on 24 July 1978 on the first of that Detective's visits to Greece and nine months before the Commonwealth outlined its case in the committal hearings in Sydney. Chief Detective Inspector Thomas stated that he was in Greece on behalf of the Australian Government to investigate, with the help of the Greek Police, a fraud against the Australian Government based on false and bogus medical evidence. He gave details of how the frauds were allegedly perpetrated and claimed that the fraud had cost the Australian Government $6.5m, excluding Medibank, in 1977-78-a figure which has never been substantiated. Four of the nine people arrested in Greece later are, in fact, named in this document.

The next reference is a court report of the court of the first instance of 13 February 1979. I point out that that was the second time that Chief Detective Inspector Thomas was in Athens and, again, the detective was under oath. This time he put as fact again sworn evidence about seven of the people subsequently arrested, with details of social services received, the alleged fraud each had committed and how each had committed that fraud. He said also that apart from those seven people there were another 100 or so people of Greek origin who succeeded in similar ways in getting sickness benefits and invalid pensions. He said:
These people are living in Greece and I will, at an appropriate time, provide you with a list of their names.

Presumably he was speaking of the court. I put it to the Senate that Detective Thomas was not giving useful background information to the police and the magistrates. He was giving the Commonwealth Police's version of what had occurred so that the Greek Government would take action, action which he could not take because there was no extradition treaty. The examining magistrate, on the basis of Chief Detective Inspector Thomas's evidence, pronounced that there was what in Greece is called a 'penal offence' and an 'accusation' against the nine people named by Thomas. The same nine people were subsequently arrested. The magistrate reported the crime and the accusation to the Council of Courts of Petty Sessions, a body composed of three judges which met on 1 April 1980 in the company of the District Attorney and the secretary of the Council.

As a result of the Council's report it was decided that fraud had occurred and that a large number of Greek migrants residing in Australia had conspired against the State and had, without having suffered any illness, succeeded in getting sickness benefits and invalid pensions through false doctors' certificates. Among the persons who conspired against the Australian state were the nine people involved, following the evidence of the witness Thomas Donald or, as we know him, Chief Detective Inspector Donald Thomas. The council's report went into considerable detail based on Detective Thomas's assertions and concluded that it was evident that all the defendants were conspirators and dangerous-the Greek terms used in Greek courts. The report states that there was enough evidence to support publicly the accusations and that these people were punishable by Greek law. The same actions which the court said were punishable by Australian law were the basis for the court's decision that the defendants should appear before the court of appeal and undergo trial. They were arrested. They were detained. They were, in Greek parlance 'gravely suspect of guilt and suspect of trying to escape'. They were to be taken into custody until a final judgment.

The report of the Council was released on 2 May 1980. I do not know when it was first reported in the Greek Press but the first report in the Australian Press was on 27 May 1980. The Attorney-General claimed on 10 March this year that he was unable to inform me of the exact dates when he learned about the charges and indictments of the nine people arrested. Quite frankly, I find it strange that there is no trace of a cable or a report on the files of his Department or the Department of Foreign Affairs, but I find many things about this affair strange. The same reply told me that the Crown Solicitor had initiated inquiries through diplomatic channels following the report of 27 May, but that certainly did not result in a well-informed Attorney-General and certainly not a well-informed Senate.

The Daily Telegraph report in May 1980 was printed when the Parliament was in recess. In the first week of the sitting resuming I asked either Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle or Senator Durack to tell the Parliament what was happening, what part the Australian Government was taking and what assistance was being given to the Greek Government. Senator Durack answered the question first and said that it would not be appropriate for him to make a statement and that he would ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs about the matter. He finally stated that the Government had taken no part in the proceedings. Three months after the news had been broken the Attorney-General, firstly, was reluctant to make any comment on the Australian-Greek citizens arrested-and for all I know some may still be in gaol-on charges related to the massive arrests in Australia. Secondly, he denied the Government's participation in the proceedings. We now have documents which show the role of the Government in initiating these proceedings and providing evidence for these proceedings.

We must ask ourselves, and I believe we must ask the Attorney-General, just how ignorant he and his Department have been of the sworn evidence of Chief Detective Inspector Thomas which led directly to the arrests and the charging of these people. Certainly the denials to the Parliament that the Government was involved resulted in the Parliament being misled. Perhaps it was the Department that misled the Minister; perhaps it was another department such as the Department of Foreign Affairs or the Department of Administrative Services. Maybe the Minister was not as candid in his replies to parliamentary questions as I believe our system requires. As we now know, it was then Chief Detective Inspector Thomas who was responsible through the Commonwealth Police to the Minister for Administrative Services who gave direct evidence to the Greek Police the Greek magistrates and the Greek court. My colleague, the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, put a series of questions without notice directly to the Minister for Administrative Services, which included.
Is the Minister aware that the action in Greece is alleged to have been taken at the instigation of the Australian Government and on information supplied by Inspector Don Thomas?
The Minister at the time, Mr McLeay, said:
. . . whatever action was taken in Greece was taken on the initiative of the Greek Government and in no way was it taken on the initiative of the Australian Government.
The Attorney-General had earlier stated:
The firm advice from the Australian Federal Police was that no request was made to the Greek authorities to initiate any proceedings.

I simply do not understand how a responsible Minister can learn that nine Australians of Greek origin had been arrested in Athens on charges corresponding to highly sensitive and well-publicised arrests in Sydney two years earlier and not ask questions of public servants in his own Department and of his colleagues in the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of Administrative Services. I do not understand why he did not wonder how Greek pensioners could be indicted without evidence supplied from Australia and, if they could not, from where, in what detail, from what files and by whose hand that evidence had come. We now know more than what Senator Durack or other Ministers have ever told us. Detective Inspector Thomas was the agent involved in passing across the evidence. We know that his sworn evidence was the evidence that incriminated the nine people who were arrested and, it appears, imprisoned.

Is the Senate to believe that then Chief Detective Inspector Thomas did not report to his superior officers and, through them, to his Minister, the Minister for Administrative Services at the time, that he had, while in Greece, given to investigating officers there and before the examining magistrate his version of the alleged crimes of those same nine people arrested and confined by the Greek Police? Are we to believe that the Commonwealth Government, having requested assistance from the Greek Government, did not follow up the consequences of that request which led through Thomas's evidence to the order by the Council of the Courts to take the nine people named in the request into custody as a social danger, as it is described in Greece? Having put the request, did the Government in fact show no more interest, that is, until the Opposition in this place and the Greek Press in this country started asking questions?

The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) claimed on 25 February 1981 that the Australian Federal Police had received no official advice from the Greek Government on this matter. What kind of service is that? We sent over a senior policeman with a stack of evidence on nine people, as a result of which those nine people were arrested. Was there really no feedback at official, or unofficial, level?

On the same day the Minister informed me that there had been no requests for assistance or evidence from the Australian Government in connection with the nine indicted people. We now know why. The Government and our agent, Detective Inspector Thomas, had supplied all that evidence freely and unasked before the arrests occurred.
Information-I suggest even evasion-has had to be dragged out of Ministers in this Parliament. On 9 September 1980 Senator Durack said:

I am still not in a position to make a full and proper answer to that question of Senator Grimes. It is a matter of continuing concern and I trust that I will be able to make a statement in relation to it.
On 5 December 1980 he said:

Some information was obtained quite recently from the Greek Government. I do not have detailed information . . . Several pieces of information have been obtained . . . and they need to be put together in a full answer.
Three weeks ago I asked again and was told by Senator Durack:

I will have to refresh my mind as to the present situation. I have not a sufficiently up-to-date report on the cases. As I have said in the past, the only involvement of the Australian Government in these cases is the fact that we have made representations in relation to immunity and pardons that were given to some of the people charged. I will look into the matter and get an up-to-date answer for Senator Grimes.

Up until this date I have not received that answer. Nine Australian Greek citizens were arrested in Athens 18 months ago on information given three years ago on the say-so of an Australian police officer with or without-I believe with-the knowledge and concurrence of responsible Ministers. Yet these responsible Ministers are not sufficiently concerned to keep themselves informed. Their willingness to remain ignorant and to keep this Parliament ignorant on the matter is quite frankly stunning.

In another aspect of this affair the attitude of the Government and the authorities is, to say the least, casual. While the nine pensioners in Athens have remained on fraud charges, most of those involved in the same case who were on charges in this country have had those charges dropped. Of the pensioners charged in Sydney, 32 had all charges dropped in January 1979, at the time Detective Chief Inspector Thomas was giving his alleged facts to the magistrate in Athens. Another 32 had the conspiracy charges dropped by June 1979. Senator Chaney, then representing the Minister for Administrative Services, gave as the reason for the withdrawal of those charges 'the admissible evidence available in each case was insufficient to establish a prima facie case'. On 30 October 1980 the Government dropped conspiracy charges against the remaining 111 defendants who were not in court. It discharged 38 people completely and said it would lay substantive charges only against the other 73 people. This meant that the only people still charged with conspiracy were the original 20 still in court from March 1979, whose trial has dragged on for 350 sitting days at a cost of $7m. One defendant died of a heart attack during the commital hearings in Sydney. Those hearings are still going on after 2 1/2 years.

The fact that half the defendants had charges completely dropped while the others who were not already in court had theirs commuted to minor charges I believe changed the whole situation in regard to the approach taken by the Commonwealth Government, a situation which must have relevance to the overseas charges. I asked Senator Durack whether the information that charges had been dropped against so many of the alleged original conspirators had been passed on to the Greek Government, what legal advice had been forwarded at the time on how those judgments were made and what kind of cases were dropped and which cases were continued. He replied, in his usual considered way:

I am not sure whether that information has yet been conveyed to the Greek authorities. I will inquire from my Department as to what occurred there. But I certainly agree that that is evidence which ought to be conveyed to them. However, I think from the information that has come from the Greek authorities, there has not been any particular urgency in conveying that information to them.

What kind of fair play is it to let off the people here and not be in any hurry to tell the Government in Greece, which had arrested and gaoled nine of that group on unsubstantiated assertions by Inspector Thomas in 1978 and early 1979 when the Government was still gung-ho about the whole affair and before the Government was seen to be so bogged down in the committal hearings of the first 21 defendants. A further answer from Senator Durack on 26 March said that on 5 March 1981 the Australian Embassy was advised that the matter had been referred back to the Public Prosecutor of the Court of Misdemeanours for further investigation. The solicitor for two of the defendants had estimated it would be another year before any trial date would be set.

So the trial which was to be in July 1980 is now to be postponed until 1982. I am aware that these matters are out of the Australian Government's hands but the consequences it has put in train by its request for assistance in July 1978 and the consequences of the sworn evidence, the assertions made by the Government's agent in 1978 and 1979, should be seriously considered by the Government. We really need to know how much the Greek Government was told of the reasons for having the charges dropped. As soon as the magistrate has pronounced on the evidence in the committal hearings that too should be passed to the Greek Government.

One other strange aspect of the arrested overseas pensioners is the situation of Miss Artopolou who was among the nine people arrested. Those who have followed the case may remember she was given a pardon in Australia by the Governor-General 'in regard to the nature of the evidence she was thought to be able to give in the case'. In spite of that pardon, she was indicted in Greece as a result of Detective Chief Inspector Thomas's statements. It may be remembered that she was brought from Greece to give evidence in the Sydney hearings in August 1979. After nine days of giving evidence she was withdrawn at the request of the Crown-although she was a Crown witness-the Assistant Crown Prosecutor having called her unco-operative and her evidence unreliable. Was there any discussion between the Australian and Greek Governments on the extent of that pardon and its relevance to the charges in Athens?

Another aspect concerns Mr H. F. Woltring of the Deputy Crown Solicitor's Office in Sydney. Mr Woltring went to Greece in connection with the alleged socal security conspiracy cases for four days in February 1980, the month before the Council of the Courts met on 19 March 1980.

A further question to Senator Durack led to my being informed that he did not meet with officials of the Government concerned with the court case, but that he travelled to Athens in order to accompany a prosecution witness to Australia as that witness had set as a condition of his return that he be accompanied by an Australian officer. I, and I believe other honourable senators, should be puzzled by this. If the witness required an escort because he feared danger then an Australian Federal Police officer would have been far more appropriate. There can have been no reason for such a senior legal officer from the Attorney-General's Department being involved in escort duty. We have to take Senator Durack's word, coming from his own Department, that Mr Woltring did not meet anyone connected with the Athens cases, but I would like to know who he did meet and why a principal legal officer was chosen to bring back a prosecution witness. I would also like to know whether that witness was Mr Nakis, the Government's informant, and what is his situation now. It may be remembered that he too was granted immunity and a pardon in Australia. Was that pardon, unlike that of Miss Artopolou, extended to Athens?

However, these are minor questions compared with the important one of the involvement of the Australian Government in the Athens charges and why the Australian Government bothered to deny it at all. It has been a matter of great concern to the Greek community in Australia. On 17 June 1980 the Hellenic Herald commented:

. . . we consider it our duty to underline that the action of the Greek authorities shows servility to the Australians who for months have been trying unsuccessfully to clear up this case and to pin-point the guilty . . . It is ridiculous and servile for Greek courts to try to appear more Australian than Australian courts. They should have waited for the verdict of the Australian courts before taking any legal action.

Another Greek newspaper, the Nea Poreia, on 15 July 1980 asked how it was possible for Australian citizens, living in Greece and receiving Australian pensions, to be tried in a Greek court. It stated:

. . . if no explanation is given there will be an impression that there is 'collusion' between the Greek and Australian Governments to find an excuse for the Australian Government to stop all pensions in Greece.

I believe this is a serious matter. In Greece nine people have been charged with offences committed in Australia against Australian law. The basis for those charges is evidence sworn on at least two occasions, six months apart, by a detective inspector involved in the social security conspiracy case in this country. He stated to the Press in this country that more than 1,000 people would be charged in this case. We know that that was a gross exaggeration and that 300 people were to be charged and extradited from Greece; but that has happened to no one. We know that as a result of the efforts of the then Commonwealth Police Force, the Attorney-General's Department and the Crown Solicitor's Division, most of the people have had the charges against them dropped. We know that the chief participants in the case-Detective Thomas and Mr Lanigan, then of the Department of Social Security-are now comfortably retired from the Public Service and both in lucrative legal practises in Sydney. We know that the prosecutor in the case in Sydney, who has received over $400,000, was involved equally in a less than salubrious case, the Sankey case, in this country.

We have quite clear evidence of Australian government involvement. I do not believe that Ministers could have been ignorant of that involvement at the time. Ministers have pleaded ignorance, evaded the questions, and left this Parliament in ignorance. I believe it is time we had a full and proper statement on this matter. If the Opposition can get this information from Greece, surely the Government can get it and clarify matters for the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly there is one matter on which I agree with Senator Grimes, and this is that the facts, insofar as we know them, do present a matter of serious concern. When Senator Grimes has asked me questions over the last year or more, I have indicated the concern I have had about some aspects of the matter. Unfortunately, a number of circumstances have made it difficult at any one time to provide a full statement to the Parliament in relation to the matter. Even now I do not have all the facts that I would like to have. If the Opposition has been able to obtain some more information-it appears that it has, and Senator Grimes has mentioned some-I will be very interested to study in the Hansard the further information he has provided because it will help to put all the pieces together.

SPEECH.PARA: Difficulties have been encountered which have prevented me from giving a full statement. Questions have been asked of me by Senator Grimes from time to time, and I have endeavoured to provide answers. When he has asked me questions without notice, with months elapsing between them, and it has been very difficult to give answers there and then, I have subsequently, as far as possible, provided the answers. Questions have been put on notice and answers have been given to them. There is probably some value in the matter being raised this afternoon. It is true that there is no full statement which puts all the pieces together as far as they are known at the moment. In fact, Senator Grimes has put the thought in my mind that it may be proper to make a statement to the Parliament at some stage. At this stage I would like to try to get some more information.

The other difficulty I face in providing answers to Senator Grimes's questions is that a number of departments are involved. I, as Attorney-General, am involved only in relation to the witnesses we have called and who have been charged in Greece. As well, we have some other peripheral involvement, I think some of which Senator Grimes has mentioned. I have expressed, and I again express, some general concern that Australians who are Greek nationals living in Greece should be charged with alleged offences committed in Australia. However, regretfully that is not an unusual situation. We are aware of the dual nationality problem of a number of migrants to Australia. Honourable senators must be very familiar with this problem. In Continental law, one's nationality remains and apparently one can be charged as a national with offences committed in other countries against the laws of those countries. To that extent there is an assertion of power by those countries which we do not always make in Australian law. On the other hand, some Australian laws do not apply in those circumstances. I instance the law relating to whaling, which was passed by this Parliament not so very long ago. Dual nationality is certainly a problem, and I am not at all happy about the situation.

Perhaps something more could be done in representations to the Greek Government in relation to these people. In that area there has certainly been a necessity to involve the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). I, as Attorney-General, do not deal directly with the Greek Government. I have to put any representations to the Government through my colleague, the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I have in fact done that in this case, as I have already explained. Furthermore, and perhaps more importantly, responsibility for Detective Inspector Thomas's activities in Greece comes under the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who is responsible for the Australian Federal Police, and on many occasions I have had to get information from the police about these activities. So there has been a combination of circumstances which I mention by way of explanation as to why the information that has been made available in relation to this case may have been given in bits and pieces over a period. I can see some basis for Senator Grimes's complaint that the information has not all been put together. As I said, I will look at the matter to see whether a more detailed statement, putting all the information together as best we can, should be made.

The other and final difficulty I have had in this case-I think my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs has also had this difficulty-is getting timely and detailed information from the Greek authorities. I became so frustrated with the situation that earlier this year I wrote to His Excellency Mr Stamatis, the Minister for Justice, because I felt that it was necessary to make some more immediate contact with the Greek authorities. Incidentally, I wrote to Mr Stamatis on 23 June this year but I have not had a reply. We are trying to get some information through the Australian Embassy in Athens in relation to the matter. The latest information we received through the Embassy was at the end of August this year. That is the latest information we have been able to get.

TALK.START.PARA: —They must be asleep if we can get it.
—When did the honourable senator get it?
—A month ago at least.

—Maybe we will try again. As I said, I would be very interested to read what information the honourable senator has. If he has other information which he has not been able to convey in the time available to him I would also be very happy to receive it because I think it could be of assistance in putting the whole story together.

SPEECH.PARA: The latest information that I have been able to get through the Australian Embassy in Athens is to the effect that the Ministry of Justice hopes to be able to provide an answer in the near future-some fairly vague period is mentioned-to the letter that I wrote in June. The Australian Embassy comments that an election will be held in Greece on 18 October and that perhaps people are waiting until after the election is held before they provide any further information. It may be that more direct contact has to be made with the Greek authorities than has been made so far. All I can do is convey to the Senate the information that I have been able to obtain from time to time. I have done my best to provide that information to the Senate.

I do not appreciate suggestions that I have been less than frank with the Senate, much less that I have been engaged in misleading the Senate. I readily confess that there has been a lack of adequate information in relation to this matter and I have felt the same frustration throughout this business. The latest information about the situation was conveyed in an answer to Senator Grimes by me on 26 March 1981. I think I should read the answer to that question because it really is the latest information.

TALK.START.PARA: —On your side.

—All right, Senator Grimes, I acknowledge that you have been able presumably to get some later information. I told the honourable senator that I would be very happy if he gave it to me. I will read to the Senate the relevant parts of that question on notice which appeared in the Hansard of 26 March 1981. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In November 1980 I was advised that appeals against the Order of Committal were being examined by the Public Prosecutor of the Court of Appeals who would, in due course, submit his recommendations to the Council of Magistrates of the Court of Appeals. I was informed that a date for the hearing of the charges would await the outcome of any appeals.

On 5 March 1981 the Embassy advised that the recommendation of the Public Prosecutor was accepted by the Council of Magistrates and that the matter had been referred back to the Public Prosecutor of the Court of Misdemeanours for further investigation. The solicitor for two of the defendants has estimated that it will be at least another year before any trial date is set.

It is not to be necessarily assumed from the information given in that answer that a trial is going to take place at any particular date or, I would suggest, even at all. The immediate and primary concern, apart from the general concern of Australian citizens being charged in Greece with offences that, if committed at all, were committed in Australia against Australian law, which I have had in my capacity as Attorney-General is in relation to three people who were brought out to Australia to give evidence in the committal proceedings in Australia and to whom I gave immunities and in one case a pardon for particular reasons I have already discussed at length in the Senate. These three people, who are witnesses in Australia and who were given immunity from any offences that may have been committed in Australia, are three of the nine people who have been charged. This matter has given me really serious concern. It has been the subject of the representations I have made to the Ministry of Justice both through the Department of Foreign Affairs and, as I said, in one case earlier this year, in a letter which I wrote to the Minister himself. It is in respect of that matter that I am most concerned to obtain a response and endeavour to do all I can to stop the trial going on in relation to those three people. As I have said, they have been given an immunity from prosecution for any offence they may have committed in Australia.

As I have said, the information we have is that the matter has gone back for further consideration by the Public Prosecutor and we are awaiting the outcome of that. We are advised that it may be some little time yet, possibly after the elections, before we will get any further response to those representations. I do not know that I can say anything more in relation to the matter of public importance submitted by Senator Grimes.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the detective inspector's role?

—Senator Grimes may recall that his first question on this subject was directed to the then Minister for Social Security, not me. I intervened in the matter because I had already become aware of this matter, I think, a few weeks before the honourable senator asked me a question in September of last year. At that time I had already written to my colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs in regard to the problem about three of the nine people who had been given an immunity by me. The honourable senator then raised the question about whether the Government had initiated these proceedings. I have always understood that to mean the prosecution itself. Certainly, the official Government understanding of this matter is that when Mr Thomas had to go to Greece to obtain, or try to obtain, evidence for use in the Australian courts he carried with him a request for legal assistance and that is set out in my answer of 11 September 1980. I think the facts as we understood them to be, and still understand them to be, are set out in that answer.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly in Greek law an Australian police officer cannot go to Greece and make his investigations as he would in Australia. He has to go through the Greek legal channels and in fact it is the Greek authorities who do the interviewing. Mr Thomas had to provide these people with the information that he had to assist in the obtaining of evidence for use in Australia. That is the position as we understand it. As I said, as far as we are concerned he went there for the purpose of gaining evidence for use in Australia. He certainly did not have any authority to seek to initiate prosecution of people in Greece. We may be able to obtain more information about that point. The honourable senator says that he has further evidence that indicates that Mr Thomas went further than that. I am certainly most concerned to hear of that. I would like to obtain further information if there is any indication that he went further than that. If he did, then of course that provides very strong grounds for the Australian Government to take direct steps in relation to all of these people, not just the three to whom we have given the immunity. I have taken a very clear note indeed of what Senator Grimes has said about that situation.

I do not think I can take the matter any further than that this afternoon. I will certainly study what further information Senator Grimes has provided the Senate in his speech, a speech which of course had been carefully prepared for him. I might say that I had notice only this morning that he intended to raise this matter. That has not given me much time to prepare an answer in a matter which involves so much detail and so many different departments. To that extent I am at some disadvantage in dealing with this matter this afternoon. That is why I say I will study the other information which the honourable senator has given us the benefit of in his address this afternoon and which will be printed in Hansard. If the honourable senator has any other information which he feels will be of assistance to me or to the Australian Government in trying to ascertain any further details about this matter I will be grateful to receive it. As I have said all along, I am concerned about this matter. I have a particular and serious concern about the situation of the three people in Greece to whom I have given an immunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are in gaol.

—I do not think they are in gaol. The information, as far as I have it, is that they have been released on bail. They are not in gaol in Greece. But, again, I cannot be held to that because that is based only on the information and understanding that I have. Under Greek law there are processes of very long inquiry. The answer I read--
—Not only in Greek law. The case has been going on here for months.

—The difficulty we have is that we are not familiar with the detailed processes of Greek law. The difficulties in actually understanding the situation in a different legal system altogether from the one with which we are familiar will be seen from the answers that I have given.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a whole lot of difficulties in this area. All I want to emphasise is that we have been trying to obtain information. No immediate trial of these people is pending. There is still a great deal of time ahead in which we hope we will be able to make some further and successful representations to the Greek Government in relation to the three people about whom I am most concerned. If there is any indication that Australian officials, even without the authority of the Australian Government, have in any way initiated the prosecution then of course it will be a matter on which the Australian Government will have to make some very strong representations. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON SOUTH WEST TASMANIA

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate nominating Senators Primmer and Coates to be members of the Senate Select Committee on South West Tasmania.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senators Primmer and Coates, having been duly nominated in accordance with the provisions of the resolution passed on 23 September 1981, be appointed members of the Select Committee on South West Tasmania.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEAR CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1981APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1981APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to Senator Georges for calling honourable senators into the chamber for what I believe is an item of national importance. I will continue the comments I made yesterday in relation to education. Last night before the adjournment I had gone through a number of items that were of concern in the funding of universities within Australia and had sought to detail, with reference to the University of Queensland, how a variety of departments were affected in their research capacity. I wish today to mention briefly one more area which I believe is one of the most important areas being affected by the cuts in funds. The Department of Microbiology at the University of Queensland has, or has had, a world wide reputation for its research and knowledge in relation to microbialmetabolism. While this may seem to be an esoteric subject to many people in Australia, I think that if people took the time and trouble to find out something more about the incredibly important areas of research being conducted within our universities the silly types of editorial in today's Australian Financial Review would not be written.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the program which has been conducted over the last 13 years by members of the department who are looking at the area of oxygen in microbialmetabolisms. The leader of that research team has gained a world wide reputation in that time. In recent years he has been the recipient of one invitation after another from those countries which see this as the growth industry. He is on the executive of international biotechnological organisations and is the consultant for this work with the United Nations Educational Scientific and Cultural Organisation. I point out again that this type of work is an example of the excellent work that is being done by our universities, work which unfortunately is virtually unknown in this country because it goes unreported. In pursuing biotechnology the Department of Microbiology established in 1980, in co-operation with the Department of Chemical Engineering, a post-graduate course. The number of students it has been able to attract is impressive because this field is seen overseas as the growth industry.

In support of that statement let me point out that in Japan, which at least as an example in the world of a country which has never been sluggard in moving into new industries, microbial industries are currently generating over 5 per cent of total taxable income. The fact that a country like Japan, which always is in the forefront of countries entering new industries, is able to do that at least should make us pause. Those people who know the area of biotechnology will know that this is the area into which we will be going after the computer industry. In other words, it is so vitally important that it will have more far reaching effects on Australia's civilisation, our lives and our economy than the computer industry. Most of us are aware of the types of effects of the computer. The claims that I make are not idle claims. They are claims which are backed up by the enormous amount of work which is currently being generated in countries such as Switzerland, Canada, West Germany and the United States. There was the rather absurd editorial in the Australian Financial Review which stated:
However, it is of interest that neither the economists . . . are being much consulted in the present noisy political campaign against the Government.

I do not know whether that was written by a frustrated academic or someone who did not make the grade but obviously this person has very little knowledge of the economies of the type of research which is currently being done in this country. I suggest that before he writes another editorial on this subject he might take himself off-I am sure it will be at the invitation of the vice-chancellors of the major universities-and at least have a tour of the major departments of the universities in this country. He should look at the type of work they are doing before he sets about denigrating people who are at the forefront of vitally important areas in this country. They are just not at the forefront of these areas as I will illustrate by reading from a letter which was written to me by a person who is conducting microbiology research at the University of Queensland. Amongst other things the letter states:
The introduction of fees for overseas students and for second degrees in Australia will-and indications are visible-definitely kill this post-graduate training course.

In other words, in respect of an industry of the future we have decided to cut it off in its prime. If that is not economic madness, if that is not getting into the nitty-gritty of the economy, I do not know what is. But much more importantly the writer of the letter goes on to state:
Sir, with no research money from outside the University, no technician or laboratory attendant or research assistance to help me in my research work,--
It should be remembered that this is the person who is recognised as the world's authority in this area of research, and we do have them in Australia--

Postgraduate courses are doomed, our worldwide research reputation is reduced to mainly undergraduate teaching. The present research is carried out by the few postgraduate students. With the diminishing numbers of postgraduate awards, I can even see that this effort will be reduced.
He went on to make a point which I would like to emphasise. He said:

Is it a wonder that we will look elsewhere? So far, I always turned down lucrative overseas offers, because I do not want to leave this country and wanted to help in the education and research of Australians. I am not certain that I will be able to maintain this attitude and also wonder as to how many of my colleagues think along the same lines.

That person is not being disloyal to Australia. He has information and knowledge which is not Australia's preserve; it is knowledge which is needed by the world. People are now saying to this academic who has worked hard and long in his field and who is in demand throughout the rest of the world: 'Well, why do you sit in a place like that where you cannot get money, where you cannot get research funds, where you cannot get support? How can you justify staying at such a university when the knowledge that you have is so vital to the rest of the world?' That is the type of proposition that is being put to our best brains in Australia because the universities in this country are disintegrating. While the Government places great store on the necessity for overseas investment in Australia it does not seem to have the faith or the wisdom to invest in our own future by investing in our own citizens and their education.

I point out to the Government and to the person who wrote that editorial in the Australian Financial Review that the people we do not train today, we buy tomorrow; that the technology we do not generate in this country today, we buy tomorrow. The Government knows that we were the leaders in solar research in the world. We now do not even rate a mention. There are so many other areas in which we have led the world and then sold out our own citizens.

The universities, contrary to the comments made in the Australian Financial Review, do work hard and they make do with very little. They provide this country with a massive backbone of expertise. They produce our technologists, our business managers, our doctors, our dentists, our scientists, our researchers and they do that on very little by world standards. The denigration of these institutions by expecting them to get by on less and less every year is a national disgrace. Unfortunately, the types of problems that will show up will not show up by the next election. We are not talking about an election issue. We are talking about the future of this country. The problems will show up in 15 or 20 years when none of us here now will be fighting elections. Our legacy for future generations will be rundown, second rate, hack universities and colleges of advanced education and we will be buying in experts from overseas. We will be importing the knowledge in areas which we had been world leaders in getting under way.

I am talking about plain economics. I am not talking about any of the other things that I believe in-the Government certainly does not-that is, the fact that every Australian needs and deserves an adequate and good education and that we should develop the abilities that our people have. I am not talking about that at the moment. I am talking about plain economics. It makes good economic sense to invest in our own people. I only urge the Government before it introduces the States Grants (Tertiary Assistance) Bill of which we have had warning today, to see whether from the Budget surplus that is projected it cannot find a measly $35,000 to support a research proposal which has world-wide effects. That amount would not even have provided for the partitions in the journalists' room at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. That is the state to which we are reduced. The editorialist in the Australian Financial Review wondered why we got the types of comments we got from vice chancellors yesterday. Can any responsible vice chancellor presiding over a university disintegrating for lack of that measly, paltry sum not make a claim publicly to the rest of Australia that we must rally behind our tertiary institutions and support them? He would not be doing his job if he did not do that.

I think that shows the state of tertiary institutions in Australia. I make that plea before the Government brings in the Bill. From reading the variety of comments made by the Government I think I make that plea in vain, but I still think it needs to be made. What we are arguing-I know a lot of other people in the country are also-is not that we need massive injections of funds for us to leap ahead of everybody else. All we are asking for is an injection of funds to keep us where we are. We are way behind. The Government is intent on saying: 'We are pulling out the funds so you can drop further and further behind'. That shows the sorry state of tertiary education at the university level in Australia. Yet today in Question Time we heard Government members lauding an editorial, such as the one I mentioned, which denigrates academics, vice chancellors and the enormous amount of work done under incredibly difficult conditions in our universities.

I for one, and on the part of the Australian Democrats totally reject the accusations raised in the type of editorial. I believe that when Australians look for information in 15 or 20 years time they will look back on this Government and say: 'That is where the rot set in. That is where the rot really started and that is why we have second rate tertiary establishments in this country not able to provide even the technicians for our own developments'. In conclusion, I do not see how this Government, which has talked so much about how we should help countries not as developed as Australia, can expect us to continue such an effort if indeed we are to starve ourselves of the essential ingredients. To my mind the essential ingredients are not so much the amounts of goods we are able to generate and manufacture in this country; I think the essential goods are the knowledge, the skill, the dexterity and dedication of our people. I would much prefer we invested in those than in mines or the types of investments that seem so much to the heart of this Government. Indeed, the people of this country are our major resource. If we do not fund the education of our own people we will be a sorry country in years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a previous first reading of a money Bill I discussed a trip I had had to the north of Western Australia and made some points in relation to the Aboriginal communities that I visited there. I expressed my concern at that time that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Peter Baume, had been in the area where a confrontation between white pastoralists and the Aboriginals had taken place and that he had chosen not to go to see the community involved. I want to take the opportunity given by this first reading of a money Bill to expand a little on that situation and a number of other matters that occurred whilst I was on that trip.

SPEECH.PARA: I made mention in my speech of 22 September of the rip-off of the public purse by the white pastoralists in the north of Western Australia when I said that there were complaints from the Aborignal people that the white pastoralists were employing them as station hands and stock hands. They were not in receipt of payment from the pastoralists but were in receipt of unemployment benefit. The information that I have to date indicates that practice is much more widespread than I was first led to believe or than I first suspected. At the time of my first speech on this matter I asked that there should be at least an inquiry by the Department of Social Security or the Department of Aboriginal Affairs into just how much of a racket this exercise is and how much it is costing the Australian taxpayer. It is certainly providing cheap labour for the white pastoralists. It may be said to be providing employment for some of the Aborigines in isolated areas where they would not be likely to gain other employment. I do not think that is the point at issue; the point at issue is that if people are employed to do some work they are entitled to be paid a proper wage by their employer for the work they do.

Following my visit to Halls Creek and my discussion with the Nicholson Downs people I went to Turkey Creek to speak to the Warmun people. After I had been in contact with the chairman of the Warmun community, Mr Bob Nyalcus, he very kindly made his council available to meet with me and to discuss matters of serious concern to them, matters that perhaps honourable senators may consider to be minor in our everyday lifestyle but which are major matters when it comes to people-whether they be black or white-who live in the isolation of the north of Western Australia. I assure those honourable senators who have not been there that it can be an extremely isolated, desolate and lonely place. In the main the Aboriginal communities are of course living in the extended family situation. Perhaps they do not suffer the pangs of isolation of some of the white people who live there. During my visit I spoke with Queenie McKenzie, who was most upset. I was with her community at the end of June. On 9 July the West Australian published a report of what has been happening to Queenie McKenzie. I shall quote from the article because it shows just how people in the bureaucracy can gang up and make people very angry. The article is headed 'Red tape angers Aborigines' and is written by Paul McGeough. The article reads:
Queenie McKenzie's 2 1/2-year battle against bureaucracy has made her an angry woman.
For 13 years she has lived on the east bank of Turkey Creek near the town of the same name but has been unable to leave her humpy for new Federal Goverment-funded accommodation.

The obstacle is that the land she wants is part of a recreation reserve vested in the Halls Creek shire. Federal Aboriginal housing funds can be used only on land vested in Aboriginal associations or the Aboriginal Land Trust.
She has travelled to Perth to push her case and has escorted Federal and State Ministers on tours of the site. All have said they will help expedite the claim.
The WA Ombudsman has also been involved but there has been no conclusion.

Funds have been earmarked for members of her family and the Mung Mung family to be housed on the eastern bank but have had to be used elsewhere in the Warmun community because of the ownership problem . . .
The Warmun community's file on the bid for the extra land, and for another area they wish to acquire to accommodate their expanding community, is a litany of 'under consideration' letters.
Speaking from Turkey Creek yesterday, Mrs McKenzie said she wanted to have proper accommodation before the next wet season.
'I have goats and chickens and ducks here on the east bank,' she said. 'If I go over the other side to get a house I will have nothing left because of the dogs'.

In actual fact, she put it to me in these words: 'I do not want to spend the rest of my life in a humpy. I want to live in a home. I want to sleep in a bed. I want proper accommodation that will house me in a proper lifestyle through the wet and through the dry'. It turns out that the reason that the shire will not allow her to have this piece of land is that it is used on two days of each year by a gymkhana club. I would have thought that that situation could have been eased because of the amount of property that surrounds that area, which I understand at the moment is being leased for agistment to one of the white stock owners who apparently had no trouble obtaining a leasehold. I am sure that the proper people would not have any difficulty obtaining a small portion of the land to allow them to have Queenie McKenzie put her home there. But for 13 years she has been waiting to get a home. It would appear, given the speed with which our bureaucracy works, that she may be waiting another 13 years before she gets it. The article continues:
. . . last financial year two houses were earmarked for the east bank but had not been built.
The community would get six houses this financial year. The McKenzies would get one if the ownership question was cleared up.

. . . In a letter to the Kimberley MLA, Mr Ernie Bridge . . . last month, the community chairman, Mr Bob Nyalcas, said it appeared that the Minister for Lands, Mr Wordsworth, was allowing a neighbouring station to use as a bullock paddock the land sought by the community.
The letter said that the Minister had made no allowance for the community's request.
The Aborigines argue that they have been using the east bank of the creek before it was included in the recreational reserve used by the Turkey Creek Gymkhana Club for two days a year.
Last night Mr Wordsworth agreed that the matter had dragged on for too long.
However, he said it had been found that the club expanded beyond the boundaries it was allowed to use.

The club is obviously allowed to expand beyond the boundaries that it is permitted to use, but the Aboriginal community is not allowed to do so. However, Mr Wordsworth went on to say that in discussions with the shire council it had been agreed that this matter would be investigated and it was hoped that an exchange of land could be made with the gymkhana club to allow the community to have its site; that the community had run into problems because the land was under title; and that the situation of newcomers, such as the roadhouse further down, was different because they were seeking vacant Crown land.

The matter of the roadhouse is a contentious one as far as the Aboriginal community is concerned. It is very close to the Warmun community's housing site. The members of the community are concerned because obviously the roadhouse supplies alcohol to the workers in the Argyle Downs area, who are now coming down in great numbers to this locality. They are concerned that, having moved their community into an area where they can determine whether or not they will allow alcohol, that determination is endangered because of the close proximity of the roadhouse. That is one of the additional problems I found.

I decided, having some three months prior to my visit notified the mission station at Kalumburu that I would be visiting their area, that this would be an ideal opportunity for me to undertake that trip. I must admit to experiencing an enormous amount of trouble, as a member of Parliament, in seeing people that one is supposed to represent. I notified Father Sanz that it was my intention to visit. I also notified the chairman of the Kalumburu community, Mr John Maraltadj, by letter some three months prior to my visit. Some 10 days prior I also sent a telegram to Father Sanz and one to Mr John Maraltadj. I sent them at a time of day when I knew they would be within the radio schedule for that afternoon. On arriving home fairly late, at 5.30 p.m. or a quarter to six, I found that a telegram had just been phoned through to the effect that my visit would not be welcome at that time because plans were changing. It was signed 'John Maraltadj, Chairman'.

I thought that was a little strange as in my past dealings with the community it had always made me feel that any visit I made to Kalumburu would be quite welcome. It was interesting to note that I received from the mission neither an acknowledgement of my letter or of my telegram.
