During conversations with the Kimberley Land Council in Derby I mentioned the fact that I intended to go there the following week and would like to think that I had the permission of the community. I was informed that the President of the Kimberley Land Council had spent the previous week with Mr John Maraltadj and that John had not mentioned receiving a telegram from me. I found that rather strange in view of the fact that it was at a time when there was some controversy about Kalumburu, its administration, and the paternalistic approach that continued to be adopted by the mission. I was aware that plans referred to in the response to my telegram were under way because of my contact with the Kimberley Land Council. I had been informed some ten days before of the actual day of the proposed movement by the Kalumburu people from the mission. I could have informed the mission of the date but I did not because I did not think that it was my place to do so.

I was more than disturbed to find that I had received a telegram, supposedly from the chairman, John Maraltadj and then been informed by the Chairman of the Kimberley Land Council that to the best of his knowledge my telegram had not been received.

Recognising that the mission mans the radio schedule, one can only assume that someone is tampering with the Queen's mail, in that my telegram to John Maraltadj was intercepted and was responded to by mission staff. That disturbs me more than a little because it is an indication that the communities are not being advised of what is happening elsewhere and that decisions which may be detrimental to them are made.

However, in company with a Victorian member of the House of Representatives and his wife I decided to continue my plan to got to Kalumburu. I was then told that there was a NOTAM on the Kalumburu strip. I believe that is the technical expression and that it stands for 'Notice To Airmen'. This obviously meant that the Kalumburu strip, at the determination of the mission, was out of bounds to everybody. The Kimberley Land Council had informed me that that was going to be the case but I had said that as I had given prior notice of my visit I did not foresee any problem and it was still my intention to visit Kalumburu. I was told that the airstrip had been blocked so that private charter aircraft could not make contact with the community without the mission station first giving permission. Apparently a private charter firm from, I believe, Kununurra had taken out people to the mission station and the missionaries, having decided that they were not to meet with the community, had closed the strip.

Having been told of the NOTAM on the Kalumburu airstrip, I endeavoured to get in touch with Bishop Jobst in Broome. He was not available so I contacted New Norcia and spoke to the priest in charge. I was told that my visit would be welcome and every facility would be made available to both myself and the member of the House of Representatives to visit Kalumburu. On arriving at the airport the next morning I was informed by the Department of Transport officers that there was no way in which my pilot was going to be given permission to land at Kalumburu. First, the schedule did not open until 10 or 10.30 a.m., so they could not get a message through to the station to ask whether in fact I was going to be welcome. I then informed them that if necessary I would put through a call to New Norcia to confirm that I had been given permission by Father Bruce to go.

Eventually we were allowed to take off. I know that I am a little naive, and it was something that I did not pick up until later on, but I was not at all concerned when we landed to find a large number of petrol drums on the side of the airstrip. Being naive, I assumed that they were there for the purpose of refuelling aircraft. I was told when I re- turned to Kununurra later that night that these were the drums that had been placed on the strip to make sure that there was no outside contact with the Aboriginal community at Kalumburu. I must confess that all facilities were made available to Mr and Mrs Milton and myself while we were at the mission. We were informed that we could go anywhere and talk to anybody we liked.

The interesting thing was that neither Father Sanz nor Mr John Maraltadj was there, but I did speak to a large number of the community, all of whom were extremely surprised to find that I had sent a letter and a telegram to John telling him of my intention to come, because he had not discussed it with them. It is most remarkable in an Aboriginal community when matters are not discussed by the chairman with either his councillors or, as a general rule, all of the community. I would not think that if in fact that telegram or letter had been received by John Maraltadj he would have failed to discuss it with some of the people there. His mother informed me that he had not told her that he had received a recent telegram from me. So I have no reason to believe that he did receive it. I have to contend that my telegram was intercepted by the mission staff, who answered it on his behalf, which is more than a little paternalistic on their part. The mission staff are obviously adopting a 'holier than thou' attitude and saying 'I will determine who you will talk to and who you will not'.

There has been a lot of discussion in the Western Australian newspapers about the situation which exists on Kalumburu. One matter which has been discussed is the midday handout of what is supposed to be a hot meal. The meal is ladled out through a grill-that is the only way in which one could describe it. It is brought out from the Mission buildings in a large cauldron before being ladled out into billy cans. The meal appears to be a mixture of rice and water with something that could even be carrot. There is very little of it. The meal looked like slush to me and I would not have offered it to anybody to eat. The interesting thing was that while I was around one side of the Mission watching that midday handout Mr Milton was on the other side of the Mission. When we met on the plane later he said: 'They cannot really complain about the type of meal with which they are provided at midday. I was impressed with those beautiful steaks on the barbecue'. Of course, the beautiful steaks on the barbecue were for the mission staff and certainly not for the black people at the mission. They had been given their portion-that billy can of rice. I forgot to mention the eggs which were on top. If they were not hard boiled they would not be in an edible state by the time the people got them back to their humpies or houses.

The word 'humpy', in most people's minds, conjures up a canvas tent of some sort, but that is not necessarily what I would regard as a humpy. I would regard a humpy as a broken down building which is inhabited by people and which is not very well looked after either inside or outside. That is exactly what exists in certain sections on that mission station at Kalumburu. For instance, the elderly people live in the most incredible circumstances. The mission gardens are a picture. I suppose one could say that the area outside the houses which appear to be provided to the younger Aboriginals, because they are healthy and are able to work, is in reasonably good condition. The homes in which the elderly people live could only be described as humpies. They are in a disgraceful condition. The people did not look well. Certainly they did not look as if they were living on a mission station and being cared for. That is part of the problem at Kalumburu. The paternalistic attitude which is being adopted by the mission staff is such that the Aboriginals have not been able to develop as people.

The people moved from Kalumburu to the adjoining station. It is interesting to note that when I asked Father Umberto whether all the people had returned he said: 'Yes, all except two. One was a woman and she wanted to bring her de facto husband here but we could not allow that'. Who is to determine who is going to live with whom? Who on this earth has the right to say to another human being: 'You will not associate with such a person because I say so'? Who has that right? Certainly, the mission staff do not. If that is the custom and if it is accepted by the balance of the community then that is something which is accepted by that society and should be permitted-if permission is required, which I doubt. That is the extremely dangerous and volatile situation at the moment. It has been eased to a large extent by the fact that Father Sanz has now been moved from Kalumburu. It is interesting to note also that only two weeks ago in the National Times there was a letter from Bishop Jobst of Broome lauding the virtues of Father Sanz and describing how the Aborigines loved him. That may have been-
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was cut off in my prime, in full flight, in mid-sentence, however one likes to describe it, by the Acting Deputy President. I have warned him that as an Acting Deputy President the opportunity will arise for me to take the same action against him, I am sure. If it does not I will manufacture it. I was speaking about a letter from Bishop Jobst which appeared in the National Times two weeks ago and which said how much the Aborigines of Kalumburu loved Father Sanz. I raised the question of whether that love and affection that perhaps was there some years ago in actual fact is still there with the awakening of the Aboriginal people. That paternalistic approach is not what will fulfil their lives. We have many white people who interfere in Aboriginal affairs. It is because of that interference that the Aboriginal people are unable to fulfil themselves completely. I am not suggesting for one moment that we should provide them with large sums of money and then say that they are on their own and that they can do all things.

SPEECH.PARA: In a moment I want to return to discussing the situation I found at Ringers Soak, but first I will deal with the situation at Kalumburu. I have already made mention of the fact that my planned visit to Kalumburu was impeded to some extent by the interference by the mission staff and, possibly, the administrators in the collection of mail which was addressed to the chairman of the Kalumburu community. He had obviously not been advised that I would be there and consequently he was not there when I arrived; I add that neither was Father Sanz. I am feeling a little happier about the situation at Kalumburu now that I have discovered that Father Sanz has left the mission and gone to New Norcia. I hope that the new administrator will recognise the problems associated with Aboriginal development and will extend to the Aboriginals the pastoral care and the normal human concern that those people require at this time. This is a very difficult period in the lives of Aboriginals in Australia.

I want to touch on the situation at Ringers Soak where the people from Gordon Downs have been taken. In my previous speech I made mention of some of the things which concerned me and which had not been done within 12 months of those people moving from Gordon Downs to Ringers Soak. I made mention of the fact that a well had been left without a top covering it so that any young child could fall into it. What concerned me also-this matter was raised on my behalf by another colleague at the Estimates committees-was the fact that there is no provision, apparently, in the estimates for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs for immediate attention to be given to people when they find themselves in distress, as happened to the Nicholson Downs people. When they left their station they were on their own. In response to a question about that matter the Minister said that the situation was being monitored. I am saying that monitoring the situation is not quite good enough when an entire community of some 35 or 40 people are camped on the outskirts of a town with only fresh water being provided to them and with one canvas fly between all of them when there are overnight temperatures of 4 degrees. In those circumstances the Minister cannot say that his Department is only monitoring the situation. That is not quite good enough. There has to be some mechanism by which immediate assistance can be provided to those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Secular paternalism.

—That is right. Let me make this point: At Ringers Soak I found a pathetic situation in that the leader of the group was concerned that his people had available to them fresh vegetables. He had developed a small area as a market garden. Inside an area no larger than 2 feet square were something like 200 carrot seeds which were starting to sprout. No one had bothered to give those people advice on how they should tend those carrots. That is just one example. They had melons, cabbages and everything else. Nothing had been planted in the right way because no one was there to give them advice on how to start a market garden. No one cared about the provision of fresh vegetables for the entire community.

SPEECH.PARA: My time is limited. In the four minutes left to me I want to speak for just a moment about the report in last week's Age on the hospital at Warburton. I understand that the administrator of that hospital is leaving. All I can say is that the whole Aboriginal community at Warburton must be thankful that he is leaving. I have not read the newspaper report. I have simply been told about it. I will be checking it as soon as I have finished making my speech in this place. It would appear that the hospital services for the Aboriginal community have been so run down as to be almost entirely non-existent. At the door, which is barred and bolted, there is a screen window to prevent anybody from getting in and taking advantage of any medical services that might be available to them. Hanging inside that door is a rubber cosh. One has to question what services the hospital is supposed to be providing. The hospital is obviously not there to provide the care and medical attention to the Aboriginal community at Warburton which it should be providing. That is cause for great concern.

All of the things I mentioned in my speech on 22 September and which I have mentioned tonight are matters of grave concern. They are of concern to the black people of Australia. They are of concern to the white people of Australia. They are of concern to the caring people of Australia. I believe that we have seen enough paternalism, particularly since 1967. I draw on that date because that was the date of the referendum in which the entire Australian community determined that Aborigines had a proper place as proper citizens of this country. Having accepted that principle, surely to goodness it is now time to demonstrate that we are really a caring, concerned community, that we have really a caring, concerned government and that we will do our utmost to make sure that any Aboriginal program is managed by Aboriginals for Aboriginals and that its success will depend on Aboriginals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills before the Senate are non-controversial and I feel that they are supported by both sides of the chamber. Therefore, I take this opportunity to bring to the notice of the Senate the disastrous situation in the export apple industry in my State. This past season has been a calamity for the industry. Prices in Europe have been extremely low. This is because our main competitors have had bumper crops. The European market is flooded with fruit. This is nothing new. The Tasmanian apple and pear growers in the past have faced similar situations. Over the last 10 years the industry has retracted as far as it possibly can as a direct result of European Economic Community policy. It is only just now viable. The problem of fluctuating prices is one faced not only by apple growers. Indeed, those living on the land are so used to prices going up and down and shortages and gluts that they seem to face this problem with tremendous fortitude. The Federal Government recognises this situation and, indeed, allows primary producers to equalise their tax burden to cope with the good and bad seasons.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this year things are different in our Tasmanian industry. The Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority, which deals with the export market, is now seeking a $2.8m repayment of the advances made to growers. This is the total debt facing the apple growers after all payments have been made for the 1981 season. I would like to underline the fact that the Federal Government has indeed paid more this season under its underwriting scheme than on any previous occasion. Yet the apple growers in my State start the new season with this tremendous debt hanging over their heads. It means the whole of the export industry is in jeopardy.

On the face of it, the Federal underwriting scheme is a very just scheme. It allows the underwriting figure to be reached by averaging export prices for the last four years. This year that price was $5.60 a carton. However, with the inclusion of this tremendously low season in the average for the four years, the estimated underwriting price for 1982 will be $5-a loss of 60c a carton. This reduction will mean that many growers who previously exported their full crop must think over the situation and consider local markets. The implications of Tasmanian fruit that was previously exported going on to the local markets would be understood by every senator who comes from a State where apple growers put their fruit on the local market. It would be disastrous for them but it may at least enable our apple growers to survive.

The present cost of growing apples in Tasmania is $3.50 a carton. That is 30c a carton less than Western Australia can manage. As I have said, our industry is a most efficient and productive one. The cost for packing and cool storage is $3 a carton. If we add to that figure inflation for 12 months of 10 per cent, the debt from the Tasmanian Apple and Pear Marketing Authority, increases in freight and wharfage, the additional running costs of TAMA and a host of other increases, we can see that the reduction in that underwriting price of 60c a carton will create insurmountable problems for next season. The growers just cannot go into the season with that enormous debt. If the apple growers were at fault through inefficiency, incompetence or lethargy I would be the first to say that industry should go. From the very first planting of an apple tree to the finished carton packed on the wharves-that is, while the apple growers in Tasmania have control over their own fruit-the industry is efficient and productive. The growers not only have kept up with the latest in new plant and cool stores but they also have invested more in this area in the past five years than in the previous 20 years.

So what are the problems? One is the revaluation of the Australian dollar in relation to overseas currencies and the other-the one that concerns me-lies with the fruit when it leaves the hands of the grower and is ready for shipment. I wish to give the Senate a few figures which compare Tasmanian wharfage costs with those of our main competitors. I refer firstly to the loading costs per carton. The costs are: Chile, 25c a carton; South Africa, 25c; New Zealand, our closest competitor, 32 1/2c; Brazil, 35c; Argentina, 45c and Tasmania, $1.16 a carton. That is for loading onto the ships. I also bring to the attention of honourable senators the matter of productivity-that is, the loading rate per gang hour. I refer to the same countries. Chile loads 1,185 cartons per gang hour; South Africa, 1,250 cartons; New Zealand, 1,100 cartons; Brazil, 1,000 cartons; Argentina 1,000 cartons; and Tasmania, 488 cartons per gang hour.

When one looks at those figures one wonders how the Tasmanian fruit growers were ever able to compete. We have to consider whether the Government has any responsibility for the fact that Australia has the most expensive wharfage in the world. Should an efficient and productive industry just go down the drain because we have allowed this situation to develop on our wharves? This is the question we have to answer. There is no way the Australian apple growers can continue to compete with those in other countries with this wharfage burden round their necks. When the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) rises to reply in this debate I would be grateful for his comments. I suggest that the Minister suggests to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) in the other place that he should look at an amendment to the Export Underwriting Act enabling the lowest year of the previous four years to be disregarded when the minimum export return rate is struck. This may assist our industry. I have great confidence that the Minister in the other place will not allow our apple industry to go to the wall through no fault of its own; allow it to go to the wall because we in Australia have allowed our wharfage rates to be so much greater than in any other country. It is an efficient industry and must be able to survive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on a matter of public importance on 23 September Senator Rae refuted claims by Mr Anthony that Mr Webster, the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation, had falsely claimed on 13 October 1976 that the Australian Dairy Corporation had suspended sales of skim milk powder at below the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade minimum price. In refuting the statement of Mr Anthony, Senator Rae tabled documents supplied to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, of which he is Chairman, which proved that the Dairy Corporation had suspended sales at that time. Senator Rae then added:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . between 13 October and 15 November 1976 . . . Mr Webster negotiated a contract which involved a continuation of the breach of GATT until the end of June 1977.

Senator Rae then asked what act occurred between those dates. He then suggested that it was an interview with the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair. I have since received information which confirms Senator Rae's conclusion. It shows not only that Mr Sinclair condoned breaches of GATT-he instigated them. In late 1976 the Australian Dairy Corporation had refused to issue an export certificate for skim milk powder which was to be sold at below the then GATT minimum price. A dairy products manufacturer who had been refused a certificate by the Dairy Corporation-probably by Mr Webster himself-made representations to the Minister to see what Mr Sinclair could do to assist this manufacturer. Mr Sinclair contacted Mr Webster and put pressure on him to issue a certificate on the grounds that everyone else was breaching GATT anyway.

Having regard to all the circumstances of the time many people might argue that Mr Sinclair's action was, if not fully justifed, then at least pardonable. What is not pardonable in his parliamentary denials of the truth about his role in the GATT breaches. He has misled Parliament not once but many times. He refused to deney his role on oath before the Senate Standing Committee on the ground that he had denied it in Parliament. The sanctions of Parliament, Mr Sinclair claimed, were more severe than the sanctions of perjury. Let the first of those sanctions now be applied; let his resign. Under no other regime in Australia's history would a Minister with Mr Sinclair's record have been allowed to remain in Cabinet. Only a Prime Minister too cowardly to stand up to the National Country Party and require it to resile from its assorted villainies would allow this country to be run like a banana republic. I know the details of some of these incidents but must withhold names to protect individuals from victimisation by the National Country Party Mafia, which controls crucial departments in this Government. Given the audacity of Mr Sinclair in toughing it out and the cowardly abdication of responsibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Fraser), there seems little hope of satisfactorily resolving this issue unless the parliamentary Liberal Party cries 'Enough' or unless the Senate inquiry into the Dairy Corporation is re-opened. I suggest that the Senate should consider that action.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN APPLE AND PEARCORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL(No. 2) 1981
The purpose of this Bill is to increase the number of grower members on the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation from four to six.

This change has been requested by the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association which represents apple and pear growers on a national basis, and which nominates candidates for appointment to the Corporation as grower representatives.
The Association believes that an increase in the number of grower representatives will enable the Corporation to more fully reflect the interests of different apple and pear growing regions.

The Government has accepted this view. In effect the current grower membership is sufficient only to represent major exporting areas. The growing importance of the domestic market means that we must provide the scope for fuller representation on the Corporation of those growers supplying that market.

The difficult export situation being faced by the industry, highlights the importance of the Corporation's domestic market promotion function and the need for a membership which will enable this function to be performed as well as possible.
This Bill and the changes proposed in the associated Levy Bill and Export Charge Bill are designed to increase the Corporation's capacity to carry out this task.

An opportunity has also been taken in the Bill to bring those sections of the Act relating to the dismissal of members and disclosure of interest into line with standard provisions in other similar legislation.
Also the number of members who constitute a quorum has been increased from seven to eight because of the increase in total membership of the Corporation.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
APPLE AND PEAR LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1981
This Bill increases the maximum rates of levy to enable the industry, should it so wish, to support greater activity by the Corporation in domestic promotion and other programs.

It does not change the operative rates of levy which are set by regulation. Actual charges at present are: Juicing fruit-50 cents per tonne; processing fruit-$1.00 per tonne; in any other case-5 cents per box.

The present Levy Act provides that fruit which is not packed in boxes but to which the box rate of levy is applicable is to be converted to a box equivalent on the basis that a box equals 18 kilograms of apples or 20 kilograms of pears.
The Bill also amends this basis so that, consistent with the weight equivalents used for similar purposes in other apple and pear legislation, a box equals 18 kilograms of either kind of fruit.
The amendments have the support of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
APPLE AND PEAR EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1981
This Bill increases the maximum rate of export charge per box of fruit to bring it into line with the maximum rates provided in the associated Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1981.
The Bill does not change the operative rate of charge, which is set by regulation and presently stands at five cents per box.

Two other amendments have been made. The weight factor used to convert fruit not packed in boxes to a box equivalent has been modified on the same lines as for the Levy Act. The Bill also amends the section dealing with the regulation-making power of the Governor-General to bring its expression into line with other legislation.
The amendments have the support of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to two of the three Bills before the Senate-the Apple and Pear Levy Amendment Bill 1981 and the Apple and Pear Export Charge Amendment Bill 1981. One levies a charge on fruits sold on the domestic market either as fresh fruit or as processed fruit, and the other levies a charge on fruit exported for the common purpose of providing for promotion and other expenses of the Australian Apple and Pear Corporation. The Bill dealing with fruits sold on the domestic market increases the maximum rate of levy. It does not necessarily increase the operative rate of levy, which is determined by regulation. The actual charges authorised by the Bill are 50c a tonne for juicing fruit, for processing fruit $1 a tonne, and for other fruit 5c for an 18 kilogram box of apples or a 20 kilogram box of pears.

SPEECH.PARA: The Apple and Pear Export Charge Amendment Bill increases the authorised maximum rate but the present rate will remain at 5c a box. There are also some minor changes to the weight factor and some other minor changes dealing with the regulation-making power under these Bills which are about to become Acts to bring them into line with other legislation. It is claimed, I believe correctly, that the Bills in question have the support of the Australian Apple and Pear Growers' Association, the members of which will, of course, be paying a levy. The Opposition does not oppose the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the opposition for its support of the Bills, and wish the Bills a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment, requests, or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill (No. 2), which gives effect to a taxation agreement between Australia and Denmark, similar to agreements previously negotiated with numerous other countries, including Japan, the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada and West Germany. The agreement in this case, as in the precedents, relates to the taxation of individuals and enterprises to prevent the double taxation of income earned in one country by a resident of another country. It also simplifies the obligations of the taxpayer so that the taxpayer knows in advance how earnings in one country will be treated in another.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill contains provisions designed to prevent tax avoidance arising from price manipulation between branches of the same company or between related companies operating in different countries-what is commonly known as transfer pricing. It is worth noting, as my colleague Ralph Willis did in the House of Representatives when the Bill was debated there, that Mr Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association, who has again been receiving a good deal of publicity in the last few days, about which I will probably be saying more later this evening, has estimated that the Melbourne branch alone of the Australian Taxation Office loses $2,000m each year from transfer pricing. If that is correct, the estimate for all of Australia must be well in excess of $3 billion and possibly as high as $4 billion. There are documented cases dealing with transfer pricing. In the celebrated Comalco Ltd case within the last 12 months the High Court of Australia, following the precedent established under the chief justiceship of Sir Garfield Barwick, came down on the side of the tax dodgers-in this case international corporate tax dodgers-and refused to levy the tax which would clearly have been due to the Australian subsidiary of the company had the actual price been appropriately disclosed.

Without doubt transfer pricing is a serious problem, comparable in magnitude to the problem of tax evasion, or taxation theft as it probably ought to be known, by Australian residents, and this Government has failed to take effective action in either case. However, we do not oppose the Bill because it is not primarily concerned with the question of transfer pricing but with the extension to Denmark of the so-called double taxation agreements, for which numerous precedents already exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for its support of the Bill and wish the Bill a speedy passage.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the first reading debate on this legislation to refer to statements and Press comment in numerous newspapers not only in Australia but also throughout the world relating to the tragedy that is known as East Timor. I was appalled this morning when listening to the Australian Broadcasting Commission program AM to hear a former Australian diplomat make certain statements in respect of Portuguese Timor. Sir Keith Shann, a former diplomat of some 35 years standing, made statements on that program which I believe need to be thoroughly rejected and repudiated certainly by my side of politics if not by the Parliament itself. Many of us in a bipartisan way have concerned ourselves with the problems of East Timor. We have had numerous debates in both the House of Representatives and the Senate on this issue. I am concerned about what I consider to be a disgraceful and despicable contribution to this problem by a diplomat of some 35 years standing, whose statements have been published in this morning's newspapers and broadcast during this morning's ABC program AM. Not only did the diplomat take the view that the Indonesian Government acted correctly and properly in invading and annexing a former colony that was established by Portugal some four centuries ago but also he went so far as to say that the Australian journalists who were murdered at Balibo in 1975 had asked for it and had got it. He made statements that they went into the area-
—This is Shann?

—Sir Keith Shann. He said that they went into the area wearing Fretilin uniforms against instructions not to go there. Of course, this raises the very vexed question about the role of sections of the Foreign Affairs Department who have taken it upon themselves over a considerable period to speak on behalf of the Australian Government, the Australian Parliament and the Australian people. They do not have that authority and we ought to disassociate ourselves from their attempts to defend the indefensible attitude that was taken by the Indonesian Government about that territory which-in a state of flux it is true-was invaded by the Indonesian Army and which has been the subject of a protracted war since 1975. All that the people of Portuguese Timor wanted to do was establish their right of self-determination. This Government, this Parliament, the Australian Labor Party and the United Nations in overwhelming majority decisions have endorsed the right of people to self-determination.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that there are many grey areas in respect of what happened in that region. Peter Hastings, the foreign editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, made a number of assertions and statements in this morning's edition of that paper, some of which I agree with and some of which I disagree with. I was privileged to go to Portuguese Timor in 1974 and 1975. On the latter occasion I went with two prominent members of the Liberal Party of Australia. We came back and spoke as one voice as a result of our experiences. I am sickened by the statement that has been made by Sir Keith Shann that the journalists who went into the area of Balibo acted in a way that deserved retribution. Firstly, I would say that Sir Keith Shann's information is incorrect. I met a number of journalists in August 1975 on the second occasion I visited that country. I cannot remember, of course, whether they were the same journalists who were subsequently killed at Balibo. But let me say that they were journalists who were doing the job that journalists are employed to do. They were there to investigate, to examine and to report the circumstances of the projected invasion, which invasion in fact occurred subsequently to the coup that took place in this country when Malcolm Fraser and his minions seized power as a result of the infamous conduct of our Governor-General of the day-I call him the cur that he is. The regrettable feature is that, in the absence of any factual information, a former diplomat who spent many years in Jakarta, the Philippines and Japan, should make a statement that our journalists were dressed in Fretelin uniforms. All I can say is that the Australian delegation of members from both sides of the Parliament and the journalists who were in East Timor in August of 1975 were dressed as the average Australian dresses in a tropical climate, that is, with the least amount of clothes but sufficient to be able to say they were dressed properly.

I do not believe that any evidence is available whatsoever and to that extent I call Sir Keith Shann a liar when he suggests that the five journalists who were murdered at Balibo were dressed in Fretilin uniforms. Likewise I call him a liar when he says that they were warned not to go there. Who would have warned them not to go there? It is true that the Australian parliamentary delegation that went there, which included Senator Bonner, Mr Fry, Senator McIntosh and myself, were warned by the officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs in Darwin that there could be trouble in Dili and that there were rumours that the Indonesians would subsequently take some unilateral action in respect of Portuguese Timor. We were going, therefore, in the knowledge that there could be repercussions.

An Australian representative in Dili looked after us. He has subsequently been shown to have been employed as a member of either the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation or the Australian Security Intelligence Service, which is the branch which operates under the umbrella of the Department of Foreign Affairs. He took us in his plane to various parts of Portuguese Timor. He was not in a position to give us any advice, and I am certain that he gave no advice of the nature that Sir Keith Shann has suggested. Therefore, I say that the information that Sir Keith Shann gave in an address to the Australian-Asian Association of Victoria yesterday at its silver jubilee meeting, and repeated on AM this morning, is propaganda coming out of the Indonesian intelligence organisations. Sir Keith Shann, as indeed his successor, our Ambassador, Mr Critchley, have lived too long in Indonesia and have succumbed to the Indonesian point of view to the detriment of objectivity and to the detriment of Australia's basic position in respect of the rights of small nations.

We have had some posturing in recent times but I am prepared to give some credit to the Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Malcolm Fraser, in relation to his activities in respect of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, his association with the Third World countries and his apparent conversion to the principles of a better distribution of wealth and resources throughout the world and particularly to the underdeveloped countries. I find it, therefore, something of a contradiction that, on the one hand, we have our Prime Minister properly acting as the host to this conference and pledging himself to the principles of self-determination, human rights, and all of those other important principles-some might say platitudes, but certainly principles about human relations and relations between governments and the rights of the people-and on the other hand we have a former diplomat of this country not only defending to the last degree the role that Indonesia has played in this issue of Portuguese Timor but also going so far as to suggest that the journalists involved were guilty of some malpractice or some improper conduct.

I believe the journalists represented all that is best and noble in their profession in seeking to get a story to the outside world. It will be remembered that at that time communication had been deliberately stopped in relation to what was happening in Timor, and steps had been taken by both the Indonesian Government and, regretfully, the Australian Government, to sever communications with a country that was struggling for the basic and simple fact of self-determination, the right to determine its own affairs-the very basic principles upon which governments ought to operate and which governments ought to support. Because of that, newspapers and television channels in Australia made a decision that journalists should go to Timor with a view to reporting the facts.

Unfortunately, the Australian Government, and-I say this with regret-a Labor government, was being given information and advice from a section of the Department of Foreign Affairs which was slanted towards the Indonesian point of view. It was given on the basis that we could not afford to offend the powerful nation of Indonesia. So we were prepared to write off the rights of 600,000 people. We were prepared to dismiss the principles of self-determination, the principles of the rights of people to make a decision about their own future. These people had been enslaved by a tyrannical country and had been part of a colony since the sixteenth century. Their only crime was to express the desire to make a decision about their own future.

Because of this breakdown of communication-I remind honourable senators that there was a decision taken that broke the communication link between the people in Timor and the outside world-Channel 7, if my memory serves me correctly, and several newspapers in this country and one from overseas, the country escapes me for the moment, decided to send in journalists and a television crew for the purpose of recording for the outside world the events which were rumoured to have taken place. We saw the assassination of President Sadat a week or so ago and saw what television cameras were able to do. There were people there with initiative to report that particular public function which the President of Egypt was attending. They were able to record the actual attempt, the successful attempt as it turned out to be, to assassinate the President of that country.

All that the journalists in Timor were seeking to do was to tell the world the truth, to report the facts. Yet this man, Sir Keith Shann, says that our journalists were dressed in Fretilin uniforms and that they were in areas that they were not supposed to go to. I challenge Sir Keith Shann to come to the Senate, to come to the Australian Parliament, and tell us who made the decision that the journalists were not to go to Balibo. Where did he get that information that the journalists were dressed in Fretilin uniforms? People in their logical sense knowing that they were reporting a possible invasion, civil war or war situation would know that they would not dress themselves in the uniform of the supposed enemy. Does anyone seriously suggest that that is what responsible journalists and television crews would do?

Yet this man, Sir Keith Shann, has suggested that they got what they deserved because they had put on such a uniform. We have also read in the newspapers of reports circulating in Portugal to the effect that a government of the Left as well as a government in Australia, a government in New Zealand, a government in the United States and a government in Great Britain acquiesced in the invasion of Timor. I repudiate that suggestion. I reject it because I was involved, as I have said before, in intimate discussions with leaders of the Government that I supported at that time. Whilst it is true that there was an Indonesian lobby working within the confines of the Labor Government in that period-obviously if it was working within our Government it would have been working within the Liberal Party-it is totally untrue to say that on a radical side of politics there was any acquiescence in the Indonesian invasion of Portuguese Timor.

The circumstances were that the almost 50 year dictatorship in Portugal had been overthrown as a result of a revolt among the Portuguese people led by large sections of the Portuguese Army. Decolonisation was taking place in Africa and other Portuguese colonies. There was a great deal of confusion. There was a desire on the part of Portugal to share its responsibilities and the cost involved in maintaining its responsibilites in its former colonies. There was a desire to democratise the country and to shed the fascist past which was so much a part of Portugal itself. In Portugal there was not as much concern about what was happening in Timor as perhaps there would be in normal circumstances. Mozambique and other Portuguese colonies had won or were in the process of gaining their independence, so Portugal was not in a position to make a rational decision in respect of what was happening in Portuguese Timor. This was causing some concern to the Australian Government. In my discussions with Mr Whitlam and former Senator Willesee, they expressed their concern about the lack of concern of the Portuguese over what was going on in Timor. I think that was understandable, having regard to the conditions which existed at the time.

I think it is totally wrong therefore to suggest that in those circumstances Portugal acquiesced in the invasion and annexation of Timor by Indonesia. It had in fact at every meeting of the United Nations subsequent to that period voted against a formalisation of that annexation. It joined forces with the Third World countries and a majority view of the United Nations and opposed what Indonesia did in December 1975. The Australian Government, of course, committed as it was to a policy of non-interference in other countries, having made the decision a couple of years previously to withdraw Australian troops from Vietnam because we did not believe that we had the right to interfere in the internal affairs of another country, did not see fit, and correctly so, to send troops to protect the rights of the 600,000 indigenous people of East Timor.

In all of those circumstances there was a political vacuum. There was a movement for self-determination-a movement by a very small country to establish its own form of government and organise itself to stand on its own feet. But before it could do that the situation unfortunately was that the pro-Indonesian group, known as the UDT, had seized power in June 1975. Consequently the reaction was that the view of the independence group-the movement that was opposed to the Indonesian absorption, the movement for self-determination that was so evident to us when I was there in 1974 and again in 1975-became the majority view.

I can say that in August 1975 I had never felt freer when I walked in the streets of Dili and visited the towns and villages of Portuguese Timor. There were no policemen and there was no coercion. The people were running their own affairs. They were entitled to make their own decisions and they were functioning freely. Sure, they needed assistance, just as many countries in the Asian and Pacific region need assistance in their struggles for self-determination. The unhappy fact is that there were generals in the Indonesian Army who not only were unconcerned about human rights for their own citizens but who also were prepared to take advantage of political situations in their own country in order to establish in that country their own hegemony. They set about the processes of the invasion that took place early in December 1975.

I think it ill becomes a diplomat to make statements, in the face of the overwhelming majority of world opinion, in the face of the overwhelming opinion of the Australian people and in the face of the overwhelming opinion of the Australian Parliament, that, Indonesia was justified in doing what it did. Petitions were circulated in both the House of Representatives and the Senate and were signed by members on both sides of the Parliament. My recollection is that the overwhelming majority of members, something like 90 members of the national Parliament, signed the petition to President Carter asking him to intercede in respect of the problems in Timor and to condemn the Indonesian position. Party boundaries were cut across in a unique and rather historic way. The Parliament, without formalising its position, took a view that what the Indonesians had done was regrettable, that it was to be condemned and that it was unacceptable to any freedom loving people. Yet this man has come out and not only defended the Indonesian position but also has defamed the journalists who were murdered in Balibo. It will be recalled that this Government, the national Parliament and the Australian Journalists Association have from time to time tried to get information from the Indonesian authorities about what did happen. We have been frustrated in every way by the Indonesian authorities. I find this man's remarks despicable, disgraceful and regrettable.

I know I speak on behalf of my party because when we discussed the question of Timor at my party's Federal Conference in Perth that Conference, with one dissentient, decided to condemn the Indonesian position, and that remains our view. We condemn without any equivocation the remarks made by Sir Keith Shann. Not only did Sir Keith Shann defame these journalists and defend the Indonesian position but also he went on the record to suggest that Radio Australia-our own broadcasting organisation-was guilty of infamous conduct, distortion, exaggeration and peddling of gossip and rumour because it dared to express a view contrary to that of the Suharto dictatorship that exists in Indonesia.

This man who claims to represent our point of view-Australia's point of view-had the audacity to add to the remarks that he made about the journalists and Australia's position in respect of Timor and to condemn Radio Australia and the Australian Broadcasting Commission for their attempts to convey to the people of South East Asia, which includes Indonesia, some of the objective facts about the corruption, nepotism and other factors of social and political life in Indonesia that are completely repugnant and unacceptable to anybody who supports the principles of democracy. I finalise my remarks by saying that I am ashamed to be associated with the remarks made by Sir Keith Shann. I am sure that would be the overwhelming view of a great number of the people of our country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
INCOME TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1981
This Bill will amend the income tax law in a number of respects.

It will give effect to proposals announced in detail by the Treasurer on 16 July 1980 to deal with the threat to company tax revenues posed by the growing practice of public company groups reorganising their affairs so as to eliminate company tax on some of their income.
The practice involves the transfer of profitable assets, particularly investment in property, to unit trusts.

The Bill will also implement two Budget announcements-one to change the basis on which friendly society dispensaries are taxed and the other to reduce the rate at which capital expenditures on the development of a mine or oil field may be written off for tax purposes.
Some extension of the gift provisions of the income tax law is also to be made by the Bill and-finally-it will also provide the method for calculating provisional tax for the 1981-82 income year.
Public Unit Trusts
The main concern of the Government in this respect is to prevent ad hoc erosion of the so-called classical system of company taxation through the use of unit trusts by public companies.
Accordingly, the broad thrust of the amendments is to remove the taxation advantage sought by companies from placing income producing property in the hands of unit trusts.
This is to be achieved basically by treating unit trusts evolving from the practice as if they were companies for tax purposes.

Broadly, the taxable income of a public unit trust to which the amendments apply is to be subject to tax at the rate applicable to companies generally, now 46 per cent, and distributions to unit holders out of income and profits of such trusts are to be taxed in the same way as they would be if they were dividends paid to shareholders of a company.

These rules will apply to unit trusts formed as part of a reorganisation of a company or group of companies where, as part of the reorganisation, a business or other property of a company is transferred to the trust and shareholders in the company are given preference as regards taking up units in the Trust.

To confine the scope of the amendments closely to the kinds of practices referred to in the Treasurer's statements on the matter, the amendments will apply only if it is part of the reorganisation arrangement for the unit trust to be a ''public unit trust'' as defined in the Bill.

In broad terms a ''Public unit trust'' is defined as one of the units in which are listed on a stock exchange, are held by 50 or more persons, or are available for investment by the public. For this purpose, a person and his or her relatives or nominees will be counted as one person.

In harmony with the broad objective of equating public unit trusts with public companies it is proposed by the Bill that, where the income of such a trust includes dividends from companies, a rebate of tax is to be allowed in the same way as would be the case for dividend income received by a company.
Unit trust distributions made by a public unit trust to a unit-holder that is a company will qualify for rebate on a comparable basis in the unitholder's hands.
A number of safeguarding measures are contained in the Bill to support the objectives of these proposals.
The new basis for taxing public unit trusts and their unitholders will first apply in relation to the 1980-81 income year where the trust is established after 11 July 1980.

In recognition of special problems presented for unit trusts established, in some cases, out of company reorganisations a number of years ago, the amendments will apply from the commencement of the 1983-84 income year for trusts established on or before 11 July 1980
Friendly Society Dispensaries
As announced in the Budget Speech, the Government has decided to remove the present special basis of taxing the dispensaries.
In future they are to be taxed in the same way as other non-profit companies.

The effect of this decision as implemented by the Bill is that normal company tax rates will apply to the net income of dispensaries arising from investment income, from receipts from the Commonwealth for the supply of any pharmaceutical benefits and from charges paid by non-members for the supply of pharmaceutical goods and other products and services.
These changes will first apply to income derived by dispensaries in the 1982-83 income year.
This will allow the dispensaries time to adapt their accounting methods to the change.
Gifts

Amendments proposed by the Bill will further extend the existing gift provisions of the income tax law which confer deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities or institutions.
One extension will authorise deductions for gifts made after 30 June 1981 to the Victorian Arts Centre Trust.

The second will authorise deductions for gifts made during the current financial year to a public fund established for the purpose of observance of the International Year of Disabled Persons by a committee appointed by the Commonwealth, a State or the Northern Territory for that purpose.
Capital Expenditure on the Development of a Mine or Oil Field

The Bill contains the amendments necessary to give effect to the proposal announced in the Budget Speech to increase from six to ten years the maximum statutory life by reference to which deductions allowable for capital expenditure on the development of a mine or oil field are determined.
The new basis of deduction will apply generally to expenditure incurred after 18 August 1981.

However, where the expenditure is incurred after 18 August 1981 under a contract entered into on or before that day, or in respect of work carried out by the taxpayer which was commenced on or before that day, it will continue to be deductible by reference to a maximum statutory life of six years as at present.
Provisional Tax
As I think is generally understood, provisional tax is that part of the pay-as-you-earn system designed to collect tax on income other than salary or wages within the year in which it is derived.
That being so it is only reasonable that the amount charged should closely approximate the amount of tax actually imposed for the year.

In this way, the provisional tax arrangements are able to achieve a desirable measure of consistency between the treatment of salary and wage earners and of persons who derive income from a business or from property.

In the absence of provisions to the contrary, provisional tax for 1981-82 would be calculated by applying 1980-81 rates of tax to 1980-81 taxable income and taking into account rebates at their 1980-81 levels.
It is, however, expected that incomes for 1981-82 will generally be higher than for 1980-81.

As against this, due to the application of half-indexation the effective rates of tax for 1981-82 are lower than for last year and, of course, dependant rebates for 1981-82 are greater than those for 1980-81.

In the circumstances, it is appropriate that a varied basis be applied in calculating provisional tax for 1981-82 where taxpayers do not exercise the right to have the tax calculated on the basis of their own estimates of taxable income for the year.

The Bill provides that provisional tax for 1981-82 is to be calculated on the basis of taxable income for 1980-81 increased by 10 per cent and applying to this adjusted income the lower effective rates of tax applying for 1981-82.
Dependant rebates are to be allowed for in the calculations at the higher values set for 1981-82.
I add that the notional increase of 10 per cent for 1981-82 incomes over 1980-81 is less than the estimated average rise between the two years in taxable incomes of people subject to provisional tax.
This will provide a buffer against any excessive provisional tax.

And, of course, taxpayers who consider their taxable income for 1981-82 will increase by less than the notional 10 per cent have the option of 'self-assessing' and thus having the provisional tax for 1981-82 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates of taxable income for the year.

Mr President, a memorandum containing more detailed explanations of technical aspects of the Bill has been made available to honourable senators and, at this stage, I think there is no need for me to further address the matters covered by the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (INDIVIDUALS) BILL 1981
This is an annual measure which formally imposes personal income tax for 1981-82 at the rates declared in the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1976.

Honourable senators will recall that, following an announcement on 29 April 1981, the Income Tax (Rates) Act 1976 was amended in the Autumn sittings to declare rates of tax payable by individuals and trustees generally for 1981-82.
These rates reflect the decision that there is to be half indexation of the personal tax rates scale for the 1981-82 income year.
It is worth recalling the effects of that earlier legislation.
Application of the half indexation factor has meant that for 1981-82 the standard rate of 32 per cent will not apply until taxable income exceeds $4,195.
It was $4,041 last year.
The other steps in the scale have been correspondingly increased so that the 46 per cent rate will apply after $17,894 and not $17,239 as previously.
The maximum individual rate of 60 per cent will not apply until the taxable income exceeds $35,788.

The resulting tax reductions benefit all individual taxpayers, and, together with associated increases in rebates for dependants, have been reflected in lower pay-as-you-earn deductions since 1 July last.
They will be reflected in provisional tax payable for 1981-82.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
INCOME TAX (COMPANIES, CORPORATE UNIT TRUSTS AND SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1981
This Bill will formally impose income tax for 1981-82 on the 1980-81 incomes of companies and the income of superannuation funds of the current year.
The rates of tax are also declared by the Bill and are the same as for 1980-81.

In line with measures contained in the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981, about which I have just spoken, the net income of some unit trusts is to be taxed at the public company rate of tax, 46 per cent.
Measures to impose this tax are also in the Bill.

Provisions of the Bill otherwise follow the same lines as in other years and details of the various rates are set out in the explanatory memorandum that has been made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three income tax Bills are being debated concurrently by the Senate. The Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 does a number of things. It expands the range of charities and neo-charities to which contributions are tax deductible, it provides for the collection of provisional tax, it reduces the depreciation rate on machinery purchased for the mining industry from a diminishing balance rate of 16 2/3 per cent to a diminishing balance rate of 10 per cent, and it eliminates a scheme devised for the invasion of company tax through the use of unit trusts. The Opposition will not oppose this Bill but I want to make a few comments about it.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, on the proposal to reduce depreciation rates for mining industry investment, while not objectionable in itself, the proposal highlights yet again the absurdity of this Government's business taxation policy. In the last 15 months we have seen no fewer than four changes to the rates of depreciation for business expenditure. In the Budget of 1980 there was a 20 per cent across-the-board increase in the depreciation rate for investment in machinery. In November, as a result of off the top of the head pork barrelling by the member for Wannon (Mr Malcolm Fraser), we had an increase in some rates of depreciation applicable to agricultural machinery. In May last year the 20 per cent increase across-the-board in general depreciation rates, as a result of the razor gang farce, was reduced to 18 per cent. That is what one would call fine tuning the taxation system-reducing a surcharge of 20 per cent to a surcharge of 18 per cent six months later! One could not fine tune the taxation system much more effectively than that!

Now in October we have yet another change-the fourth in 15 months-to the depreciation rates applicable to business capital investment. Some stability! We used to hear a great deal from the member for Wannon and others in the Liberal and National Country parties about the need for predictability and stability in the business environment. As in so many other fields, there is an enormous gulf between the rhetoric of this Government and the record. The fourth provision, which I mentioned, in this Bill is to eliminate the evasion of company tax through the use and misuse of unit trusts. We are of course supporting that provision as we support every provision designed to crack down on the social crime of tax avoidance. However, we criticise the provision because it does not go far enough.

This so-called crackdown was announced by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 16 July last year. But it does not become effective on those who were already in the racket at that time until July 1983. Some crackdown! That parasitic trinity of shonky accountants, shonky lawyers and tax bludgers who contrived this blatant artificial scheme to rob their fellow citizens have been given three years of grace to continue their theft. Then they must stop robbing the rest of the taxpayers. That is the crackdown provision provided in this Bill. I suppose it is entirely consistent with the attitude of the Government which runs roughly along the following lines: 'If you are caught with your fist in the till it is all right as long as you pay the money back, especially if you are a Minister'.

The Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill 1981 imposes tax on companies, superannuation funds and some trust income for this financial year although the income actually taxed will be that received in the 1980-81 financial year, as is the custom with Bills of this nature dealing with company taxation. We will not oppose that Bill. The Income Tax (Individuals) Bill 1981 will be opposed by the Opposition. We will call a division on this Bill. This Bill concerns pay-as-you-earn taxation, tax on wage and salary earners and tax on the self-employed. It imposes the personal tax rates which have already been set in prior legislation in the Income Tax (Rates) Bill. We will oppose this third Bill.

Taxation on wage and salary earners-both direct and indirect taxation-already at a record level in the last financial year, is to be increased as a result of this Bill by a massive 22 per cent. Average taxation paid by wage and salary earners in this financial year will rise, according to the Government's own estimates, by a massive 22 per cent-a 22 per cent increase on top of a pre-existing record level of taxation on wage and salary earners. That is not the end of it. The indirect taxation base is-if this Government gets its way-to be both widened and deepened by an extension and intensification of sales tax which in a full year will add another $892m to Government revenue.

We have two complaints about this Bill. The first concerns the macroeconomic aspect. It is becoming increasingly apparent that economic growth is stalled and has been since the last quarter of the previous financial year. Unemployment is rising, yet this stagnant economy is to be hit with massive tax increases. It is an economy which already has an unemployment rate that is almost 6 per cent and rising. This economy, with its stagnant level of output, is to be hit by a highly contractionary Budget, of which this taxation legislation is a central component, that is estimated to produce this year a domestic surplus of $1,500m. If that figure were adjusted to account for what one might roughly call a seven-year seasonal correction-because there is an extra pay day for Government employees and social welfare recipients this year-it would be in the vicinity of $1,900m. It is inconceivable that any other country since the 1930s, or at the worst the 1940s, would have imposed so contractionary a Budget upon an already stagnant economy with near record levels of unemployment. Pre-Keynesian primitivism is alive and well in the Australia of Malcolm Fraser.

The rationale for this highly contractionary Budget has two prongs: Firstly, that it is necessary to beat inflation; secondly, that it will reduce interest rates. The prerequisite for accepting that dogma is a remarkable capacity to abstract from reality. On the first point, that of inflation, it is necessary to ignore the Budget Papers, the Government's own estimate that the rate of inflation in this financial year will be 10.75 per cent. Even that is a misleading figure, because it represents the average increase this year over that for the previous year. The actual estimate of the increase in the consumer price index from June 1981 to June 1982 is not 10.75 per cent but 11.9 per cent, or almost 12 per cent. The comparable figure for the previous year was 8.8 per cent. The underlying arithmetical reason for the discrepancy between the average figure for the entire year and the figure for the end of this financial year, as compared to the end of last year, is that the rate of inflation will be increasing throughout this financial year. That is some way to beat inflation. On the Government's own admission, the inflation rate is up from 8.8 per cent to 11.9 per cent.

The interest myth is that high, record present interest rates are caused by the voracious borrowing demands of the public sector. The line followed is that if the deficit is eliminated the public sector borrowing requirement comes down and therefore interest rates come down with it. Acceptance of that argument again requires a remarkable facility to abstract from reality. The public sector borrowing requirement as a proportion of the gross domestic product, the total output of the economy, declined steadily from 5.6 per cent in 1977-78 to an estimated 3.4 per cent this year. While over those four years that public sector borrowing requirement has been falling at a very significant rate, interest rates have been steadily rising to their present record level. They are not likely to fall in the near future unless the present stagnation of the economy deteriorates into a catastrophic recession. The recent figures for the international account suggest that that is highly likely unless some other substantial offsetting action is taken.

The great Fraser myth, accepted I note with regret by some gullible journalists, is that the economy is in good shape-not perfect but in good shape. What is the reality? On the Government's own admission, inflation is rising substantially. On the Government's own Budget forecast, unemployment is at almost 6 per cent and will rise further. Interest rates are at record levels and are unlikely to fall. Economic growth is either stagnant or, conceivably, actually negative at this time. If all of the Government's forecasts are to be realised, it is interesting to compare the present condition of the economy with its condition at the end of 1975 when, according to Mr Fraser, it was in such a catastrophic condition that any political skulduggery he could devise-in conjunction with the drunken megalomaniac who was Governor-General and the tax-dodging corporate criminal who was Chief Justice-was justifiable because the economy had to be rescued from the catastrophic condition into which the then Labor Government had placed it. In 1975 inflation was 13 per cent and falling. At the end of this year, if the Government's own forecasts are realised, it will be 12 per cent and rising, so there has been little, if any, improvement there. Unemployment is now almost 6 per cent and rising. In 1975 it was 4.2 per cent and stable. The Government forecasts growth during this financial year to be around 3 per cent. It is now quite apparent that that target will not be met. At the end of 1975 it was above 4 per cent. The interest rates on medium term Government paper are now 13 per cent. In 1975 they were 10 per cent. On the basis of three of those four major indices of the health of the economy, the economy is in a significantly worse state today than it was in 1975.

In most countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development the recession bottomed in 1974. In Australia, after three years of the Fraser Government, it bottomed in 1978. It might be necessary this time next year to amend that statement to bring it up to date. It might be necessary to say that the economy bottomed not in 1978 but in 1981-82. Australia is the only country of all the OECD countries that never lifted itself out of the recession of the 1970s. This Government is a government of failure. The failure of the Prime Minister as a macro-economic manager is seriously compounded by his moral financial infamy. The all-time record taxation over which the Prime Minister now presides has been imposed most severely on those who are least able to pay, and most cruelly of all on the single income families, for which this Prime Minister and this Government profess to have such a deep concern.

I wish to refer to two articles, published this week in the Sydney Morning Herald, which drew upon material supplied by Mr Eric Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers Association, not the Labor Party. That association is one that I would expect would not be particularly favourably disposed to the Australian Labor Party. However, it has a certain professional integrity in regard to making completely objective assessments about the state of taxation, about reality. These articles draw on information supplied by Mr Risstrom. I will pick out some of the highlights. In the six years ending June 1982-if all of the Government's forecasts are correct-indirect taxation will have risen by 150 per cent. In the same period inflation will have risen by only 75 per cent. So we could say that indirect taxation will have doubled.

Let us look at income tax. A single income family with two dependent children, on average weekly earnings, the family about which this Government professes to be profoundly concerned, is paying anything up to 81 per cent more tax in real terms than it paid six years ago. For such a family, which the Government professes is the epitome of its social ideal, taxation has almost doubled in real terms on what it was 10 years ago. A single income family without children, on average weekly earnings, is paying $26 a week more tax than it would have, had the 1975 real levels of taxation still existed. It does not stop there. It is not just income tax. The average family with two children will be paying between $3.50 and $5 a week extra sales tax this year if the Government's sales tax legislation manages to get through the Senate.

As well as there being a very substantial increase in the aggregate level of taxation to all-time record levels which are about to be increased by this Bill, the burden of income tax and indirect taxes has been shifted regressively towards the lower income groups. This is partly because of changes in the income tax schedule, partly because of the high degree of tax avoidance, partly because of additional and increased sales taxes and partly because taxation in other areas, non-income tax, has been reduced. Australia is the only country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development that does not apply a tax on capital or capital gains. Australia, under Malcolm Fraser, has regressed to a position in this respect to the right of where the British Liberal Party was in 1911.

Before I close I want to expose in advance a fraudulent gimmick which is now being concocted within this Government; that is, the gimmick of so-called tax cuts being introduced next year. At the likely rate of income increases-again, I use the rate forecast by the Government in its Budget Papers-owing to what Mr Fraser used to call the secret tax of inflation, income tax revenue will increase by $1,500m in real terms this year. That is not just an increase of $1,500m because dollars, under this Government, will be worth about 13 per cent less in a year's time than they are worth now. After adjusting for the inflation factor, income tax receipts, because of what the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation, will increase by $1,500m at expected rates of increase in incomes.

The Prime Minister, as we know, finally has totally buried tax indexation. This major reform-or what was presented as a major reform in 1975-which was essential to end what the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation has now been formally and decently buried. The secret tax of inflation runs wild under this Prime Minister. Indexation-which was probably the most solemn of all of the 1975 pre-election promises-having been repudiated and permanently interred, any so-called tax cut of less than $1,500m will, in fact, be a tax increase. It is a difficult concept to grasp for people who are not accustomed to thinking about these things. To put it in its simplest form, I repeat that, because of what the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation, any so-called tax cuts amounting to less than $1,500m this year will, in fact, be a tax increase.

The Fraser Government is to be doubly condemned for its gross incompetence in being the only government in the OECD which, throughout the second half of the 1970s, failed to lift its economy from the recession of the mid-1970s, even though at the time it took over government growth was running at 4 per cent. Incidentally, that is a figure which was not equalled until the financial year which has just passed. The Government is to be condemned for its gross incompetence in the area which it nominated as being of prime concern. It should also be condemned for the culpable immorality of the way in which it has transferred this enormous and record burden of taxation onto those groups which are least able to bear the burden. The Government should be condemned for the epitome of its hypocrisy in having transferred that burden on to the single income family about which it professes to have a special concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to outline very briefly the Australian Democrats attitude to the Government's tax strategy. Whilst agreeing almost entirely with the comments of Senator Walsh, who outlined the Australian Labor Party's attitude to the Government's tax strategy, we do not propose to take any action that may delay the passage of the Government's tax Bills. We are taking this action primarily in the interests of practical politics. We believe that there are two areas in this current Budget which the Government should look at very carefully and about which any reasonable government should be capable of being prevailed upon to change its mind. I refer to our stand on the imposition of sales tax on the necessities of life and also to our foreshadowed action in requesting the Government to increase its grants to the States for housing. We believe that these two initiatives hold out some hope for action by the Government. However, to attempt to delay the Government's tax strategy is, we believe, asking for too much.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we do not propose to take any action we criticise in the strongest possible terms what the Government is doing. We criticise in particular its action in relation to income tax. Australia already imposes one of the highest rates of income tax of any nation in the Western world. In spite of that there is to be an additional $3,300m collected in personal taxation under this Budget. Senator Walsh said that that represents a 22 per cent increase. I do not know where he got that figure from. Our arithmetic shows it to be a 19 per cent increase. Whatever it is, it is a massive increase-almost double the rate of inflation. It will have a devastating effect on the taxpayer. We have this massive increase in income tax but added to that we are to have, of course, the great increase in indirect taxes, including the increases in sales tax. These increases add up to $1,500m. So we have increases in income tax and indirect tax.
