We also have the secret taxes in the form of the crude oil levy and the cost of driving a motor car, which is a necessity for most households. We have the cost of health insurance and, of course, we have the added costs of high interest rates. If one aggregates the costs of all of these tax increases and the hidden tax increases in the form of health insurance and the cost of driving a motor car, the cost of the Government's policies, the amount of money which will be taken out of the pocket of every taxpayer in the country this year will be in excess of $1,000. I repeat that it is in excess of $1,000 a year for every taxpayer. We agree with the Labor Party that this great increase in the tax burden at a time when all the indicators are that the economy is at least stagnant, if not in fact positively turning downwards, will have a very disastrous effect on the health of the economy generally.

We criticise not only the massive increases in the tax take this year but also the direction being taken in the spending of this greatly increased revenue. A sensible person would hope that the increased revenue would be directed to labour intensive areas such as home and road building. We find that this will not be the case. We hoped that there would have been some increase in allocations for education. The reverse is the case. Instead we find that the Government is buying expensive toys such as special overseas equipment for the Royal Australian Air Force and the Royal Australian Navy. At the same time it is proposing to curtail our capability for manufacturing our own defence requirements in such places as the Ordnance Factory at Bendigo and the Government Clothing Factory at Coburg.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is also reducing the deficit.
—It is in fact budgeting for a massive domestic surplus of $1,500m; not a balanced Budget but a massive surplus.
—That is a domestic surplus.

—Indeed, it is. I do not believe there is any Western economy-certainly not the economy of the United States of America-which has clamped down to the degree that this Budget is clamping down on the social necessities of life, taking those from the people and at the same time imposing massive increases in taxation. President Reagan with his supply-side of economics is at least clamping down on government expenditure. At the same time he is reducing taxation. But this Government is doing both. There is a two-way squeeze and it will inevitably-this is unavoidable-have disastrous consequences for the economy. We do not believe the Government should get away with it. We intend to do what we consider is in the realm of practical politics by standing firm in opposing the Government's sales tax legislation in relation to the necessities of life. We propose at the appropriate time to move that a request be sent to the House of Representatives asking that increased expenditure on housing be effected. That is at least a labour intensive area of the economy and one in which increased expenditure would materially assist unemployment. We criticise the Government's taxation policies. We will not support any move to delay them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for the passage of the income tax Bills. I note from Senator Walsh's remarks on behalf of the Opposition that the Opposition does not intend to oppose two of the Bills and that it will call for a division on the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill. I do not wish to make many comments but I think that one or two of Senator Walsh's comments should receive some response. He referred to the change in the depreciation allowed for the mining industry. Perhaps it is appropriate to say that the circumstances of the mining industry have changed substantially since 1976 with the mining sector having entered a period of strong growth which is expected to continue for some time. For example, the Australian Statistician's survey of investment expectations points to an exceptionally strong growth in mining investment in 1981-82. The schedule of 'Major Manufacturing and Mining Investment Projects' recently published by the Department of Industry and Commerce adds further support to this view.

SPEECH.PARA: It ought to be borne in mind that where there has been criticism, such as that expressed by Senator Walsh with regard to changes in tax legislation affecting business, perhaps everyone could share that concern. At the same time I think governments, when introducing taxation legislation or when compiling Budgets, need to look at concessional elements which apply to one industry or another or to industry in general. In response to conditions which exist at a particular time it is competent to make changes taking account of the changing economic circumstances and to cast a Budget accordingly. What might have been seen at one time as a special industry incentive for one purpose or another does not necessarily remain static year upon year without some review of that being necessary. In this Budget it was felt that it was appropriate to reduce the taxation assistance given to the mining area by extending the period of reference in which capital development expenses could be written off to a 10-year period.

The other matter which deserves just a brief response is the comment made with regard to unit trusts. I note that the Opposition did not oppose the proposal but criticised it by suggesting that we allowed a delay, a period of grace, for unit trusts which were established on or before 11 July before this new tax legislation would have effect. Some of the unit trusts which will be affected by the proposed legislation were established several years before the Government's announcement. Therefore, many of the present unit holders would not have been a party to the original arrangement to reorganise a company into a unit trust. In the circumstances the Government considered that it would have been unfair to penalise such unit holders in a way that would have caused an immediate reduction in the value of their units when they had acquired their units in the open market along with unit holders in the numerous other public unit trusts which will not be affected by the proposed legislation.

Other comments with regard to unit trusts were made in the other place on behalf of the Opposition and the Government has noted what was said in this regard. I have noted that there will be a division on the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill. I have noted the comments of the Australian Democrats with regard to their approach to this legislation. I am surprised to hear their continued comments with regard to the sales tax Bills but perhaps we can leave those matters for another day. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it the wish of the Senate that the question for the second reading of the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill 1981 be put as a separate question? There being no objection, that course will be followed.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Income Tax (Individuals) Bill 1981 be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Income Tax Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1981 and the Income Tax (Companies, Corporate Unit Trusts and Superannuation Funds) Bill 1981 also be now read a second time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Bills together read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or requests, or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEFENCE FORCE RETIREMENT AND DEATH BENEFITS AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I shall move the amendment which has been circulated in my name. The purpose of the amendment to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Amendment Bill is to reduce the invalidity, retirement and widows' pensions paid under the Act if a person's rate is based on an acting rank held prior to death, invalidity or retirement. As such it is an important piece of legislation and it deserves careful scrutiny, particularly if we compare the proposals in it with the superannuation provisions covering persons in acting classifications in other Commonwealth Government retirement benefit schemes, notably the Commonwealth Public Service superannuation schemes. It is clearly inequitable, we believe, to penalise defence service personnel for serving in an acting rank when, on the other hand, Commonwealth public servants are rewarded for acting in similar circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) in another place did not choose to deal with these issues when he made a bland ministerial statement on 14 May this year in which he foreshadowed the introduction of this Bill to amend the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act of 1973 to correct what he described as 'an unintended effect of this legislation which was revealed in a recent Federal Court decision'. He said that the amendment would restore the operation of the scheme to the basis intended since its inception in October 1972, namely, that a person's contributions and entitlements are based on rates of salary for substantive rank and not for acting rank. The Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act would be amended with effect from 14 May, the date of the statement, to restore what the Minister described as the intended policy and to revert the pensions of those who were currently entitled to higher benefits to the levels applicable to their substantive ranks on retirement.

In the Minister's second reading speech in another place on 27 August he stated that for years contributions and benefits were calculated by reference to the salary rate of the substantive rank held by the member, with the higher duties salary, which is a common situation in the armed forces, being disregarded because of what he described as the transitory nature of the acting and temporary rank arrangements. In May 1980 the Federal Court of Australia decided that the intended link between rank in Australia and annual rates of pay regulations was not properly established. This meant that acting and temporary rank rates of pay in the armed services should be taken into account for both contributions and benefit purposes for all Services after the scheme started on 1 October 1972. A relatively small number of beneficiaries-about 550-are entitled to higher retirement benefits as a result of this decision of the Federal Court. The Minister stated at the time that the Bill would restore to the scheme the original intent that a member's contributions and retirement benefits should be calculated on the basis of the annual rate of pay applicable only to the substantive rank and not to the acting rank. Under this Bill pensioners or beneficiaries entitled to additional pension benefits will be paid in full, including any available commutation amounts, from the date of retirement. From May 1981 their pensions will be adjusted by reverting to what they would have been if calculated according to substantive rank held on retirement and taking into account any additional lump sums received.

It seems fairly reasonable for the Government to want to amend this complicated piece of legislation and the Opposition certainly believes that it should be tidied up. However, I think we must look at the real reason for the Government's anxiety to correct this legislation. The Minister referred briefly to the need 'to correct an unintended effect of the 1973 DFRDB legislation which was revealed in a recent Federal Court decision'. This is not the first time, and I am certain it will not be the last, that a decision of the Federal Court has resulted in hurried efforts to correct the sins of omission of previous legislation.

Since the Minister did not choose to enlighten honourable members in another place about the details of that recent Federal Court decision, I will touch briefly on it myself. The case is known in the Services simply as the Duncan case. Commander Peter Duncan had been granted the rank of captain from 8 November 1977 until 16 July 1979, when he was compulsorily retired. In other words, he was acting in the rank of captain from November 1977 to July 1979. During that time he was paid salary and allowances at the annual rates appropriate to the rank of captain and he received incremental increases appropriate to that rank. On 27 April 1978 he wrote to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority contending that this contribution should have been made in amounts appropriate to a captain's pay rates and he was liable to have a larger sum deducted from his pay. On 8 May 1978 the DFRDB Authority refused to let him make larger contributions on the grounds that, although he was an acting captain, he was liable to make payments appropriate only to his substantive rank of commander. The contention was that rank in the DFRDB Act of 1973 referred to substantive rank.

On 18 May 1978 Captain Duncan requested the Authority to reconsider his request. On 9 May 1979 the Authority advised Captain Duncan that legal advice confirmed the earlier view that, firstly, the acting rank should be ignored for the purpose of determining the annual rate of pay; secondly the scale of contributions should be based on the substantive rank only; and thirdly, the retirement benefits payable under the Act should be based on the substantive rank. Captain Duncan then requested the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to review this decision, and on 20 August 1979 the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, in a majority decision-one person dissenting-affirmed the decision of the Authority.

He then appealed to the Federal Court against the Administrative Appeals Tribunal decision. On 27 May 1980 the Federal Court found that the legal liability of the applicant to contribute and his legal entitlement were not affected by the Authority's view. The Authority had no power judicially to decide these matters nor to determine them in any final sense. Yet the Authority's view was accepted by the Royal Australian Navy pay office and this was effective in preventing the deduction of a larger contribution from Captain Duncan's pay. Now that the applicant had retired, the administration of the DFRDB Act may make it desirable that some adjustment be made in respect of contributions and retirement pay conformably with the declaration made.

The Court ordered that it be declared that the amount of the anual rate of pay of the applicant on the days between 8 November 1977 and 16 July 1979 was the annual rate of salary payable to a captain who had completed the longer period of service specified for an officer holding that rank.

It further ordered that the matter be remitted to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal to be heard and decided again and that the Tribunal be directed to make an order as to the receipt of additional amounts by way of contributions as appears to it to be appropriate consistent with the liability of the applicant as declared by the Court, and that it hear further submissions to assist it to determine what order was appropriate.

It had taken 25 months for Captain Duncan to get that far. It took another 12 months for the Government to decide to act to take away the right he had established for himself and others under that legislation. I suggest that in view of that delay it is easy to understand the bitterness which led Captain Duncan to write to the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, on 19 August this year, saying:

. . . how disillusioned I was to return from sea to be informed of the Department's determination to amend the DFRB Act. The statement made to me after the AAT hearing in 1979 by the DFRB representative, that no matter what appeals I may make and win, the Board would ultimately have the legislation changed, certainly seems to have been prophetic.

Captain Duncan's legitimate grievance reflects the concern evident in the recommendations of the Jess Committee report which led to the revamping of the DFRDB scheme in 1972. In September 1970 the Joint Select Committee on Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Legislation was set up in response to complaints from servicemen and ex-servicemen that the then DFRDB scheme was impractical, ridden with anomalies, and randomly disadvantaged retirees. The joint select committee was chaired by Mr J. D. Jess, C.B.E., M.P., and therefore became known as the Jess Committee. After an inquiry lasting over two years the committee found that the complaints were justified and recommended that sweeping changes be introduced to remedy the anomalies and injustices that it had documented in its report.

The report recommended that all defence force members on continuous full time duty for 12 months or more should be eligible and required to join the DFRB scheme, that all contributing members be required to contribute at a flat rate of 5.5 per cent of pay and that retired pay and invalid pay be expressed as a percentage of final pay and adjusted annually so that relativity with average weekly earnings was maintained. However, the leading recommendation of the Jess Committee that the existing DFRB Act be repealed and a new scheme introduced which should apply to both retirees and serving members was not then fully implemented. In the event, the old DFRB scheme with all its anomalies, inequities and injustices was retained for all personnel who retired before 1 October 1972.

The new scheme, the present DFRDB scheme, covers all who retired after 1 October 1972. It is clear that the Jess Committee intended to use the rate of pay as the determining factor. Sections 19 and 23 of the Act are equally clear in specifying that contributions and benefits will be based on actual rate of pay. The Minister's contention that this amending legislation will restore the operation of the scheme to the basis intended since its inception in October 1972 does not stand up. It does not stand up in the words of the legislation, as was clearly demonstrated by the Federal Court decision; it does not stand up to any reading of the Jess Committee's report. We only have to go back to the original pamphlet on the DFRDB scheme which was made available to those transferring to the new scheme on the eve of the 1972 election. One would be forgiven for thinking that the timing of the new scheme amounted to a last minute attempt to buy the servicemen's votes.

The pamphlet stated that the new scheme was based on recommendations of a joint select committee now known as the Jess Committee, to which I have referred. The pamphlet went on to state that contributions were payable at the rate of 5.5 per cent of the member's fortnightly rate of pay with effect from the first pay-day following 1 October 1972. There was no reference in the pamphlet to substantive rank. The reference before and in the pamphlet was constantly to the rate of pay received by the servicemen. The fornightly rate of pay for contribution purposes was the member's annual rate of pay multiplied by 14 and divided by 365. The annual rate of pay for contribution purposes was the maximum rate of pay for the member's rank-that is, where increments are provided, the maximum of the salary range for that rank-plus service allowance if payable. The pamphlet said specifically that a member whose annual rate of pay was reduced could elect to have the change in pay disregarded for the purposes of both contributions and benefits. Perhaps this was not what the Government intended servicemen to believe. Perhaps it was not what the Government intended them to believe was the general purpose of the new scheme. But it is certainly what they were told at the time-it is nonsense for the Minister to suggest that the amending legislation is being put up simply to restore the original intention. One can judge the original intention only by information which was given to servicemen at the time. One can judge it only as the Federal Court judged it-by the words in the legislation itself.

Certainly the new scheme, even as it was stated then, did not satisfy servicemen and did not satisfy DFRB pensioners at the time. After a lapse of some years and a renewal of the complaints on behalf of the original DFRB pensioners, the Fraser Government appointed Mr Duke Bonnett, a former member of parliament, to inquire into and report on the matter. Mr Bonnett reported in February 1978 that the complaints were justified and strongly recommended that a number of steps be taken to upgrade the benefits paid to the original DFRB pensioners, noting that 'some of these retired personnel fought in two, and even three wars in which our country was involved and that a review of those pension entitlements is no more than justice merited'. The Government took no action on the Bonnett report until, after repeated representations, the Minister for Defence announced in a brief statement in November 1979 that all the recommendations had been rejected.

As the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association pointed out in a carefully prepared paper presented to the first national conference of ex-service organisations in August this year, the attitude of the Fraser Ministry since that time has been universally hostile to all attempts to achieve some measure of justice for these older ex-servicemen and their widows. This legislation represents a similar hostility to those who qualified under the new DFRDB scheme. The same organisation rightly contends that the real reason for the proposed amendment to the Act currently under consideration by this House is that the Department of Defence has made a major error in its interpretation of the Act, as demonstrated by the Federal Court ruling, and now wants the Act amended to bring it into line with its erroneous interpretation. It not only wants to cover this error but also wants to avoid the administrative effort involved in setting the error right. It goes without saying that this course also attracts the present Government as it will save some money by reducing the pensions of the affected members and their widows.

It is not the case, however, that service conditions are so attractive, as has been asserted by members of the Government parties, in this economic climate. It is not the case that the Government can get away with this penny pinching approach to the welfare of those who are charged with the responsibility of defending this country. It is not only this area that creates problems for the Government and problems for ex-servicemen. The major areas of complaint dealt with by the Office of the Defence Force Ombudsman include administrative changes on pay, allowances and conditions of service and discharge decisions. Other decisions have been made which have affected ex-servicemen and servicemen in this way. At a time when expensive Army Reserve recruiting campaigns were conducted by the Government to the somewhat revolutionary tune of that well known composer of the 1812 Overture, the Government's razor gang abolished the Former Regular Services Members vocational Training Scheme. That scheme enabled retired servicemen to train for a job in civilian life, to make up in part for their relatively short careers unless they were destined for senior office. Many officers, faced with retirement on inadequate pensions in their middle age, have taken advantage of the scheme to help them into either industry or their own business undertaking. Now that scheme has gone. For those still serving, inadequate pay increases of 2.95 per cent granted on top of 4 per cent in July 1980 have led to complaints particularly from lower ranks. I believe that every member of this place has received letters about this matter. One could be forgiven for believing that this Government, which purports to be so keen on defence matters, would be trying to make current service conditions, training, housing and retirement benefits as attractive as possible. This legislation, of couse, demonstrates that this is not so.
Sir William Keys, the President of the Returned Services League, was quoted in the Canberra Times of 4 September 1980 as saying:

I believe any fair-minded adjudicator would go for certain preferment in the serviceman's basic rates of pay. They have to be available for duty all day, every day and are subject to incredible family turbulence caused by frequent moves. They often have to engage in dangerous work and training and they have to be available to place their lives at risk should the nation ask them to do so.

I do not think anyone can argue with that statement. I do not think anyone can argue that their rates of pay and their rates of retirement benefits should not be at least the equal of those in the Public Service.

It is significant that the Returned Services League and the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association have recently agreed to form a conditions of service committee to study the current problems and provide advice to the Government in this area, advice that has been ignored in the past and I suppose will be ignored in the future. They consider that a source of independent advice free from the constrictions of the bureaucracy should be of valuable aid to the Government in avoiding the blunders and thoughtlessness which I believe are presented in this legislation.

The legislation affects not only servicemen but also defence force widows, especially those under the DFRDB scheme. The majority of defence widows living on pensions obtained under the Defence Forces Retirement Benefit Act 1948-1973, the old DFRB, receive an income below the current level of the poverty line. During their husband's service in the defence forces a significant portion of the family income was a mandatory contribution to the DFRB fund. The present situation is widely regarded within the defence community as evidence of the Government's neglect and disinterest in the welfare of Service families. These widows need an increase in their pension to provide some measure of justice.

Annual consumer price index adjustments to the pension of the widows of servicemen retired under the DFRDB scheme are not at the full rate of the declared CPI percentage. The present practice of eroding these widows' pensions by granting them only part of the CPI rate is a mean and, I suggest, petty measure which actually saves very little money but gives great offence to Service families who view it as a Government confidence trick against the widows and the orphans of ex-sevicement. The discrimination against defence widows who married prior to 10 November 1977 should be ended. All widows whose pensions were terminated because of remarriage before this date should in fact have their pensions restored as a matter of right.

In addition to taking up these matters at the national conference of ex-service organisations, the Regular Defence Forces Welfare Association recommended other changes. It has recommended that the membership of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Authority should be enlarged to include a defence widow as a member of the Authority, a reasonable request, I suggest. It considers the present structure of the Authority as much too restrictive in a body dealing with the administration of some thousands of widows and orphans, and I suggest that it has a point.

Certainly the DFRDB legislation needs adjustment. But it is a common situation in the defence forces of this country, and particularly in the Army, that people move on to acting rank rather than substantive rank, and they move on to that rank for considerable periods because this is the way in which our defence forces are run. It was clearly the intention of the Jess Committee and of the pamphlets which were issued to members of the defence forces that contributions to the DFRDB scheme and benefits from the DFRDB scheme should have been based on actual salaries. The Federal Court of Australia agreed with this and took the view that this was clearly the intention of the legislation as it was stated.

We believe that there is obviously a need to reconsider this legislation. We believe that obviously some people will be detrimentally affected by it. It is for this reason that I think we all should have a close look at this legislation. It is for this reason that I move:

Leave out all words after ''That'', insert ''the Senate calls for the deferment of consideration of the Bill until the Government has prepared and presented additional amendments to provide for the establishment of the right of Service personnel who serve temporarily in a higher capacity than their substantive rank, to elect to contribute at the rate applicable to the temporary higher grade and to qualify for benefits as if the temporary higher rank were the substantive rank.''

I suggest that if this Bill were deferred and if the Government looked at the recommendations of the Jess Committee and looked carefully at the situation and compared the position of those in the defence forces with those in the Public Service generally, the Government would arrive at the same conclusion as the Jess Committee's recommendations and the original legislation's intention. Such benefits should be contributed to and paid for at the actual salary rank. This would result in not only the elective provision that we call for in the legislation but also a reversion to what was clearly the intention of the original committee and the original legislation. It is for this reason that I have moved the amendment on behalf of the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are interested obviously in anything which provides an adequate career service opportunity for people in the defence forces. It is essential, I think, that we should provide that opportunity. I think that has not been sufficiently provided in the past and the organisation of our defence forces has suffered. People who go into the defence forces and who want to see their way through a lifetime career ought to be given every opportunity to do so. For this reason we are a little concerned about the proposed amendment of the Australian Labor Party. We have considerable sympathy for it and for the anomalous cases that have been described by Senator Grimes.

SPEECH.PARA: One of our problems is that we have had very little time to consider this Labor Party amendment. If the Labor Party had agreed to let us know something about it a little earlier perhaps we would have been able to give it more mature consideration. But as it stands now and on our observation of it at this time, there are a number of problems. There is a problem, for instance, about what would happen if a person were allowed to go up for a considerable period to a rate applicable to the temporary higher grade he was on and then had to revert to the previous grade. Would he then have contributions refunded to him or would he remain in a position where he was better off than the person who was on that substantive rank and had never been advanced further? That is a question which I think I would like the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to deal with when he sums up on this matter. I take it that some thought has been given to it.

Our fundamental objection is that we cannot legislate to justify anomalies. Basically this amendment says that there is an anomalous situation, for one reason or another, a degree of instability, perhaps, in our defence forces, which ought not to be the case in peace time in a country which has a regularly planned Defence Force. In that case it should be possible for a person going through the various areas of promotion to expect substantive promotion progressively and to pay superannuation at that rate. Perhaps that cannot be achieved for a variety of reasons, and I do not think any sort of band-aiding or patchworking around it will be very good in improving that basic situation.

Plainly a short term temporary promotion will not warrant a request to pay superannuation payments at the higher rate. There is no reason why a person who is promoted for only a short period to a higher rank-and it is usually known that it will be a short period-should pay those higher payments. There is no reason at all why we should even expect that to be the case. The man who might expect it to be the case would be the man going into the temporary higher position for a considerable period. Our position is that if the Labor Party wishes to sanctify and justify that kind of situation in the defence forces, it is also then saying to us that it wants a continuation in the defence forces of a situation where everything is such a mess all the time that it is not known whether people can be promoted to those ranks, and I remind honourable senators that I am speaking of promotions for a lengthy period.

Here again I think it is most unfair to the officers or people of any rank who are occupying these positions. If they are to occupy a position for a considerable period, certainly a sufficient period to make them think it will be worth their while to pay higher contributions, they ought to have some reason to believe that at some stage the position will become a substantive rank. We do not see any reason why that should not happen. We suggest to the Labor Party that if it wants to legislate here it should look at that sort of situation and try to encourage that system to apply in our defence forces. If we do that, we will create a situation in which people going into the defence forces will not do as they are doing now. They will go into an acting rank with no real certainty of whether they will hold that position. They know that they have a regular stepladder of promotion which I think they have every reasonable right to expect. For that reason we do not believe that it is worth while delaying this Bill and we are opposed to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister.
—A few minutes, if I may.
—Are you on the speakers list?
—I call Senator Georges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I have been quite silent for some time. Just because I have spoken a couple of times today does not mean you can cut me off, Mr Minister. I am drawn into this debate by the foolishness of the Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Mason). I have not heard so much rubbish in all of my life as I heard from Senator Mason. I take it that those members of the defence forces who have listened to him would agree with me that it is necessary for the Democrats to have a look at the amendment and perhaps even seek an adjournment of the debate so that its members can take a more intelligent position on it. In the short time that I have had to peruse it I have come to the conclusion that what is good enough for parliamentarians in this place is good enough for members of the defence forces. Under our superannuation scheme, if a parliamentarian moves to an executive position and he is paid at the higher rate he contributes at the higher rate. There is a formula by which superannuation is paid according to the earnings that he received during the period of his service.
—We don't have substantive ranks here. It is not a parallel situation at all.

—It is a parallel situation. Senator Mason is talking about substantive ranks. Any position which a member takes in this place can be quite temporary. A member could be a Whip for a year or five years and then he could revert to his former position. A member could be a Minister for a period and then lose that position if there were a change in government. But when it comes to payment of superannuation, the payment is based on the amount that a person has earned. There is a formula by which the superannuation can be calculated to the benefit of the person concerned. It seems to be quite odd that the Australian Democrats do not accept the amendment which would provide justice for these people in the defence forces. There is no real problem about the calculation. It is quite simple. When a person moves to a higher rank in a temporary capacity his contribution is based on his earnings in that position.

SPEECH.PARA: This happens on many occasions in the armed forces because of transfers and overseas assignments which may render it necessary for someone to move up to a temporary position. Although that may not be an appropriate illustration we have heard of the situation in which it was necessary for a person to take a temporary rank for a period of some 18 months. That is not unusual in the Army and of necessity it does happen. During that time he will earn a higher salary and he should be entitled to pay the higher superannuation contribution. Even though at a subsequent time he may go back to a lower rate of earnings, having contributed to the superannuation fund at a higher rate for a period his entitlement at the end of his period of service should be based on his earnings. I cannot understand why Senator Mason cannot see the simple justice of the proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about a public servant on higher duties allowance? He doesn't contribute at a higher rate during that period. What are you talking about?

—If he does not, he ought to. If there happens to be an anomoly in one area that is not an argument against the proposition which has been put in this debate. If public servants are not entitled to make higher contributions when they are doing work at a higher level and therefore get a higher entitlement the Democrats ought to be presenting a case in support of what is being proposed for the armed Services. That is my view and I think there is justice in the proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I cannot for the life of me understand why there has been the amount of opposition that has been described in the case of the person named Duncan. It seems to me that the bureaucrats have dug their toes in, as is often the case. I have seen this evidenced in hearings before the Public Accounts Committee. Bureaucrats for some reason or other become terribly stubborn about a position and seek to use the Parliament to justify the position they have taken. This is exactly what is happening in this instance. It happened to the man named Duncan. That is a clear example that those in charge of the administration of the fund for the armed Services have refused to do justice to the people concerned and, in spite of the investigations and findings of various committees, they have refused to accept those findings and have sought by legislation to have their own way. This is what has happened in this instance. I suggest to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that the amendment which now of course has little chance of being agreed to because the Democrats have taken such a--

TALK.START.PARA: —Wobbly stand.

—The word that comes to mind is 'foolish' and I will have to use it. For that reason I do not think there is any chance of there being the numbers to support the amendment. In any case, I think the amendment is worthy of support and I trust that the Government will accept it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak on the second reading of the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Amendment Bill to raise a particular matter, if I am permitted, which is of concern to the defence forces of Australia and of great concern to all of the members of the defence forces of Australia, that is, the practice of the bureaucrats to withhold moneys owing to discharged members of the forces. In some cases DFRB payments, payments in lieu of accrued leave and payments of various sorts are withheld for considerable periods to the great embarrassment of those who have given service to this country and who have sought and obtained their discharge.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) that the crux of this matter is whether in fact the Commonwealth should be entitled to behave like a private debtor by holding money back in case any is owing in return. What occurs is that these payments, in many cases amounting to hundreds of dollars and in other cases some thousands of dollars, are withheld against the possibility that some debt had been incurred by the member who has been discharged and against the possibility that, for example, stores for which a member has been responsible have not been returned. However, the crux of the matter is whether, in fact, the Commonwealth ought to be entitled to act like a private debtor. In principle, I regard this action on the part of a public authority as improper. The Commonwealth appears to be able to get away with it because legal action to enforce entitlements takes longer than it takes for payment to be made in the normal course of events. Quite frankly the Minister may point to the Defence Act. Section 12 states:

Any person who has been a member of the Defence Force may after having ceased to be a member recover from the Commonwealth by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction any moneys which under his engagement or by any agreement with the Commonwealth are due to him.

Of course, that power really is thwarted by the fact that the length of time it would take for the serviceman to avail himself of that provision in the Act would exceed, in most cases, the length of time that the money is withheld. If pay is withheld to ensure recovery of money other than that authorised by statute or regulation then it is being held for an illegal purpose. The Air Force Regulations and the Air Force Act are quite specific in regard to this. I quote section 136 of the Air Force Act, which states:

(1) The pay of an officer or airman of the regular air force shall be paid without any deduction other than the deductions authorised by this or any other Act or by any Air Force Regulation for the time being.
That is one example. There are similar provisions in Acts relating to other arms of the Services. Air Force Regulation 529A provides:

Except as provided by these Regulations, or any other regulations under the Act or under the Act and any other Act or Acts, salary, allowances, gratitudes and rewards payable to a member of the Air Force in respect of his service shall be absolutely inalienable prior to their actual receipt by the member, whether by way of or in consequence of an assignment or charge, or an agreement to assign or charge, or otherwise.

In fact what actually is occurring now by dint of a decision by some bureaucrats is that the pay is withheld as a matter of course, and that is being done illegally. It is being withheld for an illegal purpose. The fact that it is being withheld in anticipation of a liability, the identity of which is not yet known, only adds to the dubiousness of the practice. However, adequate remedies are not available. If money had been withheld to acquit a debt an ex-serviceman could sue for that pay after ceasing to be a member. In fact, as I mentioned before, he could sue in reference to the Act. He would succeed and the Commonwealth would have no defence. Its position would depend on its ability to counter-claim for its alleged debt. But as I mentioned before, the rights of the serviceman under the Act are thwarted by reason of the fact that the time that legal action would take would exceed the ultimate pay-up time determined by the bureaucrats.

What the Services are saying in effect is: 'You might owe us some money. Whether you do or not we have not as yet determined. Therefore, we will withhold a sum against that contingency. We will not sue you to recover any subsequently discovered alleged debt, we will simply deduct it from the money we withhold. If you do not agree you must sue us'. That is the principle of might is right. It does not go down at all well with the servicemen of Australia. As I mentioned, there is no legislative authority for Defence to withhold money from servicemen's pay. An argument advanced is that the protection given by legislative authority to the servicemen ceases to apply to discharged members. Of course, that argument is absurd because its corollary is that if a serviceman has incurred a debt then that debt too ceases on the discharge of the member. In fact, that sort of argument by the bureaucrats would fall to the ground.

The bureaucrats hold that withholding is lawful; at least I presume they do. I have not heard them state that. That is based on a completely incorrect interpretation of some recent legal advice which I will not table before the Parliament. If the Minister wants he can have the information given to the Department by the Acting Assistant Crown Solicitor. The advice itself is subject to review because of conflict with the opinion of the Attorney-General (Senator Durack). On this occasion I agree with the Attorney-General's opinion. The action has been taken simply to avoid the inconvenience and expense of proving debts in courts of law and recovering any proven debt in accordance with the law. Those most affected are those who have either served long enough to accumulate furlough entitlements or who have been unable-usually through pressure of work-to exhaust their recreation leave entitlements before discharge. In fact, the system is unjust and an abuse of bureaucratic power. I apologise for grasping this opportunity to speak but I hope that this practice, having been exposed, will now cease. I intend to keep my eye on it. The servicemen of this country are entitled to the protection of the law. They are entitled to the protection of this parliament. The action that has been taken by the bureaucrats does in fact affect more seriously those who have served this country for many years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a proposed amendment to the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Scheme which in itself is a relatively new scheme introduced some years ago to replace a former scheme which had a number of deficiencies. The problem that this Bill addresses arose out of an interpretation by the Federal Court of a provision of the scheme dealing with the effect of acting rank on entitlement to pension benefits. The new scheme was not understood to provide any special additional benefits for those on acting rank; retirement benefits being determined by reference to substantive rank. However, interpretation by the court of the particular provision was to the contrary.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is designed to restore what was understood by the Government-I understand also by the Services-to be the nature of the scheme. The amendment is not one dreamed up and put forward by bureaucrats-the word being used in the somewhat pejorative sense in the debate here-but it is an amendment supported by the Services as well; Service chiefs have supported it.

The Opposition has moved an amendment which would extend a rather extraordinary benefit to those temporarily holding higher ranks. Such persons, having served in a temporary position, would qualify for a permanent benefit. Having listened to Senator Mason and Senator Georges speak to the Opposition's amendment, I must say that Senator Mason understands it far better than does Senator Georges. Indeed, he pointed out very effectively the difficulties that the Opposition's amendment would create. Whether or not the Opposition intended that those difficulties would be created, or that what Senator Georges has been advocating would happen, is something that Australian Labor Party senators may work out for themselves. It is not for me, the Government, the Australian Democrats, or any other senator to work out what the Opposition intended. The fact is that what Senator Georges understood the amendment to do is not borne out by what the amendment says.

Not only would the passage of the amendment create anomalies; it would also cause untold, incalculable increases in the costs of the scheme. It is typical of the Opposition to propose amendments without any regard whatever to the burden on taxpayers. We saw, when the Australian Labor Party attempted to govern, the mess to which it brought the country. The attitude that the Opposition has adopted today shows clearly that it has no understanding whatever of the burdens that such a course would impose on the taxpayers of this country. The Government does not accept the amendment. Indeed, Senator Mason has very effectively given reasons why it should not be accepted. I need not add to or repeat them.

Senator Harradine has raised another matter altogether. Obviously, it is one of importance. Unfortunately, I had not been appraised of it and cannot respond to it now. However, I am concerned that certain action taken in this area might not be in accordance with legal rights. I will certainly have the matter investigated and provide Senator Harradine with an answer as soon as I can. I hope that the Senate will give the measure a speedy passage.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMPANIES AND SECURITIES LEGISLATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 September, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill is an omnibus Bill which makes amendments to the various Acts which have been passed in the implementation of the National Companies and Securities Co-operative Scheme-a Scheme which has been so widely trumpeted by the Government and its various apologists as the greatest innovation in company law ever to occur in Australia. I suppose to some extent that is accurate. But that it is accurate is a measure of the minimal achievement we have regrettably so far made in this particular area. The Scheme in question, of course, involves the National Companies and Securities Commission Act and the four constituent codes associated with it-the takeovers code, the Securities Industry Act 1980, the interpretation code embodied in the Incorporations and Securities Interpretation and Miscellaneous Provisions Act 1980 and the companies code embodied in the Companies Act 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the companies code before the States introduce their own respective companies application of laws Bills, the State Bills being the only ones now required to be passed in order to implement the entire scheme of legislation. In this respect we note however with some dismay the recent announcement by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities at its meeting on 25 September that the introduction of the uniform companies legislation has been deferred yet again and will now not be operative until 1 July 1982, if indeed even then. The speed with which these deferment decisions are made, by contrast with any other kind of decisions, is indicated by the fact that it was only as recently as 10 September that the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) in his second reading speech was still saying that the latest operative date for the introduction of the code was 1 January 1982. But now it is July 1982 and on past experience it could well be stretched yet again.

We deplore all those delays and we deplore the further delays that are embodied in this decision because, quite apart from anything else, they are symptomatic of the whole cumbersome, clumsy character of this national exercise in so-called co-operative federalism. The reason for the delay-to have 'a three-month general examination' of the legislation and to allow public comment on it-simply does not stand up to any kind of close scrutiny. The Ministers were also quoted as having agreed at their Council meeting that the deferral arose 'because no States had put the Bill to their respective parliaments'. Those quotations are from a report in the Australian Financial Review of 28 September. If the only reason for the deferment of the code is that no State has yet got around to implementing the legislation, what kind of charade is it that we are witnessing? To what extent will there be co-operation in this so-called co-operative enterprise if the constituent units engaged in that co-operative enterprise cannot even be relied upon to co-operate sufficiently to pass their own enabling legislation to get the legislation up? Our question, which we have to go on asking on these occasions, is: How much longer can this charade go on? What was the real reason for the deferment? I will be fascinated to get some better and further details from the Minister in his reply.

If the reason for the deferment was in fact to secure more public scrutiny or to enable more consultation with the public, that simply defies credibility, since the Companies Act 1981 was only finally enacted after a very lengthy period of such public consultation-in fact, after two separate exposure drafts being promulgated. While we, of course, regard the process of public consultation as being highly desirable in itself, before any major legislation of this kind is enacted, we have to make the point that much of that process so far has been unsatisfactory insofar as it has allowed a disproportionate weight to certain sectional interests, particularly organisations of directors and accountants. So much is visible from the results of the public scrutiny and the reform that has been implemented as a result of it so far.

I am afraid that we cannot believe that any further substantial movement in the improvement and the quality of this legislation will be gained by more public exposure at this stage. To be realistic, the few expert company lawyers and the few energetic company secretaries who will ever get on top of this legislation-not to mention the even fewer parliamentarians who have the faintest idea of what it is about; I only very barely place myself in that category and I doubt whether anyone else would approach this enormous legislation with very much more confidence than that-will gain anything more by the extension of the process at this stage and will simply experience a greater frustration at having to relearn it all and redeal with it all when the legislation comes into operation in July 1982. What is more, as the Minister said in his second reading speech, members of the Ministerial Council have already agreed among themselves that during 1982 there will be no substantive amendments to the initial legislation. Any further process of public consultation, exposure for comment or reanalysis of the legislation will not matter a tinker's damn when it comes to the actual initial text of the legislation in the form in which, it is hoped, it will get off the ground.

We were told by the Minister, again in his second reading speech, that there is some prospect that the process of implementing substantive reform in this area will commence in 1982, with the prospect of legislation to amend the companies code being implemented in 1983. To the extent that that is so, comment at this stage would clearly be inappropriate and irrelevant to that exercise and even more so to the immediate task in front of us, which is to get this companies code off the ground. I suggest that what we are confronting here is simply another classic demonstration of administrative political inertia. It is the kind of inertia which has characterised all the decision makers. I exempt only the handful of them who have been associated with this enterprise from its outset. It is exactly the kind of inertia that we can expect and go on expecting so long as we insist on operating our national companies and securities legislation in the Heath Robinson fashion that is involved in this co-operative scheme rather than having single national legislation.

If the real reason for the deferral yet again does not have anything to do with further public comment and consultation or improvement of the legislation, as seems certainly the case, and if the real reason is simply the failure of the States, for one reason or another-I will come to some of those in a moment, particularly as far as Queensland is concerned-to pass the enabling legislation, that demonstrates once again in a nutshell, as I have already suggested, that this kind of co-operative exercise is the slowest way of getting even minimal law reform in an area that has been crying out for it for decades. The whole process simply bogs down in the complex and laborious grinding legislative machinery which is characterised-or perhaps caricatured-as co-operative federalism.

The amendments in the Bill are very lengthy but none of them amount to very much at all so far as substantive effect is concerned. It is for that reason that, although we take the opportunity of the introduction of this Bill to make a number of points about the progress of the so-called co-operative scheme, we do not seek in any way either to amend or to object to the text of the Bill that is now before us. We do take the occasion, however, to remind the Senate that we have been pressing not only for the kind of things that are embodied in the second reading amendment, to which I will refer in a moment, but also for a series of substantive reforms in the subject matter of company law. We identified what at least 16 of those major reforms were in a second reading amendment moved to one of the earlier parts of this legislative package on 28 May 1981. I believe those matters deserve repetition at this stage but, in order to avoid trespassing unduly on the patience of the Senate at this late hour, I seek leave to incorporate the text of that proposed set of amendments in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(1) Expresses its concern-

(a) at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974-the Rae report,

(b) at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament, and

(c) that despite the inordinate delay in introducing the legislation, the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not been given an opportunity effectively to scrutinise this Bill and associated Bills and will not be able effectively to determine company law in the future under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme;

(2) Calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which the Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies;
(3) Notes that this Bill places uniformity before reform in deference to powerful vested interest groups and represents a retreat to the lowest common denominator standard of company law;
(4) Calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board; and
(5) Calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law, including:
(a) the abolition of the category of 'exempt proprietary company' and the privileges associated with it,

(b) the provision of statutory directions and powers to the National Companies and Securities Commission and the courts to look behind the corporate entity in appropriate circumstances, to ascertain those who control it or hold shares in it, and, having regard to the purpose of the creation of the corporate entity and the manner of its control, to affix personal liability and adjudicate personal rights where it is just and equitable to do so.
(c) the extension of the powers of inspection of the National Companies and Securities Commission to ensure the fullest reasonable access of the Commission to books,
(d) the amendment of any provision which enables questionable practices to be hidden by means of legal professional privilege,
(e) the requirement for all companies to raise and maintain a perscribed minimum nominal and paid up capital,
(f) rationalisation of the cumbersome provisions in respect of company names on the basis of single nation-wide registration,
(g) a requirement that dividends be paid only from the genuine profits of a company,
(h) full review of the provisions relating to fund raising and prospectuses to ensure maximium disclosure and to require independent valuation of assets exchanged for issued shares,
(i) reform of the provisions relating to companies financing dealings in their own shares, including the removal of the exemption given to financial assistance to salaried directors,
(j) provision for a higher required standard of competence, care and diligence for directors and officers of companies,
(k) a requirement that more frequent accounts be lodged by companies listed on the Stock Exchanges,

(l) in order to protect creditors and to assist the prevention of tax avoidance, the imposition of stringent disclosure requirements upon companies acting as trustees of trading trusts, in relation to their capacity as trustees and the accounts of the relevant trusts, and the imposition of heavy penalties for non-compliance,
(m) full disclosure to the public of the beneficial ownership of all shares in companies,
(n) published accounts to include full details of each director's and officer's remuneration and right of inspection for employees and shareholders of director's service contracts,

(o) adequate remedies for oppressive conduct, including extension of the concept of oppression to single and anticipated acts unfairly prejudicial to a shareholder, and provision of further means such as 'Shareholders' Tribunal' to protect the interests of minority shareholders, and
(p) complete reform of the winding up provisions, including greater protection for unsecured creditors, following a reference on insolvency to the Australian Law Reform Commission'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The big question that has to be now confronted, of course, is just what the future of this co-operative scheme is going to be. As I have foreshadowed, we take the opportunity that is provided by this legislation to put down on the record once again, hopefully with some prospect this time of its actual passage through this chamber, a second reading amendment which states in short and succinct compass what we regard as the basic deficiences of the co-operative scheme and what we think ought to be done about implementing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me indicate what the second reading amendment is. The first matter of concern that we express our indignation about is:

. . . the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 (the Rae Report);

Here I simply interpolate that certainly the Opposition has never wanted to give absolutely carte blanche endorsement to everything in that Rae committee report of 1974, but we certainly support, and always have supported, its basic thrust as far as the need for national legislation is concerned, that is, legislation pursuant to the Commonwealth's constitutional powers under section 51(xx) in relation to corporations, together with a miscellany of other supporting powers in the areas of banking, insurance, communications and interstate trade. We have always argued-I will not repeat the argument because we have made it at greater length on earlier occasions-that were there the will to implement national companies and securities legislation, there is a constitutional way to do so.
I return to the text of the amendment that is proposed to the Senate tonight. The second matter of concern is this:

. . . the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament . . .

The point being made there, which I will pick up again later in my response to this Bill, is that, where a commission such as the National Companies and Securities Commission is accountable or responsible to a number of different governments, the reality is that such a system means accountability to no one. That was amply demonstrated in this year's Budget with its one-line appropriation with no details being given. That can create real problems, not only for the democratic process but also for the organisation itself.

The third matter is the Parliament of the Commonwealth has not been given an opportunity to effectively scrutinise Bills introduced under the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme and will not be able effectively to determine company and securities law in the future under this scheme;

There are a number of points we want to make about that, not least being the failure of this Parliament to be given any opportunity to scrutinise in advance the kinds of amendments that are proposed for consideration by the Ministerial Council. Before they go to that Ministerial Council, decisions are made which become faits accompli and which it is impossible for this Parliament or any other to do anything about.

The amendment, in a further separate paragraph, paragraph (2), states that the Senate calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which the Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies and the securities industry.

We will support, as we have indicated on previous occasions, the setting up of this scheme, cumbersome and impossible as it is in so many ways. But we make clear our view yet again that, if that scheme breaks down, as we believe it inevitably will-I will give chapter and verse for that dire foreboding later in this speech as far as Queensland in particular is concerned-we believe the Senate ought to express its view that the Commonwealth immediately then assume its national constitutional responsibility.
Paragraph (4) reads:
Calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board . . .

That is perhaps one of the most important single elements in the original proposed package which has so far been omitted from anybody's attention but which is crying out for legislative implementation, or at least administrative implementation. Finally, paragraph (5) calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law and, as the first stage in such reform, to institute the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee without delay.
Once again, in that respect, the experience of the history of the non-establishment of that Companies and Securities Law Review Committee has been an absolute shambles.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate for that demonstration of confidence in the merits and fascination of my speech making. If the Government thinks that it can, by this performance tonight of negativing the adjournment motion, somehow advance the cause that it so obviously and crudely is promoting of creating a situation in which the Senate can, in fact, get up within the next three weeks, it is fooling absolutely nobody. Let it now start adjusting itself to the proposition that we will be sitting here for weeks and weeks yet, and every day that we are sitting here we will be causing the embarrassment to the Government that it so obviously is anxious to avoid.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now return to the subject matter before us tonight, which is the future of the co-operative companies and securities legislation. The basic point which needs to be made, and which is articulated in the second reading amendment which I have just been summarising, is that this scheme is simply not built on sure foundations. Clause 51 of the formal agreement establishing the scheme provides that any party to it may withdraw at any time on a year's notice being given. We have recently seen signs of strain in the operation of this scheme, particularly in the State of Queensland. Let me mention two illustrations in particular of what I have in mind. The first is the situation that arose in the context of the proposed takeover of Rothwells Outfitting Ltd by Walter Reid and Co. Ltd. In the Australian Financial Review of 26 August this year it was reported that the Queensland Attorney-General, Mr Doumany, had protested to the National Companies and Securities Commission about its having overridden a decision of the Queensland Corporate Affairs Office in this respect. The newspaper report of the telex of Mr Doumany stated:

. . . this is a co-operative scheme and that unless the commission is prepared to co-operate in the scheme I must express grave doubts about Queensland's continued willingness to co-operate in the scheme.

The kind of scarcely veiled threat involved in that telex and the whole matter associated with it highlights the kind of tension which a co-operative scheme of this kind inevitably generates. It purports to give the States a role in legislating and administering but in order to work effectively and uniformly the States are in fact progressively frozen out. They have to be if it is to work in that way. The experience of this scheme already shows the need for a single line of responsibility; a single parliament which can effectively scrutinise the legislation, instead of none having that capacity; a single Minister who is responsible to that parliament instead of, as at the moment, no single Minister with that responsibility; and a single regulatory body which does not have to depend on co-operation from State corporate affairs commissions and in the process have to avoid treading on toes but which can control its State agencies and can operate speedily through them.

As I will come to again in just a moment, the Opposition applauds the performance of the National Companies and Securities Commission to date for the speed and the decisiveness of its action as well as for its admirably clear promulgation of policy and of guidelines for the exercise of discretion. Only if the NCSC can be freed from the kind of shackles that seem inevitably likely to be its lot as this co-operative scheme, both in its legislative and administrative sides, grinds on can we be confident that we will be able to be quite so laudatory in our reaction to it in the future.

The other matter concerning Queensland that needs to be drawn to our attention tonight is another statement of Mr Doumany, the Queensland Attorney-General, which is reported in the Age of 26 September 1981 in the following terms:
. . . Mr Sam Doumany has been working hard to quell Queensland Liberal Party fears that the uniform code would leave Queensland companies vulnerable.

Those fears seem to relate to the relative ease of takeovers under Queensland and Commonwealth legislation. Of course the uniform takeovers legislation is now in force. Whatever the precise reason may be for these particular fears there was a suggestion that the uniform companies code would be delayed in Queensland and Western Australia. If that sort of thing is going to happen, it raises again all the old spectres of disuniformity which bedevilled the so-called uniform companies and securities industry Acts which used to be in operation, which were inaugurated in the early 1960s. The only proper way of dealing with this sort of situation to ensure that there will not be that sort of disuniformity in the future is for there to be a single Commonwealth legislation governing the situation.

There are a couple of other aspects of the second reading amendment that deserve particular attention. One of them is the question of accountability, and the lack of accountability of the NCSC the way the situation is structured at the moment. I make it clear, as I have already, that in making these points about lack of accountability of the NCSC I am not making any points about lack of confidence in the capacity of the NCSC to do its job properly and effectively. Nor are we saying anything at all about the extent to which the independence of a body such as the NCSC ought to be prejudiced by being subject to overriding ministerial directions. The point we are wanting to make about accountability is a much more straightforward one than that. Before I go on to that I want to make the point, because I think it is important for this kind of confidence and respect for the NCSC to be a guiding theme in our deliberations whatever other criticism we might make of the way the situation has been going, that the reaction of the business community to the operation of the NCSC has so far been very favourable.

It is an attitude that is shared by the Opposition. We take the view that the Commission has intervened speedily and effectively in several takeovers where the market had not been informed and it has used its powers under the security industry legislation to suspend trading and declare conduct unacceptable under the takeovers legislation. We simply hope that the challenge to which the NCSC is now being subjected in the Northern Mining Corporation N.L. v. Endeavour Resources Ltd case presently before the courts will not in fact prove to limit the kinds of powers which it has been exercising so far. But in order for it to go on exercising those powers effectively, not the least of its needs will be more staff, and not only staff but also very highly qualified staff. In that respect I draw attention to what was said by Mr Tony Greenwood of the Commission, again reported in the Age of 26 September, who said that the funding problem would inhibit the NCSC's watchdog role unless there were some very substantial increases in this respect. The report states:
Mr Greenwood said that there was 'little doubt that in 1978 there was the expectation that the commission would be actively engaged in national investigation work'.
Then he is quoted as saying:
But, unless there are significant changes to funding and staff in the next year or so, then that is not the way the commission is going to develop.

That is very cautious and very diplomatic language, but the message is very loud and very clear. This is the context in which I make the point and use it to characterise the point about the lack of accountability in the sense of direct lines of responsibility between the NCSC and this Parliament, or indeed any other, because so long as we have a situation of joint responsibility for the affairs of the NCSC and joint accountability coming back from the body to various governments and not just one, we will have a situation of continued buck-passing by the governments in question with no single government being prepared to bite the bullet on the funding and other decisions that have to be made to ensure the successful operation of a body like this. In this respect I think the point is graphically made when one looks at the Budget appropriation for the NCSC this year. The 1981-82 Budget, just as its 1980-81 predecessor, contains simply a one-line appropriation for the NCSC. This year it is $1.3m. There was not made available to the Parliament any detailed breakup of this amount nor was any detail offered to the Estimates Committee in the initial stage of its deliberations when the budgetary appropriations were being scrutinised and some attempt was being made to find out what was going on in the NCSC such as: What its staffing was like; what its funding was like, how its funds were allocated between particular functions, and what the needs of the organisation were if it were to operate on a cost effective basis for the future. Even worse than that, it was explained to the Committee-this is recorded in the Hansard of 21 September this year at page 354-as follows:
. . . the Commonwealth Government is reluctant at this stage to put forward to you details of the expenditure because at this time the Ministerial Council has not yet approved the NCSC estimates.

We were confronting then a situation in which the Commonwealth Parliament was to be expected to approve an appropriation for $1.3m without any knowledge of the manner in which that appropriation was likely to be spent. Without belabouring the point any further than that because it is a point that will be made quite strongly in the report of Estimates Committee A to the Senate when it is introduced tomorrow, let me simply state that that is a classic example of exactly the phenomenon we are talking about in that paragraph in the amendment which refers to the lack of accountability of the NCSC to any government or any parliament in the nation. That is an inherent problem that arises when we try to stitch together an important reform through a co-operative, clumsy exercise of this kind.

The final point I make specific mention of is paragraph 4 of the second reading amendment in which we call upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law, and as the first stage in such reform to institute the companies and securities law review committee without delay. This has been an absolutely extraordinary saga so far as this proposed ongoing law reform body in the company law area is concerned. Clause 21 (2) of the formal agreement of December 1978 contained clear commitments by the Ministers participating in that agreement to establish a companies and securities law review committee to do various things which are set out in that paragraph-to carry out research into and essentially to advise on law reform in relation to the legislation and regulations associated with it. That there is a huge law reform task to be conducted in this area as distinct from just a codification of the existing law is made evident by the list of necessary reforms, or some of them, which I incorporated in Hansard earlier this evening. I formally move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate-
(1) expresses its concern-

(a) at the Government's abdication of its responsibility to make national laws for companies and securities pursuant to the Commonwealth's own constitutional powers, and in accordance with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Securities and Exchange in 1974 (the Rae Report);

(b) at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or Parliament of the Commonwealth, or to any other single elected Government or Parliament; and

(c) that the Parliament of the Commonwealth is not given an opportunity to effectively scrutinise Bills introduced under the Cooperative Companies and Securities Scheme and will not be able effectively to determine company and securities law in the future under this scheme;

(2) calls upon the Government in the event of the breakdown for any reason of the scheme, of which this Bill is a part, immediately to proceed to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies and the securities industry;
