(3) calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board; and

(4) calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law and, as the first stage in such reform, to institute the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee without delay.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the amendment moved by the Opposition. We do so because it will not delay the passage of this legislation. There is no doubt that the companies and securities legislation is long overdue and has been seriously delayed. It was promised by 1 January this year, and we are now well into the year and still it has not passed through the Parliament. I believe the Senate is to be commended for sitting into the late hours of the evening in an effort to pass the Companies and Securities Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981.
—That is a matter of opinion.

—Well, we are concerned about some of the points that Senator Evans raised. Certainly the co-operative approach that has been adopted by the Government creates very serious problems. We would much prefer national regulation of companies, as was recommended by the Rae Committee of Inquiry into Securities and Exchange. Of course, the States objected to that approach, and objected very strongly, so perhaps the Government cannot be blamed for trying this co-operative approach. The amendment that has been moved very clearly calls upon the Government, in the event of a breakdown of the scheme for any reason, to proceed immediately to the introduction of Commonwealth legislation for the national regulation of companies. We are very pleased that there is a prospect of this amendment being passed and that that attitude will be incorporated in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to refer to only one other aspect of the amendment. The Opposition in paragraph (1) (b) states:

expresses its concern-at the lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission to either the Government or the Parliament . . . or to any other single elected . . . Parliament

It is our view that the National Companies and Securities Commission should be very much a free-standing body along the lines of the Australian Taxation Office. It should not have any direct interference from governments. We believe that the proper way in which to regulate the Commission would be through the courts.

If it is decided that the Commission should have less discretionary power, the proper course of action would be for the Government to introduce legislation restricting that discretionary power. We do see that, in one very important area, certainly too great a discretionary power is given to the Commissioner. I refer in particular to the area of the acquisition of companies. The law states that the Commission has to decide whether conduct in that area is acceptable. Surely clearer guidelines for the Commission to operate under should be laid down. We are saying, in effect, that there has to be less discretionary power. The discretionary power of the Commission is already too great.

Having clarified that point, I believe it is not necessary to go over the six or seven aspects of the proposed amendment. We support the proposed amendment, particularly its last two paragraphs. The second last paragraph of the proposed amendment 'calls upon the Government to expedite the establishment of an Accounting Standards Review Board'. That is long overdue. The last paragraph of the amendment 'calls upon the Government immediately to pursue a fundamental reform of company law and, as the first stage in such reform, to institute the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee without delay'. We cannot emphasise those two vital points too strongly. Mr Deputy President, we support the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will commence and perhaps finish my remarks by addressing myself particularly to the amendment moved by the Opposition, for which the Australian Democrats have indicated their support here tonight. There are a number of matters which honourable senators should consider before a final vote is taken on this matter. Firstly, I think I should outline the very clear definition of the philosophy of the Government in its approach to this matter. Without labouring that point too much, I think it is clear from what was said in previous debates that have occurred in this place over the last couple of years that the Government's philosophical approach is one of co-operative federalism, to work within the powers of the States and the frameworks of the States which have already been created in order to institute an effective system of control over companies.

SPEECH.PARA: Just one example of the kind of point I am trying to make is the very point which Senator Evans made in addressing his remarks to section (1) (b) of his proposed amendment, regarding the 'lack of effective accountability of the National Companies and Securities Commission'. It relates to that Commission's powers, its staffing and its ability to do the job. The point I make is that, through the very system which we are creating in our co-operative approach to the matter, we will in fact be able to utilise the powers, the staff and the facilities of the corporate affairs commissions in the various States. Of course, that aspect was incorporated in the legislation enabling the creation of the National Companies and Securities Commission. Section 46 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act provides for that.

That is a substantial aspect in terms of the powers and abilities of the Commission to get on with its job and to make sure it is effective in regulating companies throughout Australia. Honourable senators should bear in mind that those State commissions have a vast body of experience, ability and information concerning the operation of companies which has been accumulated over a long period. Consequently, I think the point which Senator Evans sought to make falls to the ground when one considers the very considerable powers that lie within the scope of the National Companies and Securities Commission in determining those issues. That clearly demonstrates the importance and the power of the Government's approach. It demonstrates that in fact the single-minded approach which the Opposition is proposing and which the Democrats are supporting really is the wrong approach to adopt in this kind of legislation. In fact, we have vast bodies of information, power and staffing at our disposal within the State organisations and they ought to be used for the benefit of the people of Australia in the proper way. The Federal Government is supporting this federal approach, this co-operative approach, in such a way as to maximise its opportunities to control companies. It is my belief and the Government's belief that the approach which as been outlined by the Opposition would in fact lead to a weakening of the powers of the Commonwealth. I hear no comments from Opposition senators so I take it that my points are hitting home.

I think it is important to recognise that the National Companies and Securities Commission will be responsible to the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities. We know that the lines of communication are somewhat longer than what one might expect. Nevertheless the Ministers who sit on that Council are directly responsible to their Cabinets and parliaments in respect of the operation of the Commission. Of course, reports by that body will be tabled in both Houses of this Parliament and in the State parliaments.

In paragraph 1(c) of the amendment the Opposition makes the point that the Parliament of the Commonwealth is not given an opportunity effectively to scrutinise Bills introduced under the co-operative companies and securities scheme. We, of course, have to consider what has gone before. We have seen the very effective community consultation that has occurred in the last few years in this regard over the various pieces of legislation that have come before this Parliament. There has been full co-operation at all levels between the States and the Commonwealth and with the general community. In addition to that, there has been a very high degree of consultation between the Government with its back bench through its own committees and with the Opposition through its various committees. I understand that the same courtesies would have been extended to the Australian Democrats had that party wished to seek full briefings in respect of this legislation. I think that those matters are of great importance.

We know that the whole scheme has taken a considerable number of years to get into operation. In fact it has taken some five years. We are now at a stage where the scheme is almost in place. Is Senator Evans suggesting seriously that we should discard all those years of effort in trying to--

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not saying that.

—Certainly the honourable senator's earlier comments gave us that kind of indication. That attitude is one that the Government would not support. The Opposition's amendment also calls upon the Government, firstly, to expedite the establishment of an accounting standards review board and, secondly, to pursue a fundamental reform of company law and establish a company and securities law review committee. Might I say that both of those matters are presently before the Ministerial Council.
—See what your Minister said on--

—I am advised that this is the situation. These matters are likely to be discussed again at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council before the end of the year. In relation to the wider matter concerning reforms, I understand that the Ministerial Council will in fact be considering and exposing draft legislation in that respect for consultation with the committee in the second half of 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to the final point which I suppose is the major point that Senator Evans sought to make during his speech-that is, the delays and deferment that have occurred over the last year or two and in particular the deferment which is now occurring whereby the legislation will not come into force on 1 January 1982 but rather 1 July 1982. Naturally enough, I think it is of fundamental importance at this time that we give the scheme every chance for success. In fact, the States will need to ensure that their clients-that is, the companies in those States which are signatories to the agreement-are represented on the Ministerial Council, have access to the legislation, are made aware of its provisions, and have every opportunity to make themselves fully aware of the conditions and provisions of the law so that this proposal gets off to an effective start. After five years of effort to get this legislation into place, to rush it through at the last minute, to cause ill feeling in the community and perhaps some misunderstandings which might denegrate that law in the minds of the public generally seems to me to be the wrong approach. Rather, we should take our time to ensure that the States are properly in place with the proper amount of consultation and a full understanding by the community. For those reasons, the Government rejects the amendments moved by the Opposition and wishes the legislation a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Evans's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me take just two minutes of the time of the Committee to make one point about this complex and lengthy Bill which deals with a variety of issues. This is an ample demonstration of the need, particularly if it were to deal with more substantive matters than this one does, for an ongoing companies and securities law review committee of the kind that I was referring to at the end of my remarks at the second reading stage when I was so rudely interrupted by the bell. In that respect let me add one thing so far as the Government's attitude to this sort of thing is concerned. I think an absolutely extraordinary statement was made the other day by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Moore, when this very question of the honouring of the obligation to establish such a review committee was raised. In the House of Representatives on 23 September 1981 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: As for a continuing law review committee, I could think of nothing worse than to have a group of people sitting continually to think up new ways to amend the Companies Act and associated matters. If one sits down and creates a job for someone that person is bound to think up something . . . It is incomprehensible to me, a simple country lad, to understand why we need such things.

For that kind of remark to be made by a responsible Minister, reacting to the agreement of this Government with every other government in the nation-the Maroochydore agreement-to establish such a committee, is to demonstrate not just the attitude of a simple country lad but something much worse. Indeed, it is a blot on the reputation of simple country lads for anyone to make a statement of that kind. No lad from the country or anywhere else could be so simple, unsophisticated and obtuse as to make that statement when the system of companies and securities legislation is in the condition that it is.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be as brief as I can. I raise a subject that, according to the newspapers today, the Australian Medical Association thinks unsuitable for public debate. I raise the matter because I am concerned that it has been a matter of unchallenged public debate for some time. In an attempt to reduce the length of my speech and so that I do not have to quote at any length, I indicate to the Senate that I am referring to an article in today's Australian newspaper headed 'The operations that may well be unnecessary. Challenge to womb removals'. I seek leave to have the article incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The operations that may well be unnecessary
CHALLENGE TO WOMB REMOVALS
By Sue Cook
At least half the medically insured women in Australia can now expect to have their wombs removed surgically-but at what price?
The Doctors Reform Society says a great many such operations are unnecessay, precipitate more physical and emotional problems than they solve and waste millions of dollars of taxpayers' money.

The society claims some predatory members of the medical profession are benefiting from the minimum of $280 they charge for perfoming a hysterectomy and which takes most gynaecologists only 30 to 40 minutes to perform.

New statistics from the NSW Health Commission show more than 80 per cent of all hysterectomies in Australia are performed on privately insured patients, according to Dr Brian Learoyd, a former NSW president of the Doctors' Reform Society and chairman of a seminar on unnessary surgery held at the University of Sydney last week.
He says Australian women are experiencing a rate of hysterectomy on a par with American women, but had the operation twice as often as British women and four times as often as Swedish women.

A leading obstetrician and gynaecologist, Professor Derek Llewellyn-Jones, said it was unlikely there were great differences in the physiology and hormonal patterns between Australian women and British or Swedish women.
He said hysterectomy had become fashionable among Australian surgeons, perhaps because of the system of medical payments. There was no financial incentive for doctors to explore the alternatives.
Both the Australian Medical Association and the General Practitioners' Society in Australia deny the claims by the Doctors' Reform Society of 'overwhelming' evidence of unnecessary surgery.

The NSW spokesman for the General Practitioners' Society in Australia, Dr Hal Soper, said the claim was ridiculous and hysterectomy was, above all, the operation of comfort and liberation for troubled women.

He said all surgery was initiated by the patients' complaints. The general practitioner then comfirmed whether surgery was necessary by investigation and surgical opinion. In doubtful cases further opinion was sought.
Dr Soper said the society wanted an urgent public debate on unnecessary surgery with the Doctors Reform Society.

The AMA has told the Doctors Reform Society it does not think the subject is suitable for public debate but obviously it is concerned by the continuing allegations. The association announced last week two surgical audits to look into the claims. One of these is being conducted by the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists into hysterectomies.

A detailed examination of 100 cases in each of 20 hospitals will take place in each State in both public and private hospitals. The Doctors' Reform Society said the most alarming revelation of the new N.S.W. statistics was the ''gross and continuing'' disparity between the numbers of hysterectomies being performed on private patients and public patients.
High Rate
The audit will study cases where the womb was removed for reasons other than cancer.

Dr Learoyd said the AMA was intent only on ''re-discovering the wheel or motherhood''. He said the N.S.W. Health Commission statistics confirmed the continuing high rate of hysterectomies performed in at least N.S.W.
The figures showed privately insured patients were almost three times more likely to have a hysterectomy or a curettage-the scraping of the womb for a pathological diagnosis.
''The money is continually getting in the way of proper clinical and ethical consideration of the patient's best interests,'' he said.
''Women are being frightened and pressured into hysterectomy.''
More than 50 per cent of women in N.S.W. with medical insurance would have a hysterectomy at a current annual cost of $20 million.
Dr Learoyd said there had been an ''alarming'' increase of 50 per cent in diagnostic curettage rates between 1978 and 1979-now more than twice the U.S. rate and four times the British rate.
''We think these figures are disturbing, alarming and convincing,'' said Dr Learoyd.
''What responsible professional medical bodies should be doing now is clamoring for some redemptive action.''

He said many studies showed surgical rates could be reduced by as much as 50 per cent if a second opinion were sought. Every major Australian teaching hospital should have second opinion clinics where the patient could go free-of-charge.

Dr Learoyd said he was horrified by the recent Federal Government decision to increase the surgical bed day subsidy for private hospitals. This would be an incentive to many to perform unnecessary operations.

Professor Llewellyn-Jones, associate professor of obstetrics and gynaecology at Sydney University, said he was not advocating that hysterectomies should only be performed where there was a malignancy.
''What I am concerned about is the woman who sees her doctor on Monday and is told she must have a hysterectomy on Thursday,'' he said.
''She is being pressured into having an operation without the time for reflection.''
He said there was a tendency among the medical profession to take short cuts and fall back on old training which told them if the organ was removed the symptoms would disappear.
Curettages used to be performed 15 years ago to cure bleeding disorders, but Professor Llewellyn-Jones said he could see no cause now for anything but a diagnostic curettage.

A diagnostic curettage is done either to determine the nature of the endometrium, the lining of the womb, so appropriate treatment can be clearly defined; to exclude the presence of endometrial malignancy; or, on a lesser scale, to establish whether ovulation has occurred in some infertile women.

When a hysterectomy is performed the ovaries may also be removed. If this is done to a woman whose ovaries were functioning she will experience marked menopausal symptoms. Professor Llewellyn-Jones said although these symptoms could be treated with artificial hormones, where the ovaries could be left they should be.
Questions

Apart from malignant disease of the uterus, hysterectomies were done when the woman had fibroids-non-malignant muscle tumors which distort the shape of the uterus. Professor Llewellyn-Jones said that was a tendency for gynaecologists because of their training to say to the woman she was better off having her uterus removed. But he believes women should be offered a choice and be involved in making the decision.

He said hysterectomy for birth control was not very common in Australia, but doctors in the US suggested women who were going to have their tubes tied as a permanent method of birth control should have a hysterectomy instead to prevent later complications.
He said the major reason for the different hysterectomy rates between Australia and Sweden and Britain was the number of hysterectomies being performed on women with menstrual disorders.
A number of questions had to be answered to explain the different rates.

Professor Beverley Raphael, professor of psychiatry at the University of Newcastle, conducted a study in which 194 women were interviewed immediately after having a hysterectomy. They were followed up after 13 months and a smaller group were seen again four years later.
'Hysterectomy is an extremely risky procedure for certain women because it appears to precipitate psychiatric problems in them,' said Professor Raphael.
'Doctors recommending women for hysterectomy must recognise this risk of impairment in their patients and counsel them very carefully prior to any final decision to proceed with hysterectomy.'
In some studies 20 per cent of women who had had a hysterectomy complained of significant health impairment and depression afterwards.
Professor Raphael's study found that, of the women seeking to have a hysterectomy, 36 per cent were already having psychiatric treatment.
She said if gynaecologists became more adept at recognising existing psychiatric problems in their patients the rate of hysterectomies could be reduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that this is a matter of public debate. I also indicate that I do not wish to debate in any detail the morality or the medical pros and cons of the operation in question. I raise the matter because the Doctors Reform Society has raised an issue in relation to the performance of what it has called unnecessary surgical procedures and a point it wishes to make in relation to private hospitals. The point I make is simply that it is an issue worthy of debate by our medical fraternity and by society. I ask the Doctors Reform Society and others to pick some other example.

SPEECH.PARA: It is extraordinary that on all the times this issue has been raised-it has been raised a number of times in the last two years to my positive knowledge-this is always the example given. It is raising a fear in me, as I am sure it is in many other women, that we are about to move back into the dark ages in relation to surgery on women. I would feel a lot happier about the debate if a less emotive type of surgery was the point at issue. I remember well the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden, being interviewed on television some time ago on the allegations he had made about unnecessary surgery and the effect it was having on medical payouts by the Commonwealth Government. When asked by the interviewer what type of procedure he was referring to, Mr Hayden specified only hysterectomies. Undoubtedly, Mr Hayden had been given some advice-one would expect some well-informed advice-on the subject and that was why he nominated it. I am sure it did not come to him alone; somebody had suggested to him that this was a surgical procedure which may be being performed unnecessarily. However, it is indicative that it is the only surgical procedure that Mr Hayden raised on that occasion. It is indicative that in this article about operations that may well be unnecessary it is the only surgical procedure that is referred to. It is indicative that in referring to a conference on unnecessary surgical procedures where certain of the statements reported in this article were made this is the only surgical procedure reported in the newspaper. It is not unreasonable therefore to conclude that that was the only surgical procedure raised.

It is not so long ago that it was believed-I cannot vouch for its truth but it was certainly the belief of a number of people in the medical profession and a number of the members of the community in Queensland-that there was an attitude on the part of public hospitals there that the performance of a hysterectomy on a woman under the age of 40, that is under what is accepted as child bearing age, would not be performed unless there was reason to believe that there might be a malignancy of the uterus. In other words for any reasons other than potential death by virtue of malignancy, public hospital space would not be available. That was a blanket attitude, as I understand it. It is not surprising, therefore, that a large proportion of these operations are carried out in private hospitals. There are other reasons that this could happen as well. It could well relate to the general financial situation of the women who will take something that is elective surgery but elective in the sense that it is not a question of life or death.

I am disturbed by the use of the term 'unnecessary' because nobody tries to define what is 'necessary' or 'unnecessary'. It certainly is not defined in this article. I hope the Doctors Reform Society, the Australian Medical Association, the General Practitioners Society and anyone else who joins this debate will be very careful about their definition of it. Recently the Commonwealth Government abolished medical benefits for certain plastic surgery procedures on the grounds that it was unnecessary surgery. I do not know on what advice it did it. I can only assume it was on internal advice and on the basis of personal prejudice of certain individuals. Following that decision the Government had to modify the ruling it had made and had to acknowledge that there were forms of plastic in the category specified which were deemed necessary. So we have to be very careful with this term 'necessary'.

I would just say also that if we are going to start talking about necessary surgical procedures we really do need a very careful definition and one that will apply to surgical procedures for ingrown toenails, the removal of the appendix, the removal of tonsils and adenoids and whole range of other areas where surgical procedures do not strictly have to be performed when one talks about life or death and in that sense are elective. But elective is not the same thing as unnecessary. I mention plastic surgery because I believe there was quite a lot of prejudice brought to bear in the decision on that issue and I certainly believe that the public reaction and Press reaction when dealing with it was based on personal prejudices which run something along the lines that people who have plastic surgery are vain and vain people do not deserve to have any sort of assistance with their surgery. Of course, doctors claimed-it was recognised subsequently by the Government-that it was not just a matter of personal vanity and concern with personal attractiveness that led to that sort of surgery; but it was prejudice. The thing that women fear, from people just harping on this one type of operation when talking about unnecessary surgery, is that basic prejudices are being operated on.

It is not very long ago that there was a basic community prejudice about hysterectomies and that was a prejudice that had a very profound effect on a number of women who had the operation. It is relevant to mention that matter because some reference was made to the psychiatric effect of the operation on women who have it performed on them. It was not very long ago that women who had hysterectomies kept very quiet about them because they feared what people would think about them if they knew they had had that sort of operation. They feared they would be believed to be unfeminine, that they would be unattractive to men and that they were somehow unnatural women because they had had that sort of operation. That is an absolute nonsense, of course. It is the same sort of nonsense that has led men, through a sense of machismo for some time, to believe that if they are not fertile then they would be believed to be not virile-a big difference. It was a matter of shame for many women because of community attitudes, or what they perceived to be community attitudes, that they would not allow it to be admitted that they had had this operation. Given those very deeply ingrained fears it is not surprising that there were strong psychiatric reactions.

I cannot analyse in any detail the sort of psychiatric things that are referred to here. As I said, I do not want to go into a lot of analysis on that operation. I just say that, given that sort of psychiatric reaction, it is very dangerous, for instance, for the Doctors Reform Society or anyone else to be singling out to try to prove a matter of general principle about whether there is too much surgery which is not necessary being performed by doctors in private hospitals, or, for that matter, in public hospitals. I just beseech the Doctors Reform Society that if they want to take this issue up seriously, for the sake of the peace of mind of many women, to please seek another example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perform a phimosis, maybe.

—Doctor, you would be the expert. I will allow Senator Baume to make his personal recommendations to the AMA and the Doctors Reform Society. They cynics among the feminist movement would specify some masculine type operation which might be more appropriate but I do not even suggest that. I suggest that on a matter as delicate as this, one should move right away from anything that could raise basic instinct, prejudice, phobias, whatever, among the community. Please allay my fear and, I am sure, the fears of a lot of women that there will be some sort of social pressure against this operation which is performed for a wide range of reasons including physical health, even if it may not necessarily be the actual life of the women concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to take the time of the Senate. I have instructed the Whip that I will take 10 minutes. I think I will be less. Senator Martin has covered most of the things that I wish to say on the subject except that I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the heading of this entire article which states, 'The operations that may well be unnecessary' and then in large capitals states, 'Challenge to womb removals'. The very first paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: At least half the medically insured women in Australia can now expect to have their wombs removed surgically-but at what price?

I have to question whether the Doctors Reform Society actually knows how many women are medically insured in Australia. If it does would it have made such a stupid statement? Senator Martin has already spoken about the profound effect on women of articles of this nature and the effect that a general discussion around this whole subject has on women who have had the operation. I simply point out that it has also a profound effect on women who need the operation. Because of this type of article they then decide that they will not go on and so their health in actual fact suffers because of it. Some outrageous statements are made in the whole article that need some response. For instance, it is suggested that there is no financial incentive for doctors to explore alternatives to the removal of the womb, that doctors are more concerned with reaping the financial benefits of the $280 minimum than looking at the alternatives. I think that is such a crazy statement as not to be worth while responding to. The Australian Medical Association and the General Practitioners Society deny the claim of overwhelming evidence of unnecessary surgery. I have to raise the question: Who says that it is unnecessary? Who determines that the pains, the cramps and the excessive bleeding suffered by a woman tell her that it is unnecessary for her to have the operation. Her doctor can only go on the evidence that is provided to him by the patient. Does he say: 'Look, put up with this. It doesn't matter. It is an unnecessary operation and you don't want to have it.' Surgery is, in the main, initiated by patient's complaints and the manner in which they are described to the doctor. The article suggests that women are sheep who go along to their GP who says: 'My dear, you need a hysterectomy' and the woman immediately says: 'Of course, I do'. It is suggested in the article that a woman will go along to see her doctor on Monday and have a hysterectomy on Thursday. I dispute that. I do not know of any woman who would go along to a doctor on a Monday and who, without thought or consultation, would go into a hospital to have major surgery on the Thursday to have part of her internal workings removed purely and simply because a doctor has told her to. Surely if a doctor says: 'You need this type of operation' one of the first things she would ask him is: 'What is the alternative? How much is it going to cost? How much time am I going to have off from work?'.

I suggest that with the greater portion of women in Australia already in the work force it is extremely difficult for them, particularly if they come from low income families, to say: 'I am going to take three months off work to allow me to have this totally unnecessary operation'. But they will find that in time, if they are convinced by their own ill health, that it is a necessary operation. I have not yet met a woman who has had a hysterectomy who has said that it was unnecessary. Women do not want to go through half of their lives feeling unwell. If they are working wives or working mothers they have to be fit to cope with the pressures applied to them in their normal day to day living. They need to feel well and it is their determination whether they need the operation; not the determination of the Doctors Reform Society, the Australian Medical Association or the General Practitioners Society. The woman herself, on medical advice that she receives and from the symptoms that she indicates she has, determines whether she will have such an operation.
Thursday, 15 October 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two members of my family have had hysterectomies, one as an emergency for torsion of fibroids and one for cancer. Both of them have no doubt that they were benefited by the operation. I am sure honourable senators who have contributed to the debate tonight would agree that it would be quite wrong to allow a situation to develop in the community in which people denegrated the effect of this or any other surgical procedure. Sexism in writing or reporting is not only real but it also can be made even more real to some beholders, particularly if they have a sensitivity about these things. It is not made easier by some attitudes which have persisted in society for a long time.

SPEECH.PARA: Hysterectomy comes from the root 'hyst' which refers to uterus. There is a disease called hysteria which, by definition, in the nineteenth century was alleged to be a disease that only women could suffer. At one stage the treatment was the removal of the uterus. Times do change and attitudes do soften. I think honourable senators are correct to say they do not want stereotyped views and they do not want sexist views advanced on a whole range of matters. What is at issue in public at present is the whole question of the high technology imperative as it applies to therapeutics. That is not only surgery but also pathology, consultations and diagnostic procedures-all the things which involve value judgments and where a decision to intervene has significant effects for a consumer. It may have significant effects for a provider of services as well. In a funny way this applies in other kinds of service areas; it applies in terms of legal services. A decision to intervene or not to intervene, to act or not to act, has significant effects. One could just as much want an examination of legal services, accountancy services or motor car repairs-in each of those areas where there is a value judgment whether to do or not to do some procedural matter which has significance for a consumer. The inquiry proposed by the Australian Medical Association in fact will examine some of the factors and some of the facts in society to provide a basis on which professionals can understand better the basis on which they make a number of professional, often value, judgments, I think as honourable senators have pointed out.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have said that value judgments are sometimes above the navel; that is all we are asking for.
—I understand that. I am moving beyond that. I am just saying that the issue being studied is not just about hysterectomy but about interventions generally in the area of therapeutics. I need to be--

—The claim is made in this article that more of these operations are undertaken in private hospitals. I suggest to you that one of the reasons why that is so is that people who use public hospitals cannot afford to have this type of operation.

—Can I come to that point? I need to be convinced that the incentive to intervene in medicine, surgery or diagnostics is lesser or greater in public or private hospitals, one than the other. Unlike other senators, I, of course, suffer from the disability that I worked for 20 years in a public hospital and in consulting practice. I am aware of the technological imperative as it exists. It is a fairy story to say that one part of the area is non-interventionist and one is interventionist. It is just not right. I will be interested to see the figures when they emerge. This is why I value the kind of survey that has been proposed. My impression, from having worked in public hospitals, is that intervention is the order of the day. As a consulting doctor in one of the public hospitals, the greatest difficulty I ever had was to convince the staff who reported to me that they should do nothing; that they should be prepared to keep their itchy fingers off a patient and neither investigate nor treat but just wait. It was the one thing they could not do.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate my support for the idea of evaluation-in fact, in this case, self-evaluation. You, Mr Acting Deputy President, have had an interest through the Senate committee on which you served in the question of evaluation in health and welfare services. The fact that it is being done as a self-evaluation exercise by one of the learned professions is something which I think reflects well upon the profession. If it can in a non-sexist way, without stereotyping its patients, without selecting just one operation, come to some of the answers then I think society will be well served. I agree with the main thrust of what my colleagues have suggested tonight and just hope that this will not be a stereotyping exercise but that the positive results which I am emphasising can be achieved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 12.7 a.m. (Thursday)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

(2) Are there specific requirements regarding bank to bank guarantees on the availability of funds for the project.
(3) What commercial checks are made by his Department on applicants to the CSFF.
(4) Is information supplied either directly or indirectly from Dun and Bradstreet on such applicants.
(5) What checks are made to ensure that all commercial information supplied is correct.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I assume the honourable senator is referring to the Consulting Services Feasibility Study Fund (CSFSF) and on that basis provide the following answers to his questions:
(1) The guidelines for the CSFSF are a set of published criteria which I have approved for the use of an interdepartmental committee which advises me on use of that Fund. They are as follows:
GUIDELINES FOR EXAMINING PROPOSALS FOR USE OF THE CONSULTING SERVICES FEASIBILITY STUDY FUND
Purpose

1. The purpose of the Fund is to assist the development of the export of services provided by Australian consultants. It is designed to assist Australian consultants in the preparatory stage of development projects in developing countries by the provision of funds for pre-feasibility or feasibility studies which can be used for an application for the funding from other sources for the further stages of the project. It is expected that the involvement of an Australian consultant at the early stages of the formulation of a development project will enable that consultant to gain exposure, knowledge and a track record in a developing country. It could also produce opportunities for obtaining follow-on work for Australian consultants as well as for Australian contractors and suppliers.

The Fund is not regarded as an extension of the Australian aid program but as a trade promotional scheme to assist Australian consultants to develop their activities overseas. Authority for financing a study under the Fund is given by the Minister for Trade and Resources upon the recommendation of an interdepartmental committee which assesses proposals after taking into account the relevant aspects of the guidelines, including the flow-on benefits that may be generated, and the funds available.
Definitions

2. A consultant is a person or entity which provides consultancy services on the basis of a fee for service. There should not normally be any other commercial relationship between the consultant and the entity for whom the services are performed. A person or entity carrying out an investigation or study relating to a future investment by that person or entity to obtain an economic benefit would not normally be regarded as a consultant for the purpose of the Fund.

3. An Australian consultant is a consultant which carries on business in Australia. Carrying on business in Australia means having a headquarters organisation and associated facilities in Australia, not merely a registered office or accommodation address. If the firm is a partnership the majority of the partners must be residents of Australia. If the firm is organised as a company Australian residents should have effective control of the company and generally its ownership should be Australia.
4. The term resident or resident of Australia means:
(a) A person other than a company whose domicile is in Australia.

(b) A company which is incorporated in Australia or which, not being incorporated in Australia, carries on business in Australia and has either its central management control in Australia or its voting power controlled by shareholders who are residents of Australia.

5. A developing country is a country, territory or province eligible for Developing Country Tariff Preferences as set out in the schedule of developing countries eligible under the Australian Customs Working Tariff.

6. A feasibility study means a preliminary survey and/or investigation to determine the technical feasibility and/or economic viability of a project including where appropriate rough estimates of capital outlay and costs of production and an indication of methods to be used in implementing the project. Such a study should provide sufficient information to be used as the basis for an application for funds from an appropriate financing agency.
7. A pre-feasibility study is an initial survey undertaken to determine whether a project appears likely to be viable and would warrant the carrying out of further studies.
8. Design development or detailed project design or the preparation of specifications for a project are not considered to be pre-feasibility or feasibility studies.

9. A development project is a project which is included in or related to the recipient country's development program or activity. Generally a study should be made for the Government of the recipient country, for example, for a ministry, government department, statutory authority or an organisation in which the recipient Government has a substantial interest, or for an intergovernmental lending agency.
Finance for the project
10. Studies financed from the Fund are to relate to development projects to be financed from:

(a) Intergovernmental lending agencies of which Australia is a member for example Asian Development Bank, World Bank and the UN Development Program. Where this is not the case the sources should be identified and acceptable.
(b) Australia, including funds available through EFIC's export finance facility and the bilateral aid program.

11. Where the source of funds is from within the country itself or from other countries, an assurance should be provided that Australian organisations would not be precluded from bidding for further work because of conditions attached to the supply of the funds.
Finance for the study

12. A contribution to the total cost of the study should come from the consultant and from the entity requiring the study in the developing country concerned. For the purpose of assessing a possible contribution from the Fund all services to be provided by the consultant shall be offered at cost. In assessing the adequacy of the contribution from the consultant the IDC will take into consideration the costs already incurred by the consultant, the costs which are necessary for successful completion of the study, the possible costs of follow-up of the recommendations made and the level of direct flow-on benefits if any to the consultants which are likely to occur within a reasonable time of completion of the study. The contribution from the developing country should generally be in the form of the supply without charge of local assistance to the consultant, e.g. access to local information, counterpart staff, local transport, field assistance, office accommodation and similar facilities.
Role of the trade commissioner

13. The project should be reported upon favourably by the appropriate Australian Trade representative in the country concerned after taking such steps as are necessary to enable him to make a recommendation on the request for a study. These steps would include consultation with the appropriate government departments and planning bodies in the country concerned including the entity for which the study is to be made. Liaison should also be maintained through the appropriate mission with the Development Assistance Representative (or his equivalent) to ensure the earliest possible separation of studies to be carried out under the Fund from those which will be handled under bilateral aid.

14. In particular, advice from the Trade Commissioner or other Australian representative will be sought regarding the status of the proposed project in the country's development program, the likely source of funds for execution of further stages of the project and any other information which might assist the IDC in its deliberations.
Initiation of a study
15. Studies for consideration for financing from the Fund may originate:
(a) from individual Australian consultants or a consortium of consultants;
(b) from the Department of Trade and Resources.
Procedure

16. Proposals for funding will be initially examined by the Department of Trade and Resources to determine that they are in fact proposals for the conduct for pre-feasibility studies or feasibility studies by Australian consultants for development projects as defined in these guidelines. To assist the Department in coming to a decision with regard to eligibility for funding, consultants should provide the information set out in the attachment. The Department should also obtain a report from the Trade Commissioner as envisaged in paragraphs 13-14 including an indication as to whether the proposal has the support of the recipient Government.
17. Before deciding whether to recommend the funding under the CSFSF of a study the Department of Trade and Resources should take the necessary steps to be satisfied that:

(a) the project is one which is included in or related to the particular country's development activity. Where the project involves a significant financial contribution from the Fund the recipient government should certify that the study is of high priority in their development program.
(b) the consultant's proposal contains sufficient information to enable the IDC to consider the proposal.
(c) the body for whom the study has to be made is likely to obtain the necessary funds for the project should the study indicate that it is viable and feasible.
(d) if it considers it to be necessary, the lending body concerned does not lay down any special conditions inconsistent with the purposes of the CSFSF.
(e) there will be an appropriate contribution for the study from the consultant and where appropriate from the Government or entity in the recipient country.
(f) the consultant has appropriate experience and is able to substantiate its capacity and ability to carry out studies in the field of expertise in which advice is required.
(g) the consultant has actively demonstrated its interest in undertaking overseas commissions.

(h) the consultant would be acceptable to the government of the country in which the study is to be undertaken and to the international lending authorities which could be involved in financing further phases of the project.

In order to satisfy itself regarding the above the Department of Trade and Resources may contact the appropriate authorities and lending institutions to clarify or substantiate any aspects of the consultants proposal that it considers may be necessary.

18. Should the Department of Trade and Resources consider that there is a prima facie case that the project is eligible it will submit it to the Interdepartmental Committee which will examine it and if appropriate make a recommendation to the Minister for Trade and Resources.

19. In particular cases the IDC may take into account other special factors or considerations that may be applicable and that have not been specified in the guidelines. It will also bear in mind factors such as the relevance of the study to Australia's trade and other relationships with the recipient country, the availability of funds and any other studies that have been made or are under consideration.
20. Notwithstanding paragraphs 17, 18 and 19 compliance with these guidelines does not imply an obligation on the part of the Government in relation to any proposed study submitted for consideration.

21. For studies initiated other than by a consultant or consortium of consultants, the Department of Trade and Resources will prepare a list of suitable invitees in consultation as appropriate with a technical department. This list will be considered by the Interdepartmental Committee along with the Department's recommendation in relation to the study. If the decision is taken to proceed, the Department of Trade and Resources assisted by the technical department will be responsible for selecting an appropriate firm and submitting a recommendation to the Minister for Trade and Resources regarding acceptance of the study.

22. When a proposal for a study has been approved, the Department of Trade and Resources will enter into a contract with the consultant specifying the terms and conditions for the study. Generally the contract will provide for progress payments and a final payment on completion of the study. Where a clear case can be made for establishment costs, an initial payment may also be made. The contract will contain a clause indemnifying the Commonwealth against any actions which may be brought about by default or negligence of the contractor. The contract will also include the following conditions concerning the consultant:
(a) He shall not purport to represent the Commonwealth in any connection with the conduct of the study, nor act on behalf of, nor bind the Commonwealth in any respect.

(b) The consultant shall not use any of the documents produced for the study, nor publish any material obtained from or as a result of the study, without the approval in writing from the Commonwealth.

(c) The property and copyright in all documents and other data arising from the study will be vested in the Commonwealth up to the stage at which documents are forwarded to the beneficiary client in the overseas country.
(d) The property and copyright in all documents arising from the study will become the property of the Government of the beneficiary client once the documents have been forwarded to that country.

23. The Department of Trade and Resources will normally request an appropriate technical department to certify satisfactory progress of the work and that the study has been carried out to completion in accordance with the provisions of the contract.

24. The contract will specify how and by whom the study report is forwarded to the beneficiary client. Normally this will be either that the final report will be delivered to the Department of Trade and Resources who will forward it to the beneficiary client, or that the Department of Trade and Resources, on the advice of its technical adviser Department, will certify that the final report is satisfactory and request the consultant to forward the report in the consultant's own name.
Department of Trade and Resources
CANBERRA
28 August 1980
INFORMATION TO BE INCLUDED IN PROPOSALS PUT FORWARD BY CONSULTANTS FOR STUDIES TO BE FINANCED FROM THE FUND
In order to enable a study put forward by a consultant or consultants to be considered for financing from the Fund firms should provide the following information:
details as to the reason for the request for the financing of the study from the Fund and how the proposed study fits into the firm's overall marketing strategy.
type of project, location, client, overall cost of the project and approximate value of study being sought
relevance of proposed project to country's development program and information on whether the project appears sound and likely to be taken further if the current study proves positive

graphic work plan indicating the proposed time input by each of the proposed study personnel
relevant information including CV's on proposed project leader and key personnel involved

specific details of relevant experience and other facts which substantiate the capacity and ability of the applicant to undertake the study in question together with a summary of the firm's promotional efforts in the export field
details of counterpart services including an estimated value to be provided by government of recipient country
the possible/probable source of funds for the implementation of the project
detailed breakup and estimated value of possible commercial benefits which could follow on for Australia

information on the part to be played by any Joint Venture operation which the applicant may be associated with in the country where the study is to be implemented and whose services are planned to be used.
Department of Trade and Resources

(2) No. However sections 10, 11, 17 and 19 of the Guidelines are relevant.

(3) The Department of Trade and Resources takes appropriate measures to comply with section 17 of the above guidelines. This includes checks on whether consultants who submit proposals have appropriate experience and are able to substantiate their capacity and ability to carry out studies in the field of expertise proposed and involves contact with previous clients, professional organisations and public authorities and, if necessary, request for clarification from the consultants themselves. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: When was the first 'gentlemen's agreement' concluded in relation to the Loan Council and what was the text of that agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Between May 1929 and February 1936 inclusive, the Australian Loan Council adopted a number of resolutions concerning borrowings by semi-government and local authorities. These resolutions were first brought together in consolidated form in May 1936 and thereafter became known as the Gentlemen's Agreement.
The text of the 1936 Agreement was as follows:

(a) All loans issued by authorities constituted under the laws of the Commonwealth or a State (in cases where the authorities propose to raise in any one year #100,000 or more) shall be subject to the authority of the Treasurer of the Commonwealth or the Treasurer of the State concerned (as the case may be) as to the amount, terms, and time and place of issue.

(b) Each Treasurer shall, in respect of each financial year, submit to the Loan Council the programme of borrowing of semi-governmental authorities under his control which propose to raise in that year #100,000 or more, and such borrowings shall be considered in conjunction with the loan programme of the government concerned.

(c) Such loan programmes of the semi-governmental authorities shall cover the total proposed borrowing for a complete financial year, and any approvals granted by the Loan Council for those borrowings shall, if not availed of, lapse at the close of the financial year concerned.

(d) The amount, terms and time and place of issue of each semi-governmental loan in cases where semi-governmental authority proposes to borrow in any one year #100,000 or more, shall be fixed by the Treasurer concerned, in consultation with the Chairman of the Loan Council who shall consult the members of the Loan Council before giving his decision.

(e) All proposed overseas loans, of whatever amount, by semi-governmental authorities, shall be submitted by the Treasurer concerned to the Chairman of the Loan Council, who shall, in the first place, consult the High Commissioner in London, and then submit the proposal to the members of the Loan Council for decision. In the event of the Loan Council giving approval for definite negotiations to be entered into for such a loan, the negotiations shall be conducted through the Chairman of the Loan Council and the High Commissioner and the terms of the loan and the brokers through whom it is to be issued shall be subject to the approval of the Loan Council.

(f) Brokerage at a rate not exceeding 5/-d per cent, and underwriting commisson at a rate not exceeding 7/6d per cent, may be allowed in respect of semi-governmental borrowings. Where higher rates are contemplated, the matter is to be referred to the Loan Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What has been the effect of the decision by the Government to charge market rents on community service organisations using or seeking to use Commonwealth properties.

(2) Do part of the problems of establishing a child care centre by the Commonwealth Clothing Factory in Gaffney Street, Coburg, Victoria, stem from the as yet unspecified amount the proposed centre would have to pay for rental of the land on which the centre is to be built.
(3) Is it appropriate to have funds from the Office of Child Care allocated for Services in the community to be paid to another Commonwealth Department in the form of market rents.
(4) Has this situation led to a Canberra program, the Noah's Ark Toy Library, being displaced from A.C.T. Schools Authority property as they had no funding to pay rent to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The effect of the decision has been to make Government support for community service organisations identifiable as part of a particular support program and not as a hidden subsidy through concessional rentals. Organisations receiving support must therefore seek additional funding through the appropriate Government program.

(3) While I have outlined the Government's policy in respect of charging market rentals to community service organisations occupying Government owned space in (1) above, the honourable senator may wish to address this question to the Minister for Social Security.
(4) No. The Noah's Ark Toy Library continues to be accommodated in Schools Authority space at Yarralumla Primary School.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 29 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What role has the Industrial Relations Bureau (IRB) played in examining the industrial conduct of Rank General Electric at Enfield, New South Wales where workers were sacked at ten minutes notice.
(2) What redundancy payments were offered to the dismissed workers.

(3) On what grounds did the company repudiate an earlier promise made to the workers involved that redundant workers at Enfield would be placed in work at the Rank General Electric Blacktown (N.S.W.) plant.
(4) What were the final settlement terms arrived at and what unions were involved in the dispute.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau has informed me that:

(i) the Bureau is not empowered to, nor does it, examine the industrial conduct of employees or organizations if such an examination would be beyond the authority bestowed on the Bureau by the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904;

(ii) it is the policy of the Industrial Relations Bureau to initiate enquiries into industrial relations situations when complaints are lodged with it alleging breaches of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act or regulations or of federal awards, or when it otherwise appears to the Bureau that breaches have possibly occurred, or are likely to ocur;

(iii) the Bureau has investigated those matters relevant to its function which relate to the closure in April 1981 of the Rank-General Electric Major Appliances Pty Limited plant at Enfield in New South Wales and has concluded that the actions of the company did not constitute a breach of the Act, the regulations or of federal awards by which it was bound.
(2) The Department of Industrial Relations has been advised that the redundancy payments offered by the company were:
payment of one week's pay in lieu of notice, plus;
payment of one week's extra pay for one year of service;
40 hours payment for each additional year of service over one year;
payment for all accrued sick leave;
Payment for accrued annual leave (including pro-rata) plus 17 per cent annual leave loading;
Payment for all eligible paid long service leave entitlements under State Act-pro-rata after five years;
Payment of all superannuation contributions, including company contributions, plus interest.
(3) The company has denied to the Department that it repudiated a promise to transfer workers to the Blacktown plant, and claims that the unions were not prepared to discuss this issue.

(4) It is understood that the terms of the actual redundancy settlement were as outlined in paragraph (2), except that the payment for each additional year of service was increased from 40 hours to 48 hours. The unions involved were ASE, ASC & J, AMWSU, BWIU, ETU, EMWU and FSPU.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what ways will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so, how much is it estimated that it will save.
(3) In what way will those savings break down into component savings.

(4) Can the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the government more than would the same services provided from within the public services by salaried officers.
(5) If the Minister cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the government more money than they would save and if so what are the details.
(8) Has the Minister received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Consideration will be given to contracting work out to the private sector where:
the private sector can provide the services more economically and/or conveniently.

services of the type concerned are readily available from the private sector and the use of Commonwealth resources to undertake them would result in entry into needless competition with the private sector in those areas; or
expertise in a specialised technique or access to specialised equipment is needed and is readily and more economically available from the private sector.
Work contracted out will include the acquisition where practicable of computer software services and technical advice, printing, and trustee work associated with bankrupt estates.
No specific proposals to contract out work have yet arisen consequently no estimates of possible or probable savings have been made to date.

(3) In addition to direct staff savings from contracting out work, indirect staff savings would result from the decreased need for support services. Other savings would result from the reduced need to buy, repair and maintain capital equipment.
Portion of the savings would however be offset by the requirements for staff to prepare and supervise contractual arrangements.
(4) to (7) See answer to (1).

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Consultative Council on Social Welfare

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What were the major recommendations of the first annual report of the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare.
(2) How many of these recommendations have been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In its first report, the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare, which is an important source of advice on matters related to my portfolio, made many recommendations. The Government shares Council's concern on many of the issues covered by these recommendations, as evidenced by our continuing programs and recent initiatives in these areas.
The Council's major recommendations were that:
(a) family allowances and other payments to pensioners and beneficiaries for children be indexed,
(b) there be a greater differential in payments of family allowance for the fourth child,
(c) the sole parent rebate be increased from $417 to $597, that is the same as the dependent spouse rebate, at least in the case of sole parents having dependent children aged 0-6,

(d) at least $5 million per year be made available under the Homeless Persons Assistance Program for the next three years, and that the present staff salaries formula and the meal and accommodation subsidies within the Program be reviewed.
The Government has taken several initiatives in the areas covered by these recommendations:

(a) and (b) In the 1981-82 Budget the Government decided to increase from January 1982 the rates of family allowance for third and subsequent children by 50 per cent. In the 1980-81 Budget the Government also increased additional pension/benefit for children from $7.50 to $10.00 a week, and mothers/guardians allowance from $4 to $6 a week (from $6 to $8 a week where there is a child under 6 or an invalid child).
(c) In the 1981-82 Budget the Government increased the sole parent rebate from $559 to $580 a year.

(d) In September of 1980 the Government announced it would be allocating $10 million to a three year capital program for homeless persons, with special provision for homeless youth. $1 million in capital grants was approved in 1980-81 to immediately improve facilities and services. The balance of $9 million is being allocated to capital projects in a three year program which commenced this financial year. The Government has also reimbursed voluntary agencies $2.24 million for capital projects carried out with their own funds before the introduction of this program. A total of $6.3 million has been provided for the Homeless Persons Assistance Program this financial year. A related Government initiative in the 1981-82 Budget was the provision of $2 million this financial year for a crisis accommodation program for families.

In respect of meals and accommodation subsidies within the Homeless Persons Assistance Program, the Government increased the food and accommodation subsidy from 75 cents to $1.20 from 1 July 1980. The meal subsidy was also increased from 25 cents to 40 cents at that time.

The Council also made a number of other suggestions and observations relating to social welfare issues in its first report. The Government has taken initiatives in several of these areas too; for example, in its provision of funds for emergency relief since 1979-80 and by its introduction this financial year of a pilot program involving the appointment of ten paid agents with the aim of providing a better service to social security clients in remote areas.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What is to be the future of the Australian Legal Aid Office if the New South Wales, Tasmanian and Northern Territory Governments refuse the invitation, as recommended in the Review of Government Functions, to take over the office's functions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in my address to the Seminar held in February 1981 in Melbourne on 'Providing and Funding of Legal Aid', in the event that agreements cannot be reached with New South Wales, Tasmania and the Northern Territory, it will be necessary for the Commonwealth to make other arrangements for the delivery of its share of legal aid in these States because I am not prepared to perpetuate the conflicts which are inherent in the Australian Legal Aid Office system, namely those in relation to other legal aid schemes, and to the role of the Attorney-General and of the Crown, particularly in criminal proceedings.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many (a) adult males; (b) adult females; (c) junior males; (d) junior females; (e) total males; (f) total females and (g) total persons were unemployed at the end of May 1981 in the following towns, cities and areas: Atherton, Ayr, Brisbane, Bundaberg, Cairns, Charleville, Dalby, Gladstone, Gold Coast, Gympie, Ingham, Innisfail, Ipswich, Longreach, Mackay, Maryborough, Mt Isa, Nambour, Rockhampton, Roma, Sunshine Coast, Toowoomba, Townsville, and Warwick.
(2) What percentage of the appropriate workforce do the figures for 1 (a) to (g) above represent.
(3) How were the figures for 1 (a) to (d) and (2) determined.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics there were an estimated (e) 11,500 males; (f) 10,200 females and (g) 21,700 persons unemployed and seeking full-time work in the Brisbane Statistical Division in May 1981. Unemployment data disaggregated by adult and junior cross-classified by males and females are not available for the Brisbane area. The information sought in respect of towns, cities and areas other than Brisbane is not available.

(2) The figures provided in (1) above for the Brisbane Statistical Division represent the following percentage of the appropriate labour force: (e) males 4.1 per cent; (f) females 9.2 per cent and (g) persons 5.5 per cent.

(3) The source of the figures provided in (1) and (2) is the Australian Bureau of Statistical monthly labour force survey. For further details see the ABS publication The Labour Force, Australia-Catalogue No. 6203.0.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 2 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it true that large quantities of the chemical 2,4,5-T containing dangerously high levels of the impurity TCDD were imported into Australia via Singapore during the years 1969-70; if so, where in Australia was the chemical used-reference the epidemiological study being currently undertaken by the Commonwealth Institute of Health into the effects of defoliants on Vietnam Veterans.
(2) Does the control group in the epidemiological study include military personnel who, at the time of the Vietnam war, were declared medically unfit for overseas service.

(3) Does the control group include military personnel who served in Malaysia during the time of the Indonesian 'Confrontation' Campaign; if so, were any herbicides used in that theatre, and what type were they.
(4) Has the Army used any herbicides containing the impurity TCDD in Australia since the time of the Vietnam war; if so, (a) where; and (b) what type were they.

(5) Has the Minister given an undertaking to serving members of the armed forces taking part in the epidemiological study that their future careers will not be jeopardised by any information they may give to the study.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The records of the day do not allow data on 2,4,5-T imports to be separated from a number of other chemicals and no records were kept on TCDD levels.
(2) The medical status of veterans and controls at the time of the Vietnam conflict is currently being examined in order to establish comparability.

(3) The possibility of such service is being checked and is covered in one of the questions in the study questionnaire. I am advised that the Army is unaware of the use of any herbicides in the Malaysian Campaign.

(4) Inquiries with the Department of Defence indicate that the Army uses only commercial brands of insecticides and herbicides which are registered for use within particular States to control plants declared as noxious weeds by State authorities. Control measures implemented in June 1980 indicate that herbicides which contain the impurity TCDD have not been used since that date. It is possible that commercial herbicides which contain the impurity TCDD have been used on Army property prior to the introduction of these control measures. Such spraying programmes are conducted in conjunction with the Department of Housing and Construction or the appropriate State authority.

(5) All information provided to the epidemiological study which can be identified with a particular person will be treated as confidential and will be made available neither to persons not engaged in the study nor to Government Departments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 June 1981:
