QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What proportion of married couple families is represented by a husband with dependent wife and dependent children.
(2) What is this as a proportion of all families including married couple families (as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics).
(3) What is this as a proportion of all households.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Although there are no official statistics that will directly provide the information requested, data on characteristics somewhat similar to those sought by the senator were collected in a survey conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in July 1980, which provided the following information:
(1) The proportion of married couple families where there were a husband, wife unemployed or not in the labour force, and dependent children present was 31.2 per cent.
(2) The proportion of all families, including married couple families, where there were a husband, wife unemployed or not in the labour force, and dependent children present was 27.2 per cent.
(3) Not available.

Note: For more information concerning the scope of the survey, definitions, etc, reference should be made to the publication Labour Force Status and Other Characteristics of Families, Australia, July 1980 (ABS Catalogue No. 6224.0).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are recent reports that the United States intends to cut its foreign aid programs by $56 billion next year correct; if so, what impact will this have on Australia's requirement to contribute to multilateral institutions such as the Asian Development Bank.

(2) What has the Australian Government done, or what will it do, to persuade the United States to change its mind concerning this decision, which will have a disastrous impact on the poorest and more impoverished nations of the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Some time ago there was speculation that Unites States foreign aid would be severely curtailed in the 1982 financial year as a consequence of the budgetary cuts announced by the Reagan Administration. However, a cutback of the order of $56 billion as cited in the press report to which the honourable senator's question refers would not be possible, as the total amount of United States overseas development assistance was about $6.2 billion in the 1981 United States financial year.

On 17 September, the United States House of Representatives Appropriations Committee approved a foreign aid appropriations bill providing for $US7.59 billion for foreign aid in the 1982 financial year (October-September). This represents an increase of $US1.25 billion over the level which Congress finally authorised in the previous financial year. The recommended appropriation for foreign aid will be debated by Congress in the near future.

(2) As noted in the Minister for Foreign Affairs' response to Senate question no. 455 of 10 March, when the question of possible cuts in United States aid first arose, Australia, along with a number of donor and recipient countries, made representations to the United States authorities, urging that the negotiated contributions to multilateral development banks, such as the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank, be maintained. The United States authorities subsequently sought congressional authorisation for the amounts required, and this approval has now been given.

Uncertainties in the timing of United States contributions had given rise to concern about the commitment authority of the World Bank's concessional lending arm-the International Development Association (IDA)-and to ensure continuity in the IDA's activities Australia, along with most other donor countries, participated in a bridging arrangement on behalf of IDA by making an advance contribution of $67.8m in the form of an advance promissory note.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Can the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs advise how many foreign marine scientists are currently employed in Australia; if so, what is the number and if not, why does the Minister not have information on the number of foreigners working in various occupations in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is not clear what information the honourable senator is seeking in referring to 'foreign marine scientists . . . currently employed in Australia'.
If he is referring to marine scientists who are not Australian citizens the information is not available.
Migrants approved for permanent settlement are free to choose their employment. Like other Australian residents, they are not obliged to notify changes in the occupations they choose to follow.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the conditions of eligibility for special benefit.
(2) What income test is applied to those who apply for special benefit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The conditions of eligibility are laid down in Section 124 of the Social Services Act. Under these provisions 'the Director-General may, in his discretion, grant a special benefit under this Division to a person-
(a) who is not in receipt of a pension under Part III or IV, a benefit under Part IVAAA, an allowance under Part VIIA or a service pension under the Repatriation Act 1920-73;
(b) who is not a person to whom an unemployment benefit or a sickness benefit is payable; and

(c) with respect to whom the Director-General is satisfied that, by reason of age, physical or mental disability or domestic circumstances or for any other reason, that person is unable to earn a sufficient livelihood for himself and his dependants (if any)'.

(2) The Social Services Act does not specify an income test in relation to the payment of special benefits. However, Section 125 of the Act provides that 'The rate of a special benefit payable to any person shall be such rate as the Director-General, in his discretion, from time to time determines, but not exceeding the rate of the unemployment benefit or the sickness benefit which could be paid to that person if he were qualified to receive it'.

In considering whether the discretion should be exercised to grant a special benefit, regard is had to the financial circumstances of the claimant. In cases where the claimant is caring for a person with an independent income, or where his entry to Australia was subject to a maintenance guarantee under the Migration Regulations, regard may also be had to the financial circumstances of the person cared for or the person who gave the guarantee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there an acute housing shortage amongst Aboriginals in the Townsville area, which is forcing Aboriginal people to take refuge under Victoria Bridge and in the Townsville public toilets; if so, what does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs intend to do to provide shelter, and ultimately to provide permanent housing, for these people.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I know that there is a housing shortage in the Townsville area and am aware of the problems faced by homeless people in Townsville and other urban centres. Last financial year some 30 homes were provided in the Townsville area for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island families through my Department's grants-in-aid program and the welfare housing program administered by the Department of Housing and Construction. This year another twenty-one houses are to be built or purchased in Townsville through the Aboriginal Development Commission's grants to housing associations and the welfare housing program of the Department of Housing and Construction.

I understand that the Department of Social Security has recently approved a grant to the Aboriginal and Islander Community Health Service in Townsville to establish a night shelter for the homeless, which will cater for up to forty people. In addition, Aboriginal Hostels Limited owns and operates a hostel for transients in Townsville and finances through its third party program another hostel for supporting mothers and children.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do Government funded interpreter services exist in areas where there is a large non-English speaking migrant population.
(2) Is it correct that no such services exist in Alice Springs or Darwin where there are large non-English speaking Aboriginal populations.
(3) Does such a public service for Aboriginal people operate anywhere in Australia; if not, what does the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs intend to do to rectify this disparity.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A telephone interpreter service is run by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(2) No. A telephone interpreter service operates in Darwin, but it does not include Aboriginal languages.

(3) The Government has supported the provision of interpreter services for Aboriginal people through organisations involved with Aboriginals. Funds were provided by my Department in 1980-81 to support such services in the Summer Institute of Linguistics, the Institute for Aboriginal Development in Alice Springs and the Aboriginal Medical Service (Perth).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are reports of widespread prescription of the drug Depo Provera as a contraceptive in Australia correct.
(2) Will the Minister for Health initiate a national inquiry into the use and safety of Depo Provera with particular emphasis on its use amongst Aboriginal women.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Minister for Health, I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Available information does not indicate 'wide-spread' use.

(2) No. The product information for Depo Provera contains a warning that it has not been approved for use as a contraceptive and such use is investigational since there are unresolved questions relating to its safety for this indication. In addition I would draw the honourable senator's attention to the answers given to Questions 1203 and 1202 (House of Representatives' Hansard of 26 May and 10 June 1981).

A prospective study on the safety of Depo Provera as a contraceptive is under way in New Zealand, with Australian representation on the Peer Committee supervising the study. Through this representation and with the co-operation of the manufacturer of Depo Provera, my Department will be informed of the on-going results of this study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Prime Minister aware of recent criticisms of the Public Service by Sir Lennox Hewitt in which he said it had descended into being a 'debauched system'.

(2) Does the Government agree with his criticism; if so, what steps are to be taken to return the Public Service to the high levels of integrity and competence that existed before the present Government came to power.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have seen a Press report to that effect.
(2) I do not agree with the reported criticism.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the problem of gathering information on foreign investment and investors in Australia in order to obtain a factual basis on which to assess the extent and effects of any foreign investments; if so, will the Treasurer consider the re-establishment of the Foreign Participation Section of the Australian Bureau of Statistics abolished in 1978.
(2) If the re-establishment is being considered, will the collection of statistics be widened to cover:
(a) real estate purchases by foreign investors; and
(b) the listing of foreign investors using nominee companies to hide any such transactions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the issues raised by the honourable senator. However, in the interests of controlling expenditure the Government has had to review very carefully all demands upon public resources, including the collection and dissemination of statistics.

(2) The Australian Agricultural Council agreed in Darwin on 3 August, 1981 to consider the establishment of a procedure for the registration of the beneficial ownership of rural land. The Foreign Investment Review Board is liaising with the relevant State authorities on this matter.

In respect of nominee shareholding, it is the practice of the Foreign Investment Review Board to seek from participants in foreign investment proposals information on the beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings where these are of potential significance for the purposes of its consideration of such proposals against the requirements of the Government's foreign investment policy. It should also be noted that Clause 261 of the Companies Bill 1981 gives companies the power to obtain information on the beneficial ownership of their shares.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Kerr-McGee Corporation of America or any subsidiary sought and/or been given permission to negotiate access to uranium deposits in the Northern Territory; if so, on what date was permission given, on whose authority and for what areas is access sought.
(2) What has been the outcome of any negotiations so far.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Outside the Kakadu National Park, mineral exploration in the Northern Territory is the responsibility of the Northern Territory Government. However, I understand that the Kerr-McGee Corporation in association with another company, has recently been offered the grant of an exploration licence over an area in Arnhem Land relating to an interest held or applied for prior to 15 December 1972. The offer is subject to ensuring that satisfactory arrangements are made to protect Aboriginal interests as provided for in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what occasions has the Administrator of Christmas Island been absent from Christmas Island since his appointment.
(2) Which of these absences were for (a) private business; (b) private recreation; (c) official duties; (d) health; and (e) other purposes.
(3) For which of these trips was the Administrator's and/or his wife's fares paid.
(4) For which of these trips was travelling allowance paid.
(5) What was the destination of the trip and the duration of the absence in each case.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Details of travel by the Administrator of Christmas Island and his wife up to 24 June 1981 based on information supplied by the Administrator are set out below. All this travel was approved by the Minister.
(1) (a) 27 August 1980 to 18 September 1980; (b) 26 November 1980 to 3 December 1980; (c) 17 December 1980 to 21 January 1981; (d) 12 May 1981 to 24 June 1981.

(2) (a) and (e) none; (b) and (d) 12 May 1981 to 24 June 1981 was originally for official duties and recreation leave. Due to hospitalisation and surgery, the Administrator was on sick leave from 18 May to 16 June. The balance was used for official duties and recreation leave; (c) official duties were carried out during the other periods with the exception of most weekends, public holidays, and the late Sir John McEwen's Memorial Service on Monday, 1 December 1980. Matters of relevance to Christmas Island were pursued on some weekends and whilst on sick leave.

(3) The Administrator's fare was paid for (1) (a), (1) (b), (1) (c), and (1) (d). His wife's fare was paid for (1) (a), (1) (b), to mainland, (1) (c) from mainland, and (1) (d). His wife accompanied the Administrator on trip (1) (b) but remained on the mainland when the Administrator returned to Christmas Island. His wife returned on 21 January 1981 with the Administrator.
(4) Travelling allowance for the appropriate periods of these visits was paid in accordance with the relevant sections of the 1980 Remuneration Tribunal's Report.

(5) Destination of Trips-(1) (a) Christmas Island-Perth -Melbourne-Canberra-Sydney-Singapore-Christmas Island; (1) (b) Christmas Island-Kuala Lumpur- Melbourne-Canberra-Melbourne-Perth-Christmas Island; (1) (c) Christmas Island-Perth-Melbourne- Canberra-Sydney-Melbourne-Kuala Lumpur- Christmas Island; (1) (d) Christmas Island-Kuala Lumpur- Melbourne-Canberra-Sydney-Coolangatta- Melbourne-Singapore-Christmas Island.
Duration is answered in (1) above.

The Minister has also advised that the Administrator was absent from the Island on official duties from 9 September 1981 to 23 September 1981. Fares for the Administrator and his wife were paid and travelling allowance was paid to the Administrator for this visit. Travel was undertaken Christmas Island-Perth-Melbourne-Canberra-Melbourne-Perth -Christmas Island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, in 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the attention of the Minister for Health been drawn to a report in the Melbourne Age of 28 May 1981, which indicates that Linacre Private Hospital in Victoria sends all its accounts to Nashville, Tennesee, for data processing.
(2) Can the Minister say whether this practice constitutes a breach of confidentiality of patients' records and, if so, what steps will be taken to prevent further abuses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Minister of Health, I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The report in the Melbourne Age of 28 May 1981 has been drawn to my attention. I am advised that data of a statistical nature are posted to the Sydney office of Hospital Corporation of Australia Pty Ltd, for transmission via satellite to the General Electric Computer Bureau in Maryland, United States of America. HCA's parent company in America rents time at the computer bureau to receive incoming information from its hospitals throughout the world. The statistical information transmitted to America covers bed usage figures, profit and loss statements, work flow and equipment usage statistics, and comparative statistics for the previous month. The details are solely for managerial purposes. I understand that Linacre Hospital does not forward any personal patient information to the United States of America for processing. All patients' accounts are prepared and issued locally.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister for Health noted the success of the recent anti-smoking advertising campaign conducted in the New South Wales towns of Coffs Harbour and Lismore by the New South Wales Health Commission.

(2) Is he aware of the Health Commission's calculation that if a national anti-smoking campaign achieved similar results, the Federal Government could save up to $150 million a year on the nation's health bill.
(3) In these circumstances, will the Minister consider launching a national anti-smoking campaign on the same lines as that conducted in New South Wales.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Acting Minister for Health I provide the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) I am aware of a statement to this effect made by the New South Wales Minister for Health, in which he estimated that a 6 per cent drop in smoking in Australia would result in health cost savings (overall, not only to the Federal Government) of between $125 to $150 million per year.
(3) The Government has already indicated its commitment to a national initiative in health promotion.

In 1979-80 it allocated $500,000 to a pilot campaign known as 'Help Yourself', which involved media and local support, aimed at raising general community awareness of health issues, including smoking. The pilot campaign-which covered a number of lifestyle risk factors-using television, radio and print, was trialled in 1980 in Adelaide, Canberra and Goulburn, and was most successful and well received in those communities.

This financial year a further amount of $500,000 has been allocated to enable the examination of alternative approaches in health promotion. A number of different settings, including the home, the workplace and local community, will be examined and work conducted with a variety of professional groups and State and local authorities. Smoking will be included in the program as being one of the risks to good health.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Toowoomba Office

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Social Security intend to remove a social worker from the staff of the Toowoomba office of the Department.
(2) Does this mean there will be no social worker available for areas west of Toowoomba including Roma.
(3) If this is so, why is the Department making this reduction in staff numbers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Department presently employs a Social Worker Class 2 on a permanent basis and a Social Worker Class 1 on a temporary basis. The period of employment approved for the temporary employee is due to expire on 30 October 1981 but approval for an extension is being sought from the Public Service Board.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer the following question, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When an age or invalid pension is paid on request half to the pensioner and half to the spouse, is that payment given as income for taxation purposes?
(2) When an unemployment benefit is paid on request do the same provisions apply as for the age pension?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) An age or invalid pension is income of the person entitled to receive it. Similarly, the wife's pension which is a separate pension paid to the wife of an age or invalid pensioner is income of the wife.

(2) A person in receipt of an unemployment benefit, including any additional benefit for dependants, is liable to tax on the total amount of that entitlement, notwithstanding that personal arrangements may have been made by him with the Department of Social Security to pay the unemployment benefit or part thereof to another person such as, for example, his wife.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government considered the attendant care allowance suggested in the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled paper 'Income Security Policies for Mentally and Physically Disabled People in Australia'.
(2) How many people does it estimate would be eligible for the attendant care allowance and what would be the annual cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The proposal has been examined by my Department as well as interested groups and individuals in the community. These examinations have generated many suggestions by way of possible improvements and alternatives to the proposal based on local and overseas experience. Validation of the figures used in the ACROD proposal has been delayed until such time as further data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics' 1981 Survey of Handicapped Persons is released later this year.

(2) The ACROD Paper estimated 2,500 people would be eligible for such an allowance in the first year of operation with an unestimated increase in uptake in the later years. The scheme was expected to cost $15m in the first year but the bases for these estimates were not spelt out.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the United Nations Association of Australia recently made representations to have a new Commonwealth department established to be known as a Department of International Peace and Security.
(2) Has the Association suggested the establishment at State levels of departments and Ministers of Community Peace.
(3) Has the Association suggested that Australia offer this project as an agenda item at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne in September.
(4) What is the response of the Government to the proposals of the Association.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

The establishment of Ministers and Departments of Community Peace is a matter for consideration by the States. These matters will not be included as an agenda item at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Melbourne.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that the Telecom District Office for the north-west of Western Australia is located in Perth, some 1500km from the nearest major regional centre.
(2) What steps are to be taken to identify the organisation with the people of the region by locating the District Office in the Pilbara.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Telecom has advised me that the District Office for the north-west of Western Australia is identified with the people of the various regions by the 440 or so Telecom staff who reside in the major towns where Telecom work centres are established. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many unofficial post offices were closed in South Australia during (a) 1979-80 and (b) the period 1 January 1981 to 18 August 1981.
(2) Is the Government determined to phase out or substantially reduce unofficial post offices from Australia Post operations; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Australia Post is obliged under the Postal Services Act to continually review its network of post offices (official and non-official) to ensure that the facilities and services provided best meet the reasonable needs of the community, having regard to economy and operation. Under this program, post offices may be identified for closure, where the level of business transacted is not sufficient to justify retention. It is Australia Post's objective, however, to ensure that reasonable alternative arrangements for postal services are made for communities affected by the withdrawal of a post office.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Government review sales tax legislation with a view to relieving the iniquitous situation forced on people of the outback by the imposition of sales tax on the freight component of articles imported from southern States to the Northern Territory.

(2) Will the Government ensure that those people living considerable distances from markets are not penalised for living in remote areas, with the proposed increase in sales tax on building materials.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Examination has been made on many occasions of the question of the inclusion of freight charges in the sales tax base. Basically, the issues are the same whether the taxable goods in question are purchased by persons living in remote areas or persons living in the cities; many goods are produced in one city and sold in another.

The last substantial examination was by the Taxation Review Committee (the Asprey Committee). It did not recommend any change to the present law because in its view equity could not be achieved in the matter of freight charges without sacrificing simplicity and certainty and unduly increasing compliance costs and collection costs.
I am, nevertheless, arranging to have the matter looked at once more. The honourable senator may be assured that his views will be borne in mind in this examination.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

(3) Have these recommendations been implemented; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The answers to the question which the honourable senator has asked are substantially the same as those provided in response to an earlier question asked by him in relation to the Bonnett Report.
I refer the honourable senator to the answer to question No. 2211, Hansard, 23 November 1979 (page 3008).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many research projects have been funded by the Criminology Research Council since its inception.
(2) How many of these projects were concerned with or related to research into 'white collar' crime in Australia.
(3) What percentage of total funds made available to the Criminology Research Council have been expended on research into 'white collar' crime.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) A total of 77 research projects have been funded by the Criminology Research Council covering a wide range of subject matter. Two projects have been concerned with or related to research into 'white collar' crime in Australia, representing approximately two per cent of the funds that have been made available to the Council. However, a number of projects have been undertaken by the Australian Institute of Criminology that have been concerned with or related to white collar crime.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister for Primary Industry advise the Senate of the latest stage for investigations into the horse and kangaroo meat substitution for beef in cartons for export and for domestic consumption.
(2) Have the authorities discovered who is responsible for these occurrences: If so, what prosecution is likely.
(3) Does the government intend to take any action in line with the proposals of the Cattle Council of Australia that fines and penalties should be reviewed and increased.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Federal Police are continuing their investigations into the whole question of horse and kangaroo meat substitution for beef destined for the export and domestic trade.
My information at this time is that inquiries are proceeding satisfactorily.
(2) The Australian Federal police have arrested and charged a man on a number of counts in relation to the misuse of inspection stamps and the alteration or interference with official documents.

(3) Legislation was introduced into Parliament on 10 September 1981, to amend 3 existing Acts, the Customs Act, the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act and the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act in order to substantially increase the penalties under these Acts. A fourth separate new Bill, the Meat Exports (Penalties) Act to provide for offences relating to the misuse of inspection stamps, alteration or interference into description and tags and the making of false or misleading statements was introduced to the Parliament.
These Bills have been passed by the House.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

(2) Will the Minister provide details of all such purchases or contracts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are air traffic controllers in Australia administered under the regulations of the Public Service Act.

(2) Do air traffic controllers (a) work under constant supervision; (b) work irregular shifts; (c) have no meal breaks as such, and (d) never leave the office unattended or take advantage of such benefits as flexitime.

(3) Can the Minister for Transport explain how the Public Service Act can effectively administer a team of specialists whose conditions of employment bear no resemblance to the conditions of employment of the rest of the Public Service.

(4) Does the Minister agree that a system of administration similar to that of the former Department of Civil Aviation would not only create better working conditions and more opportunities for promotion, but also be far more attuned to the special needs of air traffic control than is the general administration of the Department of Transport.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has supplied the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) to (d) Yes. It must be noted that the hours of duty and employment conditions etc., of air traffic controllers have been determined in arbitration with regard to these elements of their work circumstances.

(3) The Public Service comprises a wide variety of disciplines and designations whose hours and pay vary to meet job requirements. Within the Department of Transport there is a variety of staff categories whose work includes shift work, specialised duties and no access to flex-time and throughout the Public Service generally there is an even greater variety of such staff categories. As indicated earlier, while the hours and pay of these people vary, the general code of conditions under which they are employed is a common one based on their employment under the Public Service Act and Regulations. There is, therefore, a long history of demonstrable effective administration within this legislative cover.
(4) Under the former Department of Civil Aviation the basic conditions of air traffic controllers, as Public Servants, were subject to the same broad administrative arrangements as now.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of the Aboriginal Electoral Education program being conducted by the Australian Electoral Office (AEO).
(2) How many teams of how many people are employed.
(3) For how long have the teams operated and in what areas.
(4) What was the cost of the program (a) in this financial year and (b) in previous financial years.
(5) What co-operation, if any, and in what form, has been obtained from State Electoral Offices in the conduct of the program.
(6) Have any restrictions been placed on the activities of the education teams by any State authorities or individuals; if so what are the details.
(7) How many Aboriginal people have enrolled as Commonwealth and State electors as a result of the education team activities.
(8) Do AEO staff on the education program solicit enrolment by Aborigines in the Northern Territory where Territory law requires Aboriginal people to be enrolled; if not, why not.
(9) Does the Government propose to amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act to bring it into line with the Northern Territory Act; if so, when; if not, why not.
(10) What surveys have been conducted to check on the effectiveness or otherwise of the electoral education program.
(11) Has the AEO, as a result of its education program, made any recommendations for (a) amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act; and (b) more educational teams to be employed.
(12) If so, will the Minister supply details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) There are three teams, each consisting of two members.

(3) One team operates amongst Aboriginal communities in Western Australia and another in South Australia (including the southern region of the Northern Territory). These teams have been in the field since July 1979. The third team, covering the northern regions of the Northern Territory, began operations in January 1981.

(5) The Aboriginal Electoral Education Program has been developed with the full consultation of the governments of Western Australia, South Australia and the Northern Territory. All three governments agreed to the proposal for a Commonwealth Program to provide electoral education on both Commonwealth and State/Territory electoral procedures.
(6) No restrictions have been placed on the activities of the Aboriginal Electoral Education Team in the States and Territory in which we are operating.

(7) The Aboriginal Electoral Education Program is not an enrolment campaign. The team members cannot enrol Aboriginals, although they may witness enrolment claims, including Western Australian State enrolment claims. In any event, it would not be possible to estimate the precise number of Aboriginals who chose to enrol as a result of the electoral activities of a team as distinct from those who happened to seek enrolment while a team was in their area.

(8) No. It was agreed with Northern Territory authorities that the teams would only provide joint Commonwealth/Territory electoral education (including some explanation of the different Commonwealth/Territory enrolment requirements).

(9) The Government has a commitment to amend the Commonwelth Electoral Act to change voluntary to compulsory enrolment for Aboriginals. This commitment was made after consultation with the Council for Aboriginal Development.
(10) The Australian Electoral Office monitors the program and the activities of the teams.

At the time of the June 1980 election for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, a special electoral education campaign was conducted by the Australian Electoral Office in collaboration with Northern Territory electoral and education authorities. Some of the education material which is used by the teams was also used in this campaign. An evaluation of the effectiveness of this material (an illustrated explanatory booklet, You Can Have Your Say, and an instructor's guide to the booklet; sets of voting papers including how-to-vote cards and ballot papers for realistic 'mock' elections; an information pamphlet entitled Parliament-Enrolment-Voting; and a film, also called You Can Have Your Say) was made by the North Australian Research Unit of the Australian National University which prepared a general report on Aboriginal electoral education and the effectiveness of mobile polling for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly election. The report 'Electoral Education and Mobile Polling' (ISBN909569 57 3) is available in the Parliamentary Library.
(11) (a) Any amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act are a matter of Government policy.

(b) The financial and staff considerations of extending the Program to other States are matters the Australian Electoral Office has under consideration. Any extension of the Program to other States would, of course, need to be the subject of consultation with the relevant State Governments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 16 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Social Security undertake to increase the level of permissible earnings, before penalty, for persons receiving the Sheltered Employment Allowance in order that these earnings be made equal in value to the SEA payment, since people who work in sheltered workships lose fifty cents out of every dollar they earn over their $20 allowance, which is effectively 50 per cent taxation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Recipients of sheltered employment allowances (SEA) like other social security pensioners may receive $20 a week (single pensioners) and $34.50 (pensioner couple) of non-pension income without affecting the amount of SEA payable. Above these 'free areas', the allowance (or pension) is reduced by 50 cents for each dollar of non-pension income. Non-pension income includes earnings from sheltered employment. This means that at current rates of pension, single and married recipients of income-tested pensions (and SEA) continue to receive some pension (or SEA) until non-pension income reaches $153.30 a week and $256.70 a week respectively.

Increasing the 'free areas' for SEA recipients would inevitably bring pressures for similar increases in the 'free areas' for age, invalid and sole parent pensioners. Increases to the levels suggested would be very costly. For example, doubling the 'free areas' at current rates of pension would cost some $140m in a full year. Given the continuing need for expenditure restraint, the priority of such a measure must be viewed against other priorities in the system. The estimated full year cost of continuing the twice yearly indexation of pensions for example in respect of the November 1981 and May 1982 increases alone is some $715m.

SEA recipients already enjoy two other advantages over other pensioners. SEA (like invalid pension) is not subject to personal income tax, and recipients are paid a tax free, income-test-free Incentive Allowance of $5 a week. As announced in the last Budget, the latter payment is to be increased to $8 a week from February 1982.
As in the past, the Government will continue to keep this matter under review.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 June 1981 (Hansard, page 2796), Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning Australian ship monopoly in the Australian coastal trades.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

There are several factors contributing to the freight rate charge for transporting steel between Port Kembla and Fremantle or Japan and Fremantle. The freight rate would be influenced by inter alia, the type of vessel employed, the size of cargo and availability of backloading and the financial, social and national environment in which it operates.

It should be noted that a significant proportion of the cost of transporting an item by coastal shipping arises from stevedoring charges, which are land based and not directly shipping industry generated. In the case of steel shipped from Port Kembla to Fremantle stevedoring costs would be the same whatever the nationality of the vessel.

It is not accurate to say that the coasting trade is a monopoly enforced by Government action. Any vessel meeting certain safety and licensing requirements may trade on the Australian coast. In essence the licensing provisions of the Navigation Act require that vessels trading on the coast must meet Australian manning, accommodation and wage standards.

At present there are no restrictions on the import of new vessels for coastal operations or alternatively potential owners can order vessels up to about 10,000 gross construction tonnes from Australian shipbuilding yards where, of course, bounty is available for local ship construction.

The protection afforded Australian coastal shipping is no different from the protection of coastal trades, or cabotage, practised by many other countries. Given that coastal shipping is as much a part of domestic transport as is road, rail or air transport I do not see that the requirement to meet Australian manning, accommodation and wage standards constitutes a level of protection that warrants an inquiry into the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August 1981 (Hansard, page 50) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked a question without notice concerning standardisation of telephone installation and rental fees.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In recognition of the problems facing applicants for telephone service in country areas the Australian Telecommunications Commission has reviewed the question of rural lines regularly and the rural lines policy has been significantly liberalised in recent years. Since 1975, the free line entitlement for these subscribers has been doubled from 8 kilometres to 16 kilometres and the rate of contribution for lines extending beyond the free line limit has been held at $160 per half kilometre even though the cost has risen to about twice that amount. Furthermore, if they so desire, applicants may spread payment of the contribution over a period of three years, with interest charged at the short term Telecom Loan rate. To assist further applicants who require long lines, a special rental of $500 per annum has been adopted as an alternative to a capital contribution and no service connection fee is paid.

Telecom does not expect individual country subscribers to pay the full cost of their lines; for example, the total capital investment, on average, for a service 20 kilometres from an exchange is of the order of $15,000. However, Telcom believes that, where such a large investment is involved, the subscribers concerned should bear a reasonable share of that investment. This is particularly so when capital is in short supply and when viewed in the light of the fact that earnings from telephone services in country areas are generally insufficient to recoup costs of providing and maintaining them, so that there is a significant level of cross-subsidisation of country services by urban users of Telecom facilities.

Concerning a standard connection fee and yearly rental throughout Australia beyond the 16 kilometre point, Telecom considers that it would be inequitable for urban subscribers to bear a greater proportion of rural costs. The country lines program is continually under review but, having regard to the existing level of cross-subsidisation of country services and the current and future planned levels of capital expenditure in country areas, Telecom indicated that it is not in a position at this stage to liberalise further the conditions under which country services are provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 August 1981 (Hansard, page 138) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, the following question without notice:

In conjunction with these import controls, local manufacturers of measuring devices, on a voluntary basis, restricted the availability of non-metric devices to applications where a continuing need existed. This voluntary arrangement was terminated with the announcement of the intended repeal of the import controls.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Sales Tax Increase: Effect on Foodstuffs

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 August 1981 (Hansard, page 251) Senator Haines asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware of the fact that, for a variety of reasons, it is impossible to purchase any food ultimately in an unwrapped form? Is the Minister therefore aware that, in his Budget, by placing a sales tax on wrapping the Government is effectively increasing the cost of all foodstuffs, whether staple items or luxuries? If the Minister is aware of the effect, will he explain why the Government chose to put this de facto tax on food? If he was not aware of it, will he undertake to discuss with the Treasurer the removal of the forecast sales tax placed on wrapping and hence effectively on foodstuffs?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Government's decision to place a sales tax at 2.5 per cent on wrapping and packaging materials as from 1 January 1982 was taken as part of its policy to broaden the sales tax base to provide a better mix of direct and indirect taxes. The Government is conscious that by taking this step there could be an indirect tax effect on some foodstuffs. However, any effect will be minimal because the tax will apply only to wrapping materials used at the retail level. Manufacturers and wholesalers of foodstuffs will still obtain their packaging materials free of tax. Foodstuffs sold over the counter by retailers in the form in which they were packaged by manufacturers or wholesalers will not bear any tax on that packaging. Also, certain wrapping materials such as wrapping used by butchers and delicatessens to wrap up meat will continue to be exempt. The kinds of wrapping materials that will become taxable include wrapping papers, bags and carry-bags supplied by retailers as a service to their customers or for shop security reasons.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 319) Senator Teague asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning arts funding.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Visual Arts Board of the Australia Council has advised me that it is factually correct to assert that that Board favours artists working in contemporary styles. The Board believes, as I am further advised, that it is in this sphere that new artistic forces will emerge. Moreover, artists working in experimental or unfamiliar ways are less liable to obtain assistance from other sources and their work may be less easy to sell.

I am also informed that through its support for the Australian Gallery Directors Council, the Visual Arts Board gives significant assistance to the more traditional styles of art, including the mounting of exhibitions of historical art. In 1980 the Australian Gallery Directors Council's exhibitions programs attracted an audience of 1.9 million people. These exhibitions included Pompeii AD 79; France: The Revolutionary Decades; 19th and 20th Century Masters from the Baron Von Thyssen Collection and the Old Master Drawings from the Albertina Collection.

I am informed by the Australian National Gallery that its acquisitions policy was approved by the Government in 1977, and was published in the Australian National Gallery Annual Report, 1976-77. The approved policy covers Australian Art; the Arts of Asia and South East Asia; Primitive Art; European Art before 1850; and Art of the Modern Period (from 1850); Prints, Drawings and Illustrated Books; Sculpture; Decorative Art; Photography and Film.

I am further informed by the Australian National Gallery that within these areas of acquisitions there are no inherent biases. The only considerations that apply are that the works of art should be of the highest aesthetic standard and bear relationship to other works in the area.

The aim is to establish a National Gallery with collections which will complement and extend those of other Australian galleries and provide the Australian community with visual art experience of the highest order. It is intended that the Gallery will be a source of national pride and stand among the leading art museums of the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 314) Senator Hill asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware that yachts are presently being constructed for a new South Australian tourist venture, namely, that of skippered yacht charter in South Australian waters. Is the Minister also aware that to date construction of yachts in such circumstances has not attracted sales tax. Will the Minister confirm that this is regarded as one of the sales tax anomalies referred to in the Budget which are to be corrected. If so, will the Minister indicate whether the Government gave consideration to the effect the imposition of a 17 1/2 per cent sales tax would have upon this new South Australian industry. If not, will she indicate whether the Government would be prepared to do so and to consider an exemption if it finds the viability of establishment of this industry to be threatened by the imposition?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

During the deliberations which preceded the recent Budget, when proposals to remove a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the sales tax law were being considered, the Government was mindful of the effect that the proposed changes would have on the various sections of the community, including industry.

The anomaly recognised by the Government was that, where a yacht was acquired by a person to hire it out with crew for pleasure, sport or recreation, it was exempt from sales tax. On the other hand, a yacht acquired for use for the same purposes without crew was subject to sales tax. There is no logical reason for such a distinction and the Government has moved to treat all such yachts equally.

The Government would, of course, be concerned if the viability of any industry was threatened by the elimination of this particular anomaly. It must be questioned, however, whether sales tax concessions conferring competitive advantages are an appropriate means of assisting any sector of industry to maintain a profitable operation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard page 384) Senator Coleman asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of the directive issued by the Minister she represents that the film On Sacred Ground is not to be distributed through Australian overseas posts? The Minister apparently feels-and I quote his statement-'that considerable harm could be done to Australia's image' if the film is distributed overseas. I make the point, very briefly, that the film was viewed by a fairly large audience in Parliament House last night and was extremely well received. It is a documentary on factual lifestyles of Aboriginal people in Western Australia and was produced to promote interracial understanding. In view of the interest already shown-I understand that requests have been received at three of our embassies already-will the Minister review the directive given and allow this very worthwhile, well-produced and well-documented film to be distributed in the usual manner through the Australian embassies?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Officers of my Department were among an audience that was invited to preview the film late last year. They subsequently were advised that the Australian Film Commission (AFC) did not intend to distribute the film to our overseas missions because it was not regarded by the AFC as being suitable for showing overseas and because the film was expensive ($900 a print plus freight costs). Officers of my Department saw no reason to request the AFC to vary its decision.

The AFC also advised that it intended sending video tapes of the film to its representatives in London and Los Angeles, and to outlets in Tokyo and Manila, with a view to selling the film to television stations. This was a commercial decision aimed at recovering some of the costs of making the film.

My Department was concerned that while the AFC had decided not to distribute the film to overseas posts, it was at the same time proposing to offer it for sale to overseas television stations where there would be no control over the use of the film. They were also concerned that overseas audiences, unlike Australian audiences, would lack knowledge of the divided responsibility for Aboriginal affairs that is a consequence of the Australian federal system and which is necessary to understand the issues involved at Noonkanbah. This is not made clear in the film.

A further concern was that overseas distribution of a film made by a Commonwealth instrumentality which included criticism of the Western Australian Government's policies could prejudice the domestic consultations between Commonwealth and State authorities on land rights and mining issues. Since advancement of Aboriginal interests requires co-operation between the Commonwealth and State authorities, it would be contrary to the best interests of the Aboriginals if the Commonwealth Government were seen by a State government to be acquiescing in the overseas showing of such a film.

Foreign policy considerations clearly dictate that the Australian Government should not do anything that would inhibit the realisation of the advances in Aboriginal rights to which it is committed, nor do anything that could negate the advances already made. Equally, any criticism that the film generated overseas would in all probability be directed at Australia without any acknowledgement of the Commonwealth Government's policy and achievements in Aboriginal affairs.

The above considerations led me to conclude that selling On Sacred Ground to overseas television stations would be contrary to Australia's foreign policy interests and put at risk the implementation of the Commonwealth Government's policies for the advancement of Aboriginals. I accordingly wrote to the Minister for Home Affairs suggesting that he might wish to consider further the Australian Film Commission's proposal.

Subsequently, the AFC decided not to sell the film to overseas television stations and Film Australia decided that in the light of developments since the film was made, it required further editing to bring it up to date. They are also proposing to reduce the length of the film from its current 58 minutes to approximately 40 minutes to fit in with school teaching periods which they see as an important use. The AFC will be looking at the edited film when completed to decide their attitude to overseas distribution of the film.

My Department will continue to work with the AFC and Film Australia so as to ensure that Film Australia's contributions to Australia's overseas information activities are as effective as possible. Film Australia has a difficult task since it is charged with the dual role of telling the world about Australia and Australians about themselves. It is not always possible to accomplish both objectives in the one film and films intended principally for Australian audiences may not necessarily be suitable for overseas audiences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard, page 376) Senator Button asked as part of a question without notice on the 'Buy Australian' policy, whether Telecom Australia is the largest purchaser of high technology equipment in Australia and if Telecom Australia has a policy of buying up to 80 per cent Australian technology.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In 1977, when introducing a new system of local exchange switching equipment using stored program controlled techniques, an Australian content of 80 per cent was stipulated. As a consequence of its dedication to local sourcing, 90 per cent of all telecommunications supplies are obtained from Australian industry sources.
Telecom is certainly a very large purchaser of high technology equipment in Australia and has done much to foster the local telecommunications manufacturing industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 September 1981 (Hansard, page 489) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Whether his attention has been drawn to statements by the former General Manager of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Mr Harold White, that telephone subscribers are being forced to pay more because the government refuses to fulfil its function as the sole shareholder of Telecom Australia. Mr White alleged that these extra telephone charges were due in large measure to the Government's tight restrictions on borrowings by Telecom.

(2) In addition to those aspects of the question, will the Minister confirm that the report by the McKinsey organisation in relation to Telecom's borrowing capacity has been in the hands of the Government for well over a year?
(3) Is it not a fact that that report has been suppressed by the Government because it criticises the way in which the Government has exercised unfair controls over Telecom's borrowing capacity?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:
(1) Yes.
(2) The report was transmitted to me by Telecom Australia in November 1980.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 563), Senator Evans asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it the case that the Government is planning as one of its highest category legislative priorities this session the passage of a defence (Call-out) Bill to clarify the position of the military when called in aid of the civil power, as notoriously happened in the aftermath of the Hilton bombing? Is it the case that the Government will attempt to introduce and pass such legislation prior to the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting later this month, notwithstanding the now very few parliamentary days available for consideration of what will obviously by a very sensitive matter?
Will the Minister refresh himself from the confidential Cabinet paper describing the legislative priorities for this session and, in particular, category one of that paper?

TALK.START.PARA: also asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice, on 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 823):

Is the Minister aware that the now confirmed abandonment by the Government of its proposed defence (call-out) Bill has left a dangerous vacuum in the law governing military intervention in civil emergencies in that if troops are called out in reliance solely on the Commonwealth's general executive power under section 61 of the Constitution, as happened after the Hilton bombing at the 1978 Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting, there are simply no rules in existence governing the duration of the Army presence, the powers of individual soldiers and the lines of authority as between the civil and military authorities? Is the Minister further aware that Mr Justice Hope found in one of the unreleased parts of his royal commmission report on national security that the present situation was seriously inadequate in a number of respects, drew attention to this vacuum and, in fact, recommended urgent remedial legislation to clarify the situation for everyone concerned and for the community generally? How can the Government justify its inertia on this matter? Is it because it wants to have open-ended and unlimited military powers available to it in the event of some real or imagined security crisis errupting at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

Since 1978 the Government has put considerable effort into measures designed to counter potential terrorist threats to Australia and its interests. Revision of the legislative provisions governing Defence Force aid to the civil power is an important part of this program and is receiving close attention. It is, however, a complex exercise and, as Mr Justice Hope pointed out in his protective security review, there are important principles and safeguards which must be incorporated in the new legislation.

The development of legislative proposals will take some time and it is not the Government's intention to attempt to introduce new legislation before the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. Proper consideration by Parliament is necessary and close consultation with the State and Northern Territory governments will also be required.

I should emphasise that, contrary to recent media speculation, the new legislation will not be seeking to create any new authority for the use of the Defence Force in aid of civilian security. Mr Justice Hope, and Sir Victor Windeyer in the opinion which he gave to the protective security review, confirmed that the authority already exists for calling out the Defence Force in aid of civilian security. The procedures for doing so are understood by the Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory Governments. In accordance with the recommendation of the protective security review, the new legislation is being developed to tighten, clarify and update the existing provisions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 555) Senator Primmer asked me the following question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate:

ANSWER.PARA: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry: Is it a fact that the suspension of export operations of all independent boning rooms in Victoria will lead to the stand down of up to 2,500 employees? Is the Minister aware that such a stand down will involve a loss in wages for these workers of $900 to $1,000 each? In view of the fact that these employees are the innocent victims of the incompetence and procrastination of the present Minister and his predecessor, will the Minister ensure that any loss of wages will be fully and promptly compensated for by the Government?
The Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I suspended the registration of these establishments subsequent to a further finding of horse meat in product shipped from Establishment No. 622, Jason Meats Pty Ltd of the Melbourne suburb of Abbotsford. This action was necessary to assure meat importing countries that the situation in Victoria-where the problem seemed to be centred-was under control. It was necessary to demonstrate that action was adequate to ensure substitution was no longer possible.

The way was open, by compliance with the new controls, for resumption of export activities with minimum delay. In fact 28 of the establishments affected have already done so and had their suspension notices removed.
The security and control conditions which applied initially to the Victorian independent boning rooms were rapidly imposed on all other independent boning rooms through Australia.

The management of the suspended establishments in the majority of cases were quick to respond to the new requirements, and consequently the effect on employment would have been minimal. Without the prompt and firm action taken by the Government, it is certain that a far more serious reaction against Australian meat exports generally would have resulted. This would in turn have had extremely serious repercussions for the meat industry and on employment throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 637) Senator Townley asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, a question without notice concerning the synchronisation of traffic lights.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

A considerable amount of research has already been undertaken in Australia concerning the co-ordination of traffic lights. A highly sophisticated traffic light co-ordination system covering much of the Sydney metropolitan area is in operation known as the Sydney Co-ordinated Adaptive Traffic system (SCAT). Smaller schemes operate in Melbourne and other centres. There is ample evidence that appropriate co-ordination of traffic lights can reduce delays, vehicle emissions, fuel consumption and accidents. Such systems are highly cost-effective.

Because co-ordination of traffic lights along major traffic routes has to take into account the effect upon cross-traffic at the various signalised intersections, the devising of co-ordination systems appropriate to particular situations is already a significant area of research in Australia and overseas. The appropriate form of co-ordination in Melbourne, for instance, where there tends to be a regular pattern of major cross routes may be different from that appropriate in Sydney where there tends to be more of a radial pattern with a few major ring routes.

It should be noted that the vast majority of Australian traffic light installations, although not co-ordinated, do respond to traffic demand by means of inductive loops buried just below the road surface. Much of the dissatisfaction expressed by motorists at signal delays arises from poor maintenance and inappropriate settings rather than inadequate equipment or lack of co-ordination.

The Department of Transport is familiar with developments in this field in the United States. In this context it should also be noted that most traffic signal installations in the United States operate on a fixed-time basis, often on a grid of streets, and co-ordination, although fairly straightforward, may result in long delays for cross-traffic.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Meat Industry: Statements by Senator Primmer

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 634) Senator Sibraa asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question concerned the response to Senator Primmer's statement in the Senate in March 1978 about the Australian meat export industry.

ANSWER.PARA: The Acting Minister for Primary Industry has supplied me with the following additional information:
