ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 635) Senator Bonner asked me a question without notice requesting the Minister for Transport to give consideration to amending the Road Grants Act 1981 to provide a transition period for the tender provisions of the legislation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Since early 1980 the Government had been pressing for State road authorities to use the tender and contract system for construction works on national roads. The Government decided when framing the 1981 Act that it had given adequate warning and so a long transition period was not justified.
The Roads Grants Act 1981 requires that tenders be invited and dealt with in accordance with approved procedures for all construction works on national roads commencing after 31 August 1981.

In making the decision requiring the calling of tenders the Commonwealth recognised that there could be some displacement or redeployment of day labour employees as road construction works on national roads were taken up by private contractors. The Government therefore decided that the tender procedures should allow the State road authority and local government authorities to bid for the work.

The Government realised that state and local government's local knowledge and long experience in road works should place them in a very competitive position to win projects under the tender system. This has been confirmed in one instance already where a State road authority, in competition with private contractors, bid for and won a million dollar job.

The choice as to whether to bid or not for a national roads construction project is a matter for each State and local government authority. In the case of the Tiaro shire the council made a decision not to bid for national road works.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 September 1981 (Hansard, page 728) Senator Archer asked a question concerning the 15 per cent increase in Australian National Line's freight rates and whether this increase would be taken into account in the current adjustments being made to the Tasmanian Freight Equalisation Scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following additional information:

The scheme's schedule is currently being revised to take account of movements in interstate sea freight rates to and from Tasmania and also mainland interstate land freight rates that have occurred since the schedule was last revised. In order that the schedule can be calculated accurately, the Minister for Transport directed that freight rates which applied on 1 May 1981 would be used.

As the revision of TFES schedule is a complex time consuming task, adjustments are not made each time there is an increase in either shipping freight rates or mainland interstate road/rail freight rates. Accordingly freight rate increases that have been implemented since 1 May 1981 will not be taken into consideration in the current recalculation.

Given that the purpose of TFES is to remove the transport cost disadvantage suffered by Tasmanians because of their almost total reliance on shipping for interstate cargo movements, the recent increase in ANL's freight rates would not necessarily warrant further increases in the TFES schedule. This would depend on the extent to which there have been increases in mainland freight rates since 1 May 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1981 (Hansard, page 752) Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, a question without notice regarding a report in the Australian of that day headed 'Illiteracy in Computing'.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Science and Technology advises as follows:

Computing and, more generally, information technology, is assuming increasing importance in industry, commerce, government and the community. The Government recognises this and believes that the successful application of these and other new technologies is crucial to Australia's continued industrial development.

A major influence on the successful establishment of new, technology-based firms of the type referred to in the Australian is the existence of a favourable economic climate. For this reason, the Government considers that its policies, which are designed to maintain a climate of economic growth and improved opportunities for business, are a prerequisite for the creation and growth of firms in these industries.
In addition, the Government has assisted in promoting community awareness of the benefits and opportunities offered by the information technologies referred to in the honourable Senator's question.

A significant indication of the Government's concern in this area is its sponsorship, through the Department of Science and Technology in conjunction with the Australian Computer Society, of Information Technology Week, which was held during August. Information Technology Week introduced many people all over Australia to new information technologies. It focused public attention on the important role which integrated information systems can play in maintaining the viability and international competitiveness of our industries.

The Government is also conscious of the importance of microelectronics to nearly all sectors of Australian industry. For this reason, a condition of the offer made to the National Semiconductor Corporation to establish a wafer fabrication plant in Canberra is that the Corporation should assist the adoption of microelectronic technology by Australian industry, through the establishment of applications centres.

Australia has already developed a microelectronics industrial capacity which includes the manufacture of computor hardware. Moreover, there is growing evidence that some local manufacturers are able to compete in overseas markets and in the expanding domestic market. In the field of computer software, where local involvement in systems development and applications has been more extensive, Australian firms have shown considerable innovative potential.
The Government expects to receive shortly a report from the Australian Science and Technology Council on the microelectronics industry in Australia.

In addition, in keeping with the Government's announcement of November 1976, the question of assistance to the computer industry will be referred to the Industries Assistance Commission by early 1982 to provide time for a review of assistance well in advance of the expiration of the ADP Bounty Act in 1984.

On the technical level, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Reseach Organisation has established a group to develop the design of very large scale integrated circuits. The purpose of this research is to develop integrated circuits which exploit more fully the potential for miniaturisation of electronic components. If successful, the results will be of considerable assistance to Australian industry in gaining a share of the burgeoning range of applications for microelectronic technologies.

The honourable senator asked specifically that a board be set up to administer grants to Australian computer companies to increase their research and development capabilities. Computor manufacturing companies are already eligible to receive grants under the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act. Of the $23m provided under the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act in 1979-80 for project grants, nearly $1m was allocated directly for industrial research and development in the fields of computing and microelectronics. A further $1.9m was spent in these fields under the public interest provision of the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act and through Industry Productivity Improvement Programs administered by the Department of Science and Technology.

Senator Townley also suggested that computer software companies be made eligible to apply for grants under this Act. The purpose of the Act is to promote development and improve efficiency by encouraging industrial research and development in the manufacturing, mining and construction industries. Computer software companies are therefore not eligible for direct grant support. However, where computer software research and development relates directly to the development of new products or new or improved processes employed in manufacturing, mining or on-site construction operations, such activities are eligible to receive project grant assistance. In other cases, grant recipients may contract their computer software research and development projects to those computer software companies which have been accredited as approved research organisations under the Act.

The Government does not wish to extend eligibility for grant support under the Act to the computer software industry generally, as this would dilute the effectiveness of the scheme. It would also represent the provision of assistance to an industry which is already highly innovative in the absence of significant government support.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 818) Senator Primmer asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry in the Senate. His question was:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that about three weeks ago officials of the Australiasian Meat Industry Employees Union notified the Department of Primary Industry of the possibility of contaminated meat either in or having passed through cold stores at Townsville, Port Hedland, Wyndham and Adelaide? If so, what action did the Department take on the report?
The Acting Minister for Primary Industry has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

No record of any such notification from the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has been found. If the Union has evidence of contaminated meat being stored in, or passing through registered export establishments this evidence should be forwarded immediately to the Australian Federal Police who are currently carrying out investigations into the meat substitution problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, pages 825-6) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the Azaria Chamberlain Case.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Northern Territory Chief Minister, Mr Everingham, has directed Northern Territory police to make further enquiries into the circumstances surrounding the death of Azaria Chamberlain at Ayers Rock.
The Chief Minister has indicated that additional information has come to light which was not available at the time of the inquest and so was not available to the coroner.
Mr Everingham has stated the new information resulted from research and investigations carried out by Professor J. M. Cameron, Professor of Forensic Medicine at the London Hospital Medical College.

I understand that as a consequence of receiving this information, Mr Everingham conferred with the Territory's Solicitor-General and the Police Commissioner and reviewed the whole matter with them and sought independent advice from leading counsel.

Mr Everingham, in a Press statement issued on 19 September 1981, stated: 'I am duty bound to direct police to make further inquiries. I deeply regret this, particularly as re-opening the case may cause distress. However, I have no alternative but to act conscientiously in the discharge of my duties as Attorney-General'.
If requested, the Commonwealth would assist the Northern Territory in its enquiries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 816) Senator Lewis asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, a question without notice relating to an industrial dispute in the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia).

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The industrial dispute between OTC(A) and the Professional Radio and Electronics Institute of Australia (PREIA) was resolved on 18 September 1981 following an agreement between the parties.

The PREIA had imposed selective bans on operations. These were: a complete ban on traffic tape changes and fault repair in both telex exchanges; a total ban on all fault repair; maintenance and restoration of equipment at Moree Satellite Earth Station; and a ban on all negotiations, discussions, preparation and implementation of services concerned with the forth-coming Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting.
So far as I am aware, there was no conspiracy of silence on the part of the Australian Press in reporting on the dispute.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Income Tax Avoidance: Australian Broadcasting Commission Program

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981,(Hansard, page 819) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that a private investment consultant, Mr Bruce Bond, is a regular guest on the Australian Broadcasting Commission talk-back radio program Brian Minards Morning in Canberra? Is he also aware that on a recent occasion this consultant gave advice to callers on ways of avoiding tax on income from their investments? Does the Minister consider it appropriate for the ABC to provide opportunities for those in private business to advertise their services in this way? What action will he take to ensure that the ABC is not used as a vehicle for tax avoidance advice?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Mr Bruce Bond provides two programs a week for ABC Radio on Station 2CN Canberra.

His approach to ways in which payment of income tax may be minimised are entirely within the law and are not tax avoidance schemes. Mr Bond is not a private consultant and he has informed listeners to the ABC on many occasions that he does not take private clients. His services are available to the media and it is in this context that the ABC uses his expertise, as do other broadcasting organisations and publishers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 886) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it true, as reported, that an Australian diplomat is at present in Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, on a two-week visit approved by the Afghanistan Government? Was the visit carried out secretly to avoid disclosure that the diplomat had applied for a visa from a government not recognised by Australia? On a similar matter, I ask: Is it a fact that Soviet trade missions have regularly visited Australia in the last few months without obstruction but that members of cultural and scientific delegations have been denied visas as a result of the Soviet incursion into Afghanistan?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is correct that Soviet trade visitors have come to Australia since the invasion of Afghanistan. They continue to do so, as do other Soviet visitors, such as tourists and people coming for private reasons, whose entry is not prevented by the measures the Government introduced following the Soviet invasion.

The Government's measures were calculated very carefully in terms of reasonable costs to the Australian community and impact upon the Soviet authorities. There seemed no point, for example, in cutting off valuable trade when most of the commodities Australia sells the Soviet Union are readily available from other suppliers who were not prepared to discontinue their sales. Thus, since Afghanistan, commercial exchanges with the Soviet Union have continued, as indeed have diplomatic contacts.

In other ways, however, Australia's trade and economic relations with the Soviet Union have been affected by the Government's post-Afghanistan policy. For example, there are no exchanges of visits by Ministers and very senior officials of the Commonwealth and Soviet Governments; Australian trade promotion activities in the Soviet Union have ceased; and activities of the Bilateral Mixed Commission on Trade and Economic Co-operation remain suspended.

The Government's post-Afghanistan policy towards the Soviet Union continues to disallow a range of bilateral cooperation, including cultural, scientific, sporting and trade union exchanges, and co-operation in such fields as fisheries and civil aviation. I regret to say that so far the Soviet Union has given the Government no cause to reconsider that policy.
